fullText: or abjĭc- , ĕre, jēci, jectum, 3, v. a. , to cast away, to throw away, throw down.  Lit.:  Müll.: : :  so, :  so, : : .—Absol.: .—Also with in and abl., when the place from which a thing is thrown is designated:  Madv. N. cr.; so, ut se abiceret in herba, : :  cf.: . Fig.  In gen., to cast off, throw away, give up, etc.:  Vahl.: nusquam ego vidi abjectas aedīs, nisi modo hasce, thrown away, i.e. sold too low, : psaltria aliquo abiciendast, must be got rid off , : : : : . In partic.  To throw off, cast aside care for, remembrance of, etc., to give up, abandon: : : domum Sullanam desperabam jam . . . sed tamen non abjeci, but yet I have not abandoned it, i. e. its purchase, : . To cast down to a lower grade, to degrade, humble, : hic annus senatus auctoritatem abjecit, degraded or lowered the authority of the Senate,  so also  .—Hence, abjectae res, reduced circumstances ,   . Abicere se, to throw one's self away, degrade one's self, v. : ut enim fit, etc.—Hence, abjectus, a, um, P. a., downcast, disheartened, désponding; low, mean, abject, worthless, unprincipled.  Quo me miser conferam? An domum? matremne ut miseram lamentantem videam et abjectam? Gracch. ap. : .— Nihil abjectum, nihil humile cogitare, : : —Comp.:  .—Sup.: —Adv.: abjectē.  Dispiritedly, despondingly:  .— Low, meanly: : .

In technical lang., to bring a work to a close, to complete, finish .—So of the sacrificial cake: ;   cf.   —So in Sallust repeatedly, both with acc. and de, of an historical statement, to bring to a conclusion, to relate: , n. 2:  cf.: .— Hence, absŏlūtus, a, um, P. a., brought to a conclusion, finished, ended, complete . , āfui , āfŭtūrus , v. n., in its most general signif., to be away from, be absent.  In gen.  Absol. without designating the distance : : : : facile aerumnam ferre possum, si inde abest injuria, Caecil. ap. .— With reference to the distance in space or time; which is expressed either by a definite number, or, in gen., by the advs. multum, paulum longe, etc.: : : : : : :  .—With the simple abl. for ab:  Görenz; but, ab ejus villa, B. and K.; cf.: .— With inter: .—With prope, propius, proxime, to denote a short distance:  : : :  so  Caes. ap. —Hence the phrase: tantum abest, ut—ut, so far from —that, etc. : : ego vero istos tantum abest ut ornem, ut effici non possit, quin eos oderim, so far am I from—that,  sometimes etiam or quoque is added to the second clause, Lentul. ap.   more rarely contra, . Sometimes the second ut is left out:  on the contrary, once in Cic. with a third ut: tantum abest ut nostra miremur, ut usque eo difficiles ac morosi simus, ut nobis non satisfaciat ipse Demosthenes, Or. 29, 104. Hence,  To be away from any thing unpleasant, to be freed or free from: : : a reprehensione temeritatis, Planc. ap. . To be removed from a thing by will, inclination, etc.; to be disinclined to ' a consilio fugiendi, : : . toto aberant bello, . To be removed from a thing in regard to condition or quality, i. e. to be different from, to differ = abhorrere abest a tua virtute et fide, Brut. et Cass. ap. : istae  non longe absunt a scelere, : ,   42.—Since improvement, as well as deterioration, may constitute the ground of difference, so absum may, according to its connection, designate the one or the other:  : longissime Plancius a te afuit, i. e. valde, plurimis suffragiis, te vicit, was far from you in the number of votes, i. e. had the majority; v. Wunder ad Planc. proleg. p. 83 sq.; on the other hand, to be less, inferior: longe te a pulchris abesse sensisti, Cic. Fragm. ap. :  so . Not to be suitable, proper, or fit for a thing: : . To be wanting, = desum, Pac. ap. : : quaeris id quod habes;  cf.  and 1095.—After Cicero, constr. in this signif. with dat.: : .—So esp. in the poets:   .—Hence the phrase non multum , paulum, non procul, minimum, nihil abest, quin. not much, little, nothing is wanting that ; but not parum, since parum in good classical authors does not correspond in meaning with non multum, but with non satis :  and absol.: : : :  Abesse alicui or ab aliquo, to be wanting to any one, to be of no assistance or service to : : facile etiam absentibus nobis veritas se ipsa defendet, : . So also : et quo plus intererat, eo plus aberas a me, the more I needed your assistance, the more you neglected me, v. Wunder ad h. l.; cf. also  Cicero uses abesse to designate his banishment from Rome :  cf.: discessus. —Hence, absens, entis , P. a., absent .  In gen.:  so  : : :  :  :  al.—Sup.: .—Of things :  so, : : : : .— In partic.  In conversat. lang.  Praesens absens, in one's presence or absence: .— Absente nobis turbatumst, in our absence (so also:  Afran. ap. .— In polit. lang., not appearing in public canvassings as a competitor:  so  .— = mortuus, deceased,  , praef. § 8.— Ellipt.: absens in Lucanis, absent  in Lucania, i. e. absent and in Lucania,  so .

, mpsi, mptum , 3, v. a.  Orig., to take away; hence, to diminish by taking away. Of things, to consume, to annihilate; of persons, orig. to ruin, to corrupt; later, in a phys. sense, to kill. Thus Hercules, in the transl. of the Trachiniae, complains: sic corpus clade horribili absumptum extabuit, consumed, ap.  so Philoctetes in a piece of Attius: jam jam absumor: conficit animam vis vulneris, Att. ap. : :  : : :  so, :  cf.  and: :  cf.  :  cf.:  and:  so,  and: .—Absumi, to be killed: —Absumi in aliquid, to be used for any thing, to be changed into: — Fig., to ruin: : .—Often of time:  so, : : : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n.  Lit., of a wave, to flow over and down, to overflow : apud abundantem antiquam amnem, Att. ap. :  cf.   and in the beautiful figure in Plaut.: ripis superat mi atque abundat pectus laetitiā, for joy, my heart swells above its banks and overflows, Stich. 2, 1, 6:  cf.: : so, . Transf.  Poet., of plants, to shoot up with great luxuriance: . In gen., to abound, to be redundant: : , prooem. § 4.—Once with dat.: . To overflow with any thing, to have an abundance or superabundance of, to abound in ; constr. with abl., and once poet. with gen. .  With abl.: : : : : : cujus oratio omnibus   ornamentis abundavit, : : : : .—Poet.: amore abundas, you are too fortunate in love ,  cf. Lucil.: ille abundans cum septem incolumis pinnis redit, ap. Don. Ter. l. c.— With gen.: quarum et abundemus rerum et quarum indigeamus, Lucil. ap. .—Esp., to abound in wealth, to be rich : : .—Hence, ăbun-dans, antis, P. a., overflowing.  Lit., of rivers, fluids, etc.: : : . — Transf.  Existing in abundance, copious, abundant: .— Containing abundance, abounding, rich, full; constr. with abl., gen., or absol.  With abl.: : : .— With gen.: : : .— Absol.: : :  cf. .—Also in a bad sense, of discourse, pleonastic, superabundant,  .— Hence, adv.:   — Esp., abounding in wealth, rich : : .—Hence, adv.: ăbundanter, abundantly, copiously: : .—Comp., .—Sup., .

, ūsus, 3, v. dep., to use up any thing, to use to the end, to consume entirely ; constr. in ante-class. period with acc., in class. per. with abl.  Lit.  With acc.:  so, : :  Ruhnk.: : .— With abl.:  Creuz; so, : : : : : abuti  aliquā re ad aliquid, to make use of for any purpose, to take advantage of:  cf.  .—Hence,  In a bad sense, to misuse, to abuse:  so in the exordium of the first oration against Cat.: Quousque tandem abutere, Catilina, patientia nostra? will you abuse our patience? libertate, : : :  cf.  — Esp., in rhet. , to use improperly,   !*? Pass.:  so also Varr.: utile utamur potius quam ab rege abutamur, ap.  P., and Q. Hortensius, ib., abusis locis: .
, āre, 1, v. n., to sing at: .

, cessi, cessum, 3, v. n. , to go or come to or near, to approach .  Lit.  In gen., constr. with ad, in, the local adverbs, the acc., dat., infin., or absol.  With ad:  so, : : : : : : ad manum, to come to their hands , :  so, .—Impers.: .— With in: : : : — With local adv.: : : .— With acc. : , and 4, 2: :  cf. : :   : : .—（) With dat. : : : caelo , , and 870.— With inf.: —（) Absol.: : : : —Impers.: non potis accedi, Enn. ap. : . In partic.  To approach a thing in a hostilemanner , to attack: : :  : : Atque accedit muros Romana juventus, Enn. ap. : hostīs accedere ventis navibus velivolis, id. ap. ; .— Mercant. t. t.:  .— In late Lat.: ad manus , to be admitted to kiss hands, Capit. .  Fig.  In gen., to come near to, to approach:  so, :  cf.: :  cf.: . In partic.  To come to or upon one, to happen to, to befall ; constr. with ad or with dat.: : : : :  With the accessory idea of increase, to be added = addi; constr. with ad or dat.: primum facie quod honestas accedit, Lucil. ap.  so ap. : :   : .—Absol.: :  : .—If a new thought is to be added, it is expressed by accedit with quod when it implies a logical reason, but with ut when it implies an historical fact (cf. Zumpt, § : so Cael. ap.       :  so      When several new ideas are added, they are introduced by res in the plur.: cum ad has suspiciones certissimae res accederent: quod per fines Sequanorum Helvetios transduxisset; quod obsides inter eos dandos curāsset; . Sometimes the historical idea follows accedit, without ut: : . To give assent to, accede to, assent to, to agree with, to approve of; constr. with ad or dat. :  so  :  so  To come near to in resemblance, to resemble, be like; with ad or dat. : :  cf.    To enter upon, to undertake; constr. with ad or in: : : : : :   But esp.:

, āvi, ātum , 1, v. a. and n.  Act., to hasten, accelerate: gressum adcelerāsse decet, Att. ap. ; so, ,  8: :  : : .—Pass.,   .— Neutr., to hasten, to make haste: si adcelerare volent, ad vesperam consequentur, * :     : .—With local accus.: .—Impers.: .

, ndi, nsum, 3, v. a. , prop. to kindle any thing above, so that it may burn downwards  .  Lit., to set on fire, to kindle, light: ut Pergama accensa est, Liv. Andr. ap. : : lumen de suo lumine, to kindle, Enn. ap. ; cf.:  and:  so,  Meton., to light up, to illuminate: ; . Fig., to inflame a person or thing , to set on fire, to kindle, to incite, rouse up; aliquem or aliquid aliqua re: placare hostem ferocem inimiciterque accensum, Att. ap. : : . That to which one is excited is denoted by ad:  the person against whom one is excited, by in or contra: :  with quare c. subj.: . The historians use this word very often, esp. with abstract substt.: : : :  al. In , praeclare enim se res habeat, si haec accendi aut commoveri arte possint, accendi is obviously the first enkindling, rousing, of talent ; cf.  . And so perhaps : crystallina ... quorum accendit fragilitas pretium, signifies vessels of crystal, whose fragility gives them value .

, nsum, 2, v. a., to reckon to or among, to add to; as a verb. finit. very rare:  and: accensi, qui his accensebantur, id est attribuebantur, .—But hence in frequent use, ac-census, a, um, P. a., reckoned among, or subst. accensus, i., m.  One who attends another of higher rank, an attendant, follower; hence, a state officer who attended one of the highest magistrates at Rome or in the provinces, for the purpose of summoning parties to court, maintaining order and quiet during its sessions, and proclaiming the hours; an apparitor, attendant, orderly , Varr. ap.   and 7;   —The person to whom one is accensus is annexed in dat. or gen.: : . The Decurions and Centurions also   had their accensi as aids,  Müll.; . Cf. on the accensi, Necker's Antiq. 2, 2, p. 375 sq.—  accensi, a kind of reserve troops who followed the army as supernumeraries , to take the place of those who fell in battle. They had no arms, and were only clothed with the military cloak, and hence called velati: quia vestiti et inermes sequuntur exercitum, Paul. ex  Müll.; they used in battle only slings and stones. They were also employed in constructing public roads. Cf. Mommsen, Degli Accensi Velati, in Annali del. Inst. vol. xxi. , p. 209 sq.; and Necker's Antiq. 3, 2, p. 242 sq.
, āre, doub. freq. v. a. , to take, receive, accept: stipendium, Plaut. ap. .

, cīdi, cīsum, 3, v. a. , to begin to cut or to cut into [cf.: adamo, addubito, etc.); hence, so to cut a thing that it falls, to fell, to cut .  Lit.: :  cf.: : : ab locustis genus omne acciditur frugum, eaten up, Arnob. 1, 3.—Poet., to use up: .— Fig., to impair, weaken:  so,  cf. 6, 12, 6.—Hence, accīsus, a, um, P. a., cut off or down; impaired, ruined: accisae res , troubled, disordered, or unfortunate state of things:   :  : : : : .

, cīdi, no sup., 3, v. n. , to fall upon or down upon a thing, to reach it by falling.  Lit.  In gen. constr. with ad, in, local adverbs, with dat. or absol.: utinam ne accidisset abiegna ad terram trabes, Enn. ap. :  so, : trabs in humum accidens, Varr. ap.  so, : : quo Castalia per struices saxeas lapsu accidit, Liv. Andr. ap.  Müll. :  so .— Esp.: a. ad genua or genibus, of a suppliant, to fall at one's knees: me orat mulier lacrimansque ad genua accidit, Enn. ap. ; so     , and absol.: quo accĭdam? quo applicem? Enn. ap. .— Transf., to strike the senses, to reach a thing by means of the senses; constr. with ad, the dat. or acc.: vox, sermo accidit ad aurīs , the voice, the speech falls upon or reaches the ear: nota vox ad aurīs accidit, Att. ap. :  and: :  :  absol.,   sq.;  cf.  and absol.:    v. Fabri ad h. l.—Hence sometimes in Livy: vox or fama accidit , with an acc. c. inf.: :  v. Weissenb. a. h. l. Fig.  In gen., to fall out, come to pass, happen, occur; and with dat. pers., to happen to, to befall one. :  :  cf. : : : : : : : . Also of fortunate occurrences:  :  cf. Brem.  Herz. .—Constr. with ut , sometimes with quod:  or with inf.: . Pleonast. in narrations: accidit ut, it happened, or came to pass, that: accidit ut una nocte omnes Hermae dejicerentur, it happened that, etc.,  so  —  In part.  Si quid cui accidat, or si quid humanitus accidat, euphemist. for to die; if any thing should happen to one (for which Ennius says:     § 2 al. ; so, per aposiopesin, sive—quod heu timeo, sive superstes eris, . — To turn out : : . — In gram., to belong to:
, ēre, 2, v. a., old form for accio, ire, to fetch, to bring:  dub. .

, nxi, nctum, 3, v. a.  Lit., to gird to or on, to gird round or about (in prose, first after the Aug. per.;  and med., to gird one's self:  cf.:  so, .— Transf., to arm, equip, furnish, provide: :  : : . Fig.  In gen., to endow, provide; in medicine: .—  In part.: accingere se or accingi, to enter upon or undertake a thing, girded, i. e. well prepared, to prepare one's self, make one's self ready ; constr. absol., with ad, in, dat., or inf.:  so  : :  in Tac. very often actively, to make any one ready for something: :  al.; with inf.:  .— Also in the active form, as v. neutr. = se accingere: age, anus, accinge ad molas, Pompon. ap. : .—Hence, ac-cinctus, a, um, P. a., well girded.  Lit.: cujus aut familiaris habitus condecentior aut militaris accinctior, Auson. .— Fig., ready, strict : : .
, ĕre, v. n. , to sing to any thing, acc. to  P.; cf. accano.
, īvi, ītum, 4, v. a., to call or summon, to fetch .  Lit.: cujus vos tumulti causā accicrim, Att. ap. : :       — Fig.:  :  cf.:  and: .

, cēpi, ceptum, 3, v. a. , to accept.  In gen., to take a person or thing to one's self: leno ad se accipiet hominem et aurum, will take the man and his money to himself , .  Of things received by the hand, to take, receive: cette manus vestras measque accipite, Enn. ap. :  hence, trop. of the word given, the promise, with which a grasping of the hand was usually connected: accipe daque fidem, Enn. ap. ; cf.  so   cf. , and , — Of things received or taken by different parts of the body: accipite hoc onus in vestros collos, Cato ap. : : .— In gen., very freq.,  as implying action, to take, to take possession of, to accept ;  of something that falls to one's share, to get, to receive, to be the recipient of .— To take, accept:   cf. : : : : :  : —Hence to receive or entertain as guest: :  155; —Of admittance to political privileges:  cf. : :  so   , etc.;    —Hence also ironically, to entertain, to treat, deal with: : : . Perh. also Lucil. ap. : adeo male me accipiunt decimae, treat or use me ill, deal harshly with me; and : sic, inquam, veteratorem illum vetulum lupum Hannibalem acceptum .—  To get, to receive, to be the recipient of, Pac. ap.   : : aridior nubes accipit ignem, takes or catches fire,  : : :  cf. : : praecepta, Caes.  B. G. 2, 6: accepi tuas litteras , I have received your letter, it has reached me ,   :  : :  cf.  So often of dignities and offices: : :  In partic.  To take a thing by hearing, i. e.,  To hear, to perceive, to observe, to learn : hoc simul accipe dictum, Enn. ap. : quod ego inaudivi, accipite, Pac. ap. : hoc etiam accipe quod dico, Lucil. ap. : ; 1, 270; cf. : : :   . —Hence very freq. in the histt., to get or receive intelligence of any thing, to learn: , and so al.— To comprehend or understand any thing communicated: : :  so  — With the accessory idea of judging, to take a thing thus or thus, to interpret or explain, usually constr. with ad or in c. acc.: :  cf.   : : .— Hence: accipere aliquid omen, or in omen, to regard a thing as a omen, to accept the omen ,     fin.;    —Hence poet.:  cf. .— To take a thing upon one's self, to undertake : : meā causā causam accipite, Ter. Hec. alt. prol. 47; cf.  so  —Hence also,  To bear, endure, suffer any thing disagreeable or troublesome: :      : :  al.—  To accept a thing, to be satisfied with, to approve: dos, Pamphile, est decem talenta; Pam.: : : :  Drak. Cf. Herz, : “equi te esse feri similem, dico.” Ridemus et ipse Messius: “accipio.” I allow it, Exactly so, .— In mercant. lang., t. t., to receive or collect a sum:  hence subst.: acceptum, i, n., the receipt, and in account-books the credit side: .—Hence also trop., to owe or be indebted to one, in a good or a bad sense: :   id. B. C, 3, 57: Acceptum   refero versibus, esse nocens, . — In the gram m., to take a word or phrase thus or thus, to explain a word in any manner:  P. al.— .—Hence, acceptus, a, um, P. a., welcome, agreeable, acceptable (syn. gratus. Acceptus is related to gratus, as the effect to the cause; he who is gratus, i. e. dear, is on that account acceptus, welcome, acceptable; :  .— : : : :  .—Comp.,   —Sup., see above.—Adv. accepte does not occur.
, āre, 1, v. a. , used by Laevius for lacerare, to tear, to lacerate, ap. .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n., to raise a cry at, to shout at, to exclaim , with and without the dat.; also with the acc. of the thing called.  To shout at in a hostile sense, to disapprove or blame by shouting :  cf.  id. Piso, 65;   so  :  so  — After the Aug. period, to cry at with approbation, to shout applause, to approve with loud cries, to applaud, huzza:    :  so —Impers.: .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to make clear or evident, to show or make known; in the lang. of the augurs:
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to lean on or against something .  Lit.: : .—Most freq. in part. pass.:  cf.: : : .— Trop., with se, to incline to a thing: .

, cŏlui, cultum, 3, v. a., to dwell by or near, constr. with acc. or absol.  With acc.: Histrum fluvium, Naev ap. : arcem, Att. ap.  (): illum locum, * : : : :  cf.: : :  hence, pass.: .— Absol.: .—Poet.: accolere vitem, to be  a cultivating neighbor of it,  dub.

, āvi, ātum , 1, v. a., to fit or adapt one thing to another, to lay, put, or hang on , constr. with ad, dat., or absol.  Lit.: : : gladium dextrae, Lucil. ap.  so, :  so,  absol.: .—  In gen., to prepare for any use: . Trop., to adjust or adapt to, to accommodate to:  so   —Hence, with se, to adapt one's self to another's opinion, wishes, etc., to conform to, to comply with: : alicui de aliqua re, to be compliant to one in any thing: . — In gen., to bring a person or thing to something, to apply: : : :  cf.  cf. — Hence, with se , to apply or devote one's self to, to undertake:  of property, to lend it to one for use: .—Hence, accommŏdātus, a, um, P. a., fitted or adapted to, suitable, conformable, or appropriate to , with ad or dat.: : : . —Comp.:  so :  .—Sup.:  so   —Adv.: accommŏ-dāte, fitly, suitably, agreeably: .—Comp., .— Sup., .
, essi, estum, 3, v. a., to bear or bring to: .
, āre, v. a. : aliquid alicui, to incorporate, to fit or join to ,  .
, dĭdi, dĭtum, 3, v. a. , to yield one's belief to another, i. e. to believe unconditionally .  With dat.: :  so, .— Aliquid: .   — Absol.: vix adcredens, * : . 4.

, ēvi, ētum, 3, v. n., to grow, to become larger by growth, to increase.  Lit.:  so, :  :  so, : .—Part.: .— Of abstract subjects: : : : : .—  Transf., in gen.  To be added to by way of increase or augmentation, to be joined or annexed to: : : : : .—Hence,  Jurid. t. t., to fall to one, as an increase of his property,  :

, āre, 1, v. n., t. t. , to lie near or by a thing.  In gen., constr. with dat. or absol.: : : .—Rarely with acc.: .—Of things: : .—Also of places : .—Esp.  To recline at table :  so,  :  cf.:    : : : .— To lie with,   .
, ĕre, 3, v. a., lit. to strike or stamp upon, to coin ; hence, metaph., to coin further, to add to a sum of money: .

, cŭbui, cŭbĭtum, 3, v. n., to lay one's self down at a place; and hence, to lie somewhere.  In gen. :  .— In part.  To recline at table, in the manner in which the Romans reclined, after luxury and effeminacy had become prevalent. While they extended the lower part of the body upon the couch , they supported the upper part by the left arm upon a cushion , the right hand only being used in taking food:  so , etc.;    c. acc.: mensam, Att. ap.   : : : :   absol., .—Since three persons usually reclined upon such a couch , these expressions arose: in summo , medium and imum adcumbere; and the series began on the left side, since they lay supported by the left arm. The whole arrangement is explained by the following figure:  Among the three lecti, the lectus medius was the most honorable; and on each lectus, the locus medius was more honorable than the summus; and this had the preference to the imus or ultimus. The consul or other magistrate usually sat as imus of the lectus medius , in order that, by his position at the corner, he might be able, without trouble, to attend to any official business that might occur. The place no. 7 seems, for a similar reason, to have been taken by the host. See on this subject Salmas.  Smith's Antiq.; Becker's Gall. 3, p. 206 sq. ; and Orell. excurs. ad . This statement explains the passages in   , etc.;   Sall. Fragm. ap.  .— In mal. part. ,  Men. 3, 2, 11; 5, 9, 82.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to add to a heap, to heap up, accumulate, to augment by heaping up .  Lit.  In gen.: : .—Absol.,  of heaping up money: auget, addit, adcumulat, * . — Esp., botan. t. t., to heap up earth round the roots of plants, to trench up,   — Trop., to heap, add, increase: virtutes generis meis moribus, Epitaph of a Scipio in Inscr. Orell. no. 554: : : : .—Absol.: quod ait sidera lambit , vacanter hoc etiam accumulavit et inaniter, has piled up words, .—Hence, accŭmŭlāte, adv., abundantly, copiously : : : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , orig. = ad causam provocare, to call one to account, to make complaint against, to reproach, blame.  In gen., of persons: : : : : :   Manut.: : . —Also metaph. of things, to blame, find fault with: : inertiam adolescentium, id. de  Or. 1, 58 ;  cf.   .—Hence, Esp.  Transferred to civil life, to call one to account publicly , to accuse, to inform against, arraign, indict ; t. t. in Roman judicial lang.; constr. with aliquem alicujus rei : : :  Milt. 1, 7. Other rarer constructions are: aliquem aliquid ,  cf. :    :  cf.: :  cf. Zumpt, § 446; Rudd. 2, 165 sq.; 169, note 4.—The punishment that is implied in the accusation is put in gen.:  cf. Zumpt, § 447. — Casus accusandi, the fourth case in grammar, the accusative case, Var. L. L. 8, § 66 Müll.; v. accusativus.

, ēvi, ētum, 3, v. n., lit., to become physically quiet, to come to physical repose; hence, in gen., to repose or rest .  Lit.: sine respirem, quaeso. Pe. Immo adquiesce,  : : :  cf.: , and absol. of sleep, : .—By euphemism , to die :  cf.     so, quiesco, q. v. Fig.  To come to a state of repose in relation to one's wishes, desires, etc.; to repose in; to find rest, pleasure, etc., in; to rejoice in; in Cic. mostly with in, and of things: in the historians and later writers, with dat. or abl., and also of persons: :  : . Examples in Cic. of a person: , and with abl.: : :  : .— To be satisfied with, to acquiesce in or give assent to: tu, cum es commotus, acquiescis, assentiris, approbas ,  so

, sīvi, sītum, 3, v. a. , to add to, to get or acquire , with ad or dat. .  Lit.:  :   and poet.: viresque adquirit eundo, and gains strength in her course, .— In gen.  To get, obtain, procure, secure:  : : : : .— In later Lat., absol., to acquire or amass riches or money (cf.: quaero, quaestus; ]: .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make pointed, to sharpen, in verb finit.: .—Part. perf.: : : .

, ui, ūtum, 3, v. a. , to make sharp or pointed, to sharpen, whet.  Lit.:  so,  : : : .—Poet.: :  cf. .—  Trop.  First, of the tongue, qs. to whet, i. e. to sharpen, exercise, improve: :  so  so in gen.: se, to exercise one's self, to make one's self ready: : mentem, ingenium, prudentiam, etc.; to sharpen:  so   .— Acuere aliquem , to spur on, incite, stir up, arouse:  :  :  : : : .— Aliquid, to rouse up, kindle, excite : : : , no. 3.— In gramm.: acuere syllabam, to give an acute accent to ,  cf.  Lind.: accentus acutus ideo inventus est, quod acuat sive elevet syllabam.—Hence, ăcūtus, a, um, P.a., sharpened, made pointed; hence,  Lit., sharp, pointed : : : : :  elementa, i. e. pointed, jagged atoms , : : : :  so .— Transf.  Of the senses themselves, sharp, keen: :  .— Of objects affecting the senses, sharp, acute; of the voice, soprano or treble: inde loci lituus sonitus effudit acutos, Enn. ap. Paul. ex  Müll. : :  : :  cf.  Somn. Scip. 5; Rep. 6, 18.— In gen., of things affecting the body, of either heat or cold from their similar effects, keen, sharp, violent, severe: : :  cf.   so, : , rapid.— Subst. with gen.: .— Fig.  Of intellectual qualities, acute, clear-sighted, intelligent, sagacious :  so  id. N. D.  1, 16; : : : : : .— In gramm.: accentus acutus, the acute accent , , ed. Lindem.—Comp. .—Adv.: ăcūte, sharply, keenly, acutely:. cernere,  : : : :  so, ăcūtum: : : and, ăcūta: canis ululat, Enn. ap.  Müll. .—Comp., .—Sup.,  .

To make equal to, to equalize, to level with; hence,  In Cic. usually with cum : : : .—  In the histt. alicui rei (cf.: : :  and with solo understood: : :  so Dom. 2.— Trop., to compare to or with: .—  To attain to, or reach, by equalling. —With acc. (cf.: : :  cf. , and . Neut., to be equal. Aeduis, id. B: G. 6, 12.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to heap up: : so, : terra Nilo adaggerata, brought down or deposited by the Nile, : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to love truly, earnestly, deeply :  cf.  : :  cf. :  cf. : : : : : si virtutem adamaveris, amare enim parum est , .— Of unlawful love,  :
, āre, 1, v. a. , to widen, to enlarge, to increase: adampliemus pondus, Vulg. Ital. Amos, 8, 5, where St. Jerome has augeamus:  .
, ui, ertum, 4, v. a. , to open fully, to open, throw open :  Drak. ; so    .— Transf., to uncover, to bare:  : : : aures ad criminationem  adapertae, open to, ready to hear, .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to fit, adjust, or adapt to a thing; with dat. only in part. pass.:  .

, ātus, 1, v. dep., to bring or procure water for one's self, io fetch water: nec sine periculo possent adaquari oppidani, Auct. B. G. 8, 41, where Dinter gives aquari; v. aquor.
, rui, 3, v. inch. , to dry up: .
, āre, 1, v. a. , to plough carefully: in an interpolation in .

, bĭbi, bĭbĭtum, 3, v. a. , to drink .  Lit.:  so  .— Trop., of discourse, to drink in, .—Hence of instruction, to drink in eagerly, to listen to attentively: .
, āre, 1, v. a. , to prattle, to chatter:  Elm.
, ēre, 2, v. impers. , it behooves, it becomes, it is fit or proper that , constr. with acc. or with acc. and inf.: sed virum virtute vera vivere animatum addecet, Enn. ap. : :   so    .

verbParts: , ēre, and ăd-denso, āre , 2 and 1, v. a.
fullText: , ēre, and ăd-denso, āre , 2 and 1, v. a., to make close, compact :  Rib.—In pass., of water, to become thick, to thicken: .

, xi, ctum, 3, v. a. , orig., to give one's assent to a thing , in its lit. signif. belonging only to augural and judicial language .  Of a favorable omen, to be propitious to, to favor, usually with aves as subj., and without obj.:  so,  also with auspicium as subj.:  cf. Drak.  .—And with acc. of obj.:  Müll.—In judicial lang.: alicui aliquid or aliquem, to award or adjudge any thing to one, to sentence; hence Festus, with reference to the adjudged or condemned person, says: : :  hence ironic.: Fufidium . . . creditorem debitoribus suis addixisti, you have adjudged the creditor to his debtors , : .—Hence subst., addictus, i, m., one who has been given up or made over as servant to his creditor: :  extr.; cf. . (The addictus, bondman, was not properly a slave = servus, for he retained his nomen, cognomen, his tribus, which the servus did not have; he could become free again by cancelling the demand, even against the will of his dominus; the servus could not; the addictus, when set free, was also again ingenuus, the servus only libertinus; v. . The inhuman law of the Twelve Tables, which, however, was never put in execution, that one indebted to several creditors should be cut in pieces and divided among them, is mentioned by : Niebuhr, Rom. Gesch. 1, 638;  Müll.: addicere litem, sc. judici, to deliver a cause to the judge. This was the office of the praetor. Such is the purport of the law of XII. Tab. Tab. I.: POST MERIDIEM PRAESENTI STLITEM ADDICITO, ap. :  and 80: addicere aliquid in diem, to adjudge a thing to one ad interim, so that, upon a change of circumstances, the matter in question shall be restored in integrum,   .— In auctions, to adjudge to the highest bidder, knock down, strike off, deliver to : ecquis est ex tanto populo, qui bona C. Rabirii Postumi   nummo sestertio sibi addici velit,  so  .—Addicere bona alicujus in publicum, i. e. to confiscate,  — In gen., to sell, to make over to: :  so .—In a metaph. signif.,  To deliver, yield, or resign a thing to one, either in a good or a bad sense.  In a good sense, to devote, to consecrate to: :  : .— In a bad sense, to give up, to sacrifice, to abandon ; :  so    hence poet.: .— In later Latin, to attribute or ascribe a work to one: .—Hence, addic-tus, P. a. , dedicated or devoted to a thing; hence,  Destined to:  cf. .— Given up to, bound to: : : .—Comp., sup., and adv. not used.
, dĭdĭci, no sup., 3, v. a.  To learn in addition to, to learn further:  so .— In gen., to learn, to be informed, to hear: .
, āre, 1, v. a. , to divine, to prognosticate:  dub. .

, dĭdi, dĭtum, 3, v. a. , to put, place, lay, etc., a person or thing to another.  In gen.  Lit., NEVE AVROM ADDITO, let no gold be put into the grave with the dead, Fragm. of the XII. Tab. in : Argus, quem quondam Ioni Juno custodem addidit, Plaut.  Aul. 3, 6, 20; so : : :  : : : .— With in: : : :  .—Poet.: , v. Heyne and Forb.—Hence,  Trop., to bring to, to add to; with dat.: : fletum ingenio muliebri, Pac. ap.  also absol.:  so : addere animum, or animos, to give courage, make courageous: :  so, .—So also: : : : : :  cf. : : :  hence, addere alicui calcar, to give one the spur, to spur him on: anticipate atque addite calcar, Varr. ap. : . Esp.  To add to by way of increase, to join or annex to, to augment, with dat. or ad : :  cf. :  so  : : quaeso ne ad malum hoc addas malum, Caec. ap. :  so   id : : : : : :  cf. —Poet.:  .— With ad:  so .—Poet. with inf.: : addere gradum , to add step to step, i. e. to quicken one's pace:  so    cf. Doed. Syn. 4, 58: addito tempore, in course of time:  so also: addita aetate, with increased age: in infantia scabunt aures; .— Mercant. t. t., to add to one's bidding, to give more: nihil addo, Poët. ap. .— When a new thought is added to what precedes, as an enlargement of it, it is introduced by adde, adde huc, adde quod, and the like , add to this, add to this the circumstance that, or besides, moreover . . .: : : : : adde quod pubes tibi crescit omnis, Hor.  C. 2, 8, 17; : : : .—So also when several are addressed, as in the speech of Scipic to his soldiers: .—Also with the acc. and inf.:  : : addito as abl. absol. with a subj. clause; with the addition, with this addition : vocantur patres, addito consultandum super re magna et atroci, with this intimation, that they were to consult, etc., : .— Hence, addĭtus, a, um, P. a. , joined to one as a constant observer; so,  Watching or observing in a hostile or troublesome manner: si mihi non praetor siet additus atque agitet me, Lucil. ap. .—Hence, in gen.,  Pursuing one incessantly, persecuting:  Serv. .
, cui, ctum, 2, v. a., to teach something in addition to, to teach: .
, īre, 4, v. n., to begin to sleep, to go to sleep: rursus addormiunt, Cael. Aurel. 1, 11, 38.
, ĕre, v. inch. n., to go to sleep: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. and a., pr., to incline to doubt, to begin to doubt .  To be in doubt, to doubt; constr.  With de or in aliqua re: : : .— With pron., or num, an, etc.: : :  so  cf. Drak. ad : .— With acc., to be doubtful of a thing, to call in question:  so .— With inf., to hesitate: .—（) Absol.:   .

, xi, ctum, 3, v. a. , to lead to, to bring or convey to, draw to any place or to one's self .  Lit.: :  Afr. ap. : quos secum Mitylenis Cratippus adduxit, Cic. Fil. ap. : .—With ad:  cf. : ad cenam, Lucil. ap. :  .—Or with a local adv.: :  so : . — In gen., without regard to the access. idea of accompanying, to lead or bring a person or thing to a place, to take or conduct from one place to another .—So of conducting an army: : .—With in:  cf. Oud. ad , and Auct. B. G. 8, 35: :  so .—With dat.: : .—Poet. with acc.: : .—Of a courtesan, to procure: : .—Poet. also of a place, which is, as it were, brought near. Thus Hor. in describing the attractions of his Sabine farm: dicas adductum propius frondere Tarentum, Ep. 1, 16, 11.— Esp.  To bring a thing to a destined place by drawing or pulling, to draw or pull to one's self: :  so, : : : : so : : .—Hence trop.:  cf. , and 1, 63.— Of the skin or a part of the body, to draw up, wrinkle, contract: :  so, frontem , to contract:  so . Fig.  To bring a person or thing into a certain condition; with ad or in: : : : : : :  cf. : : : : .— To bring or lead one to a certain act, feeling, or opinion; to prompt, induce, prevail upon, persuade, move, incite to it; with ad, in, or ut (very freq. and class., and for the most part in a good sense; while seducere and inducere denote instigating or seducing to something bad, Herz.  : : : : : : : : :  .—With gerund: : .—With ut: : :   , etc.;  —And absol. in pass.: :  .—With quin: .—With inf.:  facilius adducor ferre humana humanitus, Afr. ap. .— Adducor with inf., or with ut and subj. = adducor ad credendum, , to be induced to believe: : :   .—Hence, adductus, a, um, P. a.  Drawn tight, stretched, strained, contracted.—Trop.: :  cf. .—Hence,  Of place, narrow, contracted, strait: .— Of character, strict, serious, severe: : : .—Sup. not used.—Adv. only in comp. adductĭus,  More tightly: .— Trop., more strictly: : .

, ēdi, ēsum , 3, v. a. , to begin to eat, to bite, to nibble at, to gnaw, etc.—As verb finite very rare, and mostly poet.; not found in prose of Cic.  Prop.:  so, : .—Hence metaph. of fire: : .— In an enlarged sense , to eat up, to consume entirely: frumento adeso, quod ex areis in oppidum portatum est, Sisenn. ap.  so,  : and metaph., to use up, to consume, waste : : : : .—Hence, ădēsus, a, um, P. a., eaten, gnawed; hence poet., worn away, esp. by water: : : sale durus adeso caseus, poet. for sale adesus caseus, .

verbParts: , ĭī, and rarely īvi, ĭtum , 4, v. n.
fullText: , ĭī, and rarely īvi, ĭtum , 4, v. n. and a. , to go to or approach a person or thing .  Lit.  In gen., constr.  With ad : sed tibi cautim est adeundum ad virum, Att. ap. : :  : aut ad consules aut ad te aut ad Brutum adissent, Cic. Fragm. ap. : : — With in: priusquam Romam atque in horum conventum adiretis, Cic.  Verr. 2, 4, 11, § 26 ed. Halm.—Esp.: adire in jus, to go to law:   , and in the Plebiscit. de Thermens. lin. 42: QVO DE EA RE IN IOVS ADITVM ERIT, cf. Dirks., Versuche S. p. 193.— Absol.: : .— With acc.: : : : : : :  so with latter supine: .—With local adv.: : .— Esp.,  To approach one for the purpose of addressing, asking aid, consulting, and the like, to address, apply to, consult . —Constr. with ad or oftener with acc.; hence also pass.: : : : cum pacem peto, cum placo, cum adeo, et cum appello meam, Lucil. ap. : : .—Pass.: : .—Hence: adire aliquem per epistulam, to address one in writing, by a letter:  and 10; cf.  .—So also: adire deos, aras, deorum sedes, etc., to approach the gods, their altars, etc., as a suppliant : quoi me ostendam? quod templum adeam? Att. ap. : : : : :  cf. : .—  To go to a thing in order to examine it, to visit: : .— To come up to one in a hostile manner, to assail, attack: : : . Fig.  To go to the performance of any act, to enter upon, to undertake, set about, undergo, submit to .—With ad or the acc. : : : : .—With acc.: : :  cf.: : ut vitae periculum aditurus videretur, Auct. B. G. 8, 48: maximos labores et summa pericula. : : : : : .—Hence of an inheritance, t. t., to enter on:  so   and Dig.; .— Adire manum alicui, prov., to deceive one, to make sport of :  so   .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n.  To ride to or toward a place, to gallop up to.—With ad: equites Ariovisti propius tumulum accedere et ad nostros adequitare, * .—With in: .—With the local adv. quo: . —With dat.:  so, : vallo, Liv.  9, 22, 4: .—With acc. of limit: : .—  To ride near to or by: : .
, āre, 1, v. n., to wander to.— With dat.: .— Trop.: .
, āre, 1, v. a., to feed or fatten: .
, īvi, 4, v. n. , to be very hungry: .
, āre, 1, v. n.: adhabites, a false reading for adbites in .

, haesi, haesum, 2, v. n., to cleave or stick to a thing.  Lit., of iron adhering to a magnet:  cf. : tota adhaerens crocodilis, cleaving to his palate, .—With in and abl.:  so .—With acc.: .—With abl.: .—With dat., poet.: :  :  and: .— Fig.  In gen., to cling to, adhere to:  : : : .— Adhaerere alicui, to be close to a person or thing, to be near, to hang on, keep close to, etc. :  so .—Of persons: procul abesse Romanos: lateri adhaerere gravem dominum, i. e. he hangs on them, threatens them by his nearness, : : : :  .— To hang on a thing, i. e. to trail or drag after, to be the last, sarcastically in Cic.: tenesne memoriā te extremum adhaesisse? hung on the end, i. e. extremo loco quaestorem esse factum, Vat. 5 ; .

, haesi, haesum, 3, v. inch. , to cleave or stick to, to adhere, lit. and trop. .  Lit., constr. with ad, in, and abl. or ubi: : : tamquam in quodam incili, Cael. ap. : si potes in his locis adhaerescere, if you can stick in such places, : in me omnia conjurationis nefaria tela adhaeserunt, Auct. Or. pro Dom. 24; cf.  : argumentum ratio ipsa confirmat, quae simul atque emissa est, adhaerescit, sc. ad mentem,  sticks fast to, is fastened upon the memory , .—With dat.: justitiae honestatique, to be attached or devoted to, .—And absol.:  cf. : adhaerescere ad columnam ; sarcastically, to remain fixed at the debtor's columns, i. e. to be punished as a fraudulent debtor,  cf. .— Fig., to correspond to, to accord with, to fit to or suit: .
, āre, v. a., to breathe on: .
, āre, 1, v. a. , to catch, secure: Qui serius honores adhamaverunt, vix admittuntur ad eos, Cic. ap. , where Mercer. better reads adamaverunt.

, ŭi, ĭtum, 2, v. a. , to hold toward or to, to turn, bring, add to; with ad, in, dat. or absol.  In gen.  Lit.: : :  cf. : : : : : : .— Trop.:  cf. :  :  cf.  : : :  cf. : : : —Hence = addere, adjungere, to add to: : . Esp.  Of persons, to bring one to a place, to summon, to employ :  so  : : : : : : : .— Adhibere ad or in consilium, to send for one in order to receive counsel from him, to consult one: :  so also absol.:  so  ,   7;     cf. Cortius ad , and ad .—But sometimes adhibere in consilium = admittere in cons., to admit to a consultation. —So trop.: .— Adhibere aliquem cenae, epulis, etc., to invite to a dinner, to a banquet, etc., to entertain:  so   : in convivium, Nep. praef. 7.—And absol., to receive, to treat: : .— Adhibere se ad aliquid, to betake or apply one's self to a thing, i. e. to devote attention to it: ; and absol.: adhibere se, to appear or to behave one's self in any manner: .— Adhibere aliquid ad aliquid, alicui rei, or with in and abl., to put a thing to a determinate use, to apply, to use or employ for or in any thing definite :  cf.  : : : : : : : : : :  and with de: : modum, to set a limit to, to set bounds to: : : cf.  : : .— Adhibere aliquid, in gen., to use, employ, exercise: : : :  : : : .— In later Lat.: alicui aliquem, to bring up, quote one to another as authority for an assertion: .

verbParts: , īvi, or ĭi, ītum, 4, v. n.
fullText: , īvi, or ĭi, ītum, 4, v. n., to neigh to or after.  Lit., constr. with dat. and acc., also ad and in with acc.:  cf.  .—Hence, of lewd persons, Plaut. Fragm. ap. Mai. p. 19; Prud. ap. : : : so, — Fig., to strive after or long for with voluptuous desire: admissarius iste ad illius orationem adhinnivit, gave his passionate assent to, expressed his delight in, etc., : .

, āri, ātus, 1, v. dep., to encourage, urge, exhort one to a thing, constr. with ad, in, de, or absol.: : : : : : : .—Absol.: : .—Followed by ut, ne, or the simple subj.: : : : adhortari se, to rouse or bestir one's self: ferus ipse sese adhortans rapidum incitat animo, Catull. 63, 85.!*? Pass.: adulati erant ab amicis et adhortati, Cassius ap.  P.: punctione aliqua adhortati vel titillati, Cael. Aurel. Acut. 2, 3.
, āvi, v. a., to entertain as guest.—Only trop.:

, ēgi, actum, 3, v. a. , to drive, bring, or take a person or thing to a place .—Constr. usu. with ad, but also with acc., dat., in or local adv.  Lit., of cattle (cf. ago, I.: : : : . —Of persons: : : .—Hence: adigere aliquem arbitrum , to compel one to come before an arbiter :  so  .—Of things: : , and absol.: : .—Esp. often of weapons, to drive home, plunge, thrust, to send to a place:  cf.  so  : : : cf. : : .— And from the weapons transf. to the wound, to inflict : : : . Fig.  To drive, urge, or bring one to a situation, to a state of mind, or to an act : : : : .—Poet. with the subj. without ut: .—With the inf.: vertere morsus exiguam in Cererem penuria adegit  edendi,  cf. 6, 696; so   .—  so   .— Adigere aliquem ad jus jurandum, jus jurandum, or jure jurando, or sacramento , t. t., to put one on oath, to cause one to take oath, to swear one : : : :  so  : :  so 6, 38; 7, 9, 11 al.;     .—Hence ellipt.: in verba adigere, for in verba jus jurandum adigere in Tac. and Suet. : :  so 4, 59; .— And finally quite absol.: adigere , to bind by an oath: .— Poet. = subigere, to subject: : .!*? In : mare quod adigit ad ostium Rhodani, we have a false reading, for which Nipperdey restored adjacet.

, ēmi, emptum, 3, v. a. , to take to one's self from a person or thing, to take away, take any thing from, to deprive of .  Of things: : multa ferunt anni venientes commoda secum; multa recedentes adimunt, take them away with themselves, as a fine antithesis to secum ferunt, : :  so   : : : : : : : : : : : : : : .—And absol.: .—Poet. with inf. as object: .— Poet. of persons, to snatch away, to carry off: : .—
, ēvi, ētum, 2, v. a., to fill up, to fill full .  Lit.: .—  Trop.: .— Metaph., to fulfil , to perform, = absolvere, satisfacere, praestare: : : : :  Pet. 1, 2.
, ĕre, v. n., to increase, .
, ĕre, v. a., to put in besides: .
, āre, v. a., to swell up: .
, 3, v. a., to bring to in addition, to heap on: satiram in aliquem, Sisenn. ap. .
, 3, v. a., to investigate or inquire into further:  Mai.
, vēni, ventum, 4, v. a. , to find out, to devise,   cf. also : lapicaedinae adinventae sunt, Labi Ins.: si quis ainventus fuerit hoc fecisse, Mur. Ins. 794.
, 3, v. a., read by Alschefski in , manu ad digitos usque adinvolutā, but Weissenb. still reads involutā.

, eptus, 3, v. dep. , to arrive at, to reach.  Lit.: occepi sequi; .—Hence also with acc., to reach, to overtake:  cf. Drak. ad .—Far oftener,  Fig., to attain to by effort, to get, obtain, acquire, to get possession of (by overcoming natural obstacles; diff. from impetrare, to reach or obtain by victory over another's will; and nancisci, by accident, Doed. Syn. III. pp. 145, 146; : senectutem ut adipiscantur, omnes optant; : : :  :  so         .— With ex:  cf.  .—With ut. adepti sunt, ut dies festos agitare possent, .—Absol.: .!*?  iis adipiscendi magistratus, they should strive for public honors , .— Nero in adipiscenda morte manu adjutus existimabatur, i. e. consciscenda, in committing suicide,  Oud.; cf.   and: . — Pass.: : haec   adipiscuntur, C. Fannius ap.  P.: amitti magis quam adipisci, Fab. Maximus, ib.;      cf.   Rudd. I. p. 288; Kritz ad .— With gen.: ; Rudd. II. p. 120; Zumpt, § 466.

, ti, sum, 3, v. a., to turn a thing to or toward a place .  Lit. Fig.  Animum advertere; absol., or with adv. or ad aliquid, or alicui rei, to direct the mind, thoughts, or attention to a thing, to advert to, give attention to, attend to, to heed, observe, remark: : : : : .—With ne, when the object of attention is expressed: : .— Animum advertere, to observe a thing by directing the mind to it, to observe, to notice, to remark, to perceive .—Constr. with two accusatives, animum advertere aliquid , with acc. and inf., or rel. clause : : : :  :  : . In Vitruv. once with hinc: .—With the acc. and inf.: : : cum animum adverteret locum relictum esse, Auct. B. Alex. 31; .—With the rel. clause: nunc quam rem vitio dent, quaeso, animum  advortite, : quid ille sperare possit, animum adverte, Dolab. ap. : . Sometimes advertere alone = animum advertere; so once in Cicero's letters: nam advertebatur Pompeii familiares assentiri Volcatio, Fam. 1, 1 . So Verg. in the imp.: .—In the histt., esp. Tac. and Pliny, more frequently: : : :  al.: : . Still more rarely, advertere animo: :  cf. Drak. ad .— To draw or turn something, esp. the attention of another, to or upon one's self : : : recentia veteraque odia advertit, drew them on himself,  al.— To call the attention of one to a definite act, i. e. to admonish of it, to urge to it : : .— Advertere in aliquem, for the more usual animadvertere in aliquem, to attend to one, i. e. to punish one : : .—Hence,  adversus , a, um, P. a., turned to or toward a thing, with the face or front toward, standing over against, opposite, before, in front of . So, hostes adversi, who make front against one advancing or retreating, :  cf.   al.; hence, vulnus adversum, a wound in front , : : : : : : : sed adverso fulgure pavefactus est Nero, :  cf.  so  : —Hence, of rivers: flumine adverso, up the stream, against the stream: :  so : ; and of winds, opposed to a vessel's course, head winds, contrary winds, consequently unfavorable, adverse: .—Subst.: adversum, i, the opposite: hic ventus a septentrionibus oriens adversum tenet Athenis proficiscentibus,   holds the opposite to those sailing from Athens, i. e. blows against them, . —Adv.: ex adverso, also written exadverso and exadversum, opposite to, over against, : .—With gen.: .—Without case:  so  .—In adversum, to the opposite side, against:  so  cf.   .— In hostile opposition to, adverse to, unfavorable, unpropitious : conqueri fortunam adversam, Pac. ap. : : : : : adversā avi aliquid facere, vet. poët. ap. : : : : adversae res, misfortune, calamity, adverse fortune:  cf.: : : omnia secundissima nobis, adversissima illis accidisse, Caes. ap. : : : :  cf. : .—Sometimes met. of feeling, contrary to, hated, hateful, odious:  cf.  Bentl.—Comp.: .—* Adv.: adver-sē, self-contradictorily, .—ad-versum, i, subst., esp. in the plur. adversa, misfortune, calamity, disaster, adversity, evil, mischief: : :  cf.  :   so    4, 13 al.—Subst.: adversus, i, m., an opponent, adversary : .—In Quint. also once ad-versa, ae, f., subst., a female opponent or adversary: natura noverca fuerit, si facultatem dicendi sociam scelerum, adversam innocentiae, invenit, 12, 1, 2.— In rhet., opposed to another of the same genus, e. g. sapientia and stultitia: “Haec quae ex eodem genere contraria sunt, appellantur adversa,” .

Lit., that has been transacted in the Senate, in the forum, before the courts of justice, etc.; hence,  actum, i, n., a public transaction in the Senate, before the people, or before a single magistrate: : : .— acta publĭca, or absol.: acta, ōrum, n., the register of public acts, records, journal. Julius Cæsar, in his consulship, ordered that the doings of the Senate should be made public,  cf. Ernest. Exc. 1; . Still the acts of the Senate were written down, and, under the succeeding emperors. certain senators were appointed to this office , . They had also public registers of the transactions of the assemblies of the people, and of the different courts of justice; : :   :  which were all comprehended under the gen. name acta.
