, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to labor or toil at a thing: .—And with dat., to add to with labor or pains: .
, ĕre, v. a. , to lick at or on a thing, to lick:  .—Trop., to touch, come in contact with, : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., lit., to bark at; not used before the Aug. per., and trop. of persons, to assail with harsh words, to revile, rail at; and of the sea, to break upon, or dash against, the shore (the simple verb seems to be used for this in the lit. sense,      cf. :  so  :  so .
, āre, v. a., to extol, to praise much: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a.  To send one away with a commission or charge, to despatch, depute, commission (of private business, while legare is used in a similar signif. of State affairs; most freq. in Plaut.; ; so     : : : : :  so  fin.: cum patrem primo adlegando, deinde coram ipse rogando fatigāsset, first by the friends sent, and then by personal entreaties, etc.,  Gron. —Hence, allēgāti , ōrum, m., deputies:  .— Sometimes in the sense of subornare, to instigate or incite one to an act of fraud or deceit: : ut ne credas a me adlegatum hunc senem, *  Ruhnk.; cf. allegatus.— To bring forward, to relate, recount, mention, adduce : : :  fin.:  so :  .—And in a zeugma: munera, preces, mandata regis sui adlegant, they bring or offer the gifts, entreaties, and mandates,  cf.: : adlegare se ex servitute in ingenuitatem, a legal phrase, to release one's self from servitude by adducing reasons, proofs, etc., .

, ēgi, ectum, 3, v. a., to select for one's self, to choose ; to admit by election, to elect to a thing, or into : Druidibus praeest unus ... hoc mortuo, si sunt plures pares, suffragio Druidum adlegitur, *  Herz. : : :  so, : : in clerum,  , n. 34 al.—Poet.: .—Hence, al-lectus , a, um, P. a. Subst.,  A member chosen into any corporation : collegae, qui unā lecti, et qui in eorum locum suppositi, sublecti;  Müll.— Those who were added to the Senate from the equestrian order, on account of the small number of the Senators, were called adlecti, acc. to Paul. ex  Müll.; cf.  .
, āvi, āre, v. n., = , to allegorize, to speak in allegories,   ad Pamm. 3.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , = allĕvo, to make light, to lighten.  Lit.:  .— Trop., to raise up, relieve: : .—Spec.: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  Lit., to lift up, to raise on high, to raise, set up : quibus adlevati milites facilius ascenderent, * : pauci elevati scutis, borne up on their shields , Auct. B. Alex. 20: : : : ; so, : :  : : : adlevavit eum, lifted him up , — Trop.  To lighten, alleviate, mitigate physical or mental troubles; or, referring to the individual who suffers, to lift up, sustain, comfort, console : aliorum aerumnam dictis adlevans, old poet in : ubi se adlevat, ibi me adlevat, * : : : : : : adlevare corpus, id.   : adlevor animum , .— To diminish the force or weight of a thing, to lessen, lighten: : .—  To raise up, i. e. to make distinguished; pass., to be or become distinguished: .

verbParts: , less correctly al-laevo, āre, v. a.
fullText: , less correctly al-laevo, āre, v. a., to make smooth, to smooth off or over : : : .
, ĕre, v. a. , = allicio, to allure :  dub.: .

, lexi, lectum, 3 , v. a. .  Lit., to draw to one's self, to attract (in Cic. freq., elsewhere rare; .— Trop.: rex sum, si ego illum hodie hominem ad me adlexero, * : adlicit aurīs, * : :  so  : : quae adliciant animum, *       : : : :  .

, si, sum, 3, v. a. , to strike or dash one thing upon or against another.  Lit.: tetra ad saxa adlidere, Att. ap. : ut si quis, prius arida quam sit Cretea persona, adlidat pilaeve trabive, who dashes an image of clay against a post, etc.,  so :  so : .—Absol.,  cf. Schneid. ad h. 1;  .— Trop., to bring into danger; pass., to suffer damage (the figure taken from a shipwreck; cf.  so : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a.  Lit., to bind to something: : , § 71; : . —In Col. of binding the vine to trees or other supports, 4, 13; so .— In gen., to bind, to bind up, bind round: . So of the binding up of wounds: vulnus, Poët. ap. : : .—Of the binding of the hands, feet, etc.: :  : : : .—Hence, allĭgāti  , slaves that are fettered, .—Of other things: : adligat ancora, makes or holds fast, .—In Plin. of fixing colors, to fix, make fast: ita colorem adligans, ut elui postea non possit, 32, 6, 22, § 66; 9, 38, 62, § 134.—Poet.: .— Trop., to bind, to hold fast, to hinder, detain; or in a moral sense, to bind, to oblige, lay under obligation (cf. obligo; :  :  (astringit, illaqueat, et obnoxium facit, Don.; cf. :  for this gen. cf. Roby, § : : : : : : : : — With dat. : : .—*

, lēvi, lĭtum, 3, v. a. .  Lit., to besmear, cover over, bedaub, = : .— Trop., to draw over, to attach to, impart to: nulla nota, nullae sordes videbantur his sententiis adlini posse, * : incomptis adlinet atrum signum, * : .

, cūtus, 3, v. dep. a.: aliquem, to speak to, to address, esp. used in greeting, admonishing, consoling. etc.; hence also, to salute; to exhort, rouse; to console .  To speak to, to address: quem ore funesto adloquar? Att. ap. : :  so :  so Auct. ad     13, 739; :  so  :  .— Esp.  To address the gods in thanksgiving and prayer:   so, .— To address, as a general his troops, to exhort, to rouse: :  . — In consolation, to speak to, to console, to comfort: : :  P. and R.
, ĕre, v. inch. .  With dat., to be pleasing to :  .—*  Absol.: : .
, xi, 2, v. n., to shine upon ; in the lit. signif. only post-Aug.).  Lit.: : : — Trop., as v. a.: faculam adlucere alicujus rei, to light a torch for something, to give an opportunity for, * .
, āri, v. dep., to struggle with or against : : .

, ūsi, ūsum, 3, v. a. and n.  To play or sport with any thing, to joke, jest, to do a thing sportively; with ad or dat. , * : Galba autem adludens varie et copiose multas similitudines adferre, :  : :  Spald., Halm; so — Trop., of the motion,  Of the waves, to sport with, to play against, dash upon: : solebat Aquilius, quid esset litus, ita definire, quā fluctus adluderet ,  cf. : .—With acc.: .— Of the wind, to play with: : .
, ŭi, 3, v. n., to flow near to, to wash against, to bathe, of the sea, the waves, etc. .  Lit.: : : :  : : .— Fig.: .

verbParts: , ălŭi, altum, and ălĭtum, 3, v. a.
fullText: , ălŭi, altum, and ălĭtum, 3, v. a. , to feed, to nourish, support, sustain, maintain .  Lit.: : : .—With natus, educatus, or a similar word, several times: Alui, educavi, Att. ap. : :  : :  : : : : : :  so : : :   al.:  :  cf. Kritz ad  : : : : :    and in a paradoxical phrase: infelix minuendo corpus alebat, and sustained his body by consuming it, i. e. nourished himself by his own flesh,  al.—Hence in pass. with the abl. = vesci, to be nourished or sustained with or by something, to live or feed upon: : : : .— Fig., to nourish, cherish, promote, increase, strengthen: : : :  cf. : : : : : : : : —Hence, altus, a, um.

, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to have a discussion or difference with another, to dispute; to wrangle, quarrel, etc. .  In gen.: cur illa hic mecum altercata est? Pac. ap. : : .—Once with acc.: : nimium altercando veritas amittitur, P. Syr. ap. .—  Esp., in rhet. lang., to strive to gain the victory over an opponent in a court of justice by putting questions for him to answer : .—Hence poet., in gen, to contend, struggle with: altercante libidinibus pavore, * .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. and n. : aliquid, to do one thing and then another, to do a thing by turns, to interchange with something, to alternate : : :  so       * .—Without an obj.: : : arborum fertilitas omnium fere alternat, alternates, i. e. they bear every other year,  so  .—With cum: .
, āre, v. a. , to make high, to raise, elevate , : .
, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to wander in mind, to talk idly, prate, dream (syn.: : :  : : epistolae nostrae debent interdum alucinari,  to follow no definite train of thought, to digress freely, : .
, āre, v. a. , to nourish, bring up, educate :  so , p. 182, 36; .—In a dep. form:  Elm.
, āvi, ātum, āre, v. a., to send forth or away, to remove (commonly with the access. idea of contempt;  Matth.: :  Beier; so
, ĕre, v. inch. [as if from amareo; .
, āvi, ātum, āre, v. a. , to make bitter .  Lit.:  .— Trop., to excite, to irritate: , n. 15.
, ĕre, v. inch. , to begin to love,  P.
, ĕre, v. a., to eat or gnaw around, to eat up entirely:  and 17.
, ēdi, ēsum, 3 , v. a., to eat or gnaw around, and with an extension of the idea , to waste, consume : : :  so .

, ĕre , v. n. .  Lit., to go about or around: ,   15 fin.— Trop., to wander about; to waver, hesitate, be undecided, to doubt, be in suspense .—In this sense in Cic. either impers. or pass.  Impers.: : : : : .— Personal: :  : : .— Pass.: :  : .— Transf.  To argue, debate about something: : .— To contend, dispute, wrangle, etc.: vicini nostri ambigunt de finibus, * : : : : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. .  Lit.  In gen., to go about, to walk: : : :  Müll.:  : : :  : : aves aliquae ambulant, ut cornices; : :    .—Hence,  Esp., to walk for recreation, to take a walk: : : : .— To go, to travel, to journey , :  :  :  et saep.—Hence, in the comic poets, bene ambula, farewell, a good journey to you, a form oft. used at the departure of any one: : Ty. Bene ambulato. Ph. Bene vale,  and absol.: : ambulare in jus, to go into court, go to law:  .— To walk about with a certain gravity or importance: licet superbus ambules pecuniā.   .— Of inanimate things: : : .—Trop. :  : .— Act., esp. with cognate objects, as iter, via, etc., to navigate, sail, pass over, etc.: : .— Pass.: .— In milit. lang. t. t., to march: .— In the jurists in opp. to ire: .— Trop. very freq. in eccl. Lat. , to walk, in the sense of to live, with an adjunct of manner or circumstances: : : : : fraudulenter ambulare,  .—So also very freq. in N. T., but only once in this sense in the Gospels: : : : : :  et persaepe.

, ussi, ustum, 3, v. a., to burn around, to scorch ; also, with an extension of the idea, to burn wholly up, to consume .  Lit.  Hadrianus vivus exustus est: : : —So Cicero jestingly calls the tribune of the people Munacius Plancus, at whose suggestion the enraged populace set fire to the senate-house, tribunus ambustus, the singed tribune of the people,  Moeb.—Of those whom the lightning had struck, but not killed: :  so  : : : —Hence, ambu-stum, i, n., in medic. lang., a burn: : : : — From the similarity of effect, to injure by cold, to nip, benumb : : .— Trop.  Of property: .— Of one who, when tried for an offence, comes off with great trouble: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  Lit., to furnish with a strap or thong; esp. of the javelin, to the middle of which a strap was fastened, so that it might be thrown with greater force (very rare; .—Trop., of discourse: .—Hence,  Transf., poet., to hurl or dart the javelin by means of a thong: cum jaculum parvā Libysamentavit habenā, * .—And of the wind, which gives an impetus to motion, as a thong to the dart: .

verbParts: , ĭcui, or ixi, ictum, 4, v. a.
fullText: , ĭcui, or ixi, ictum, 4, v. a. , to throw round, to wrap about ; exclusively of upper garments : se amicire or pass. amiciri, to throw round, veil one's self.  Lit.: : : :   28, 14: : qui te togā praetextā amicuit, Brut. ap.  P.: —Poet.: nube umeros amictus,  : : :  so, .— Trop., of other things, to cover, clothe, wrap up: : : : : : : .
, āre, v. a. , to make friendly to one's self: .

, mīsi, missum, 3, v. a. .  In gen., to send away from one's self, to dismiss : quod nos dicimus dimittere, antiqui etiam dicebant amittere, Don. ad  Att. ap. :   so : :  so  :    :  Varr. ap. .— Spec., to let go, let slip: .—With simple abl.:   et saep.:  Ritschl.— Trop.  In gen.: : :  so    (opp. occasionem raptare, Cic.: :  Dähn.; — Of trees, to let go, let fall, to drop, lose: : : .— Esp., to lose : Decius amisit vitam; at non perdidit: dedit vitam, accepit patriam: amisit animam, potitus est gloriā, Auct. ad : Multa amittuntur tarditie et socordiā, Att. ap. : :  et saep.: : : :  so   : : :  Dähn.: : :  so : :  so .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to like, to love,  (both in the higher and the lower sense, opp. odisse; while diligere () designates esteem, regard; opp. neglegere or spernere; cf. Doed. Syn. IV. p. 97; in the high sense in the philos. writings and Epp. of Cicero; often in the low sense, esp. in the comic poets. In the Vulg. amo and amor are comparatively little used, prob. from their bad associations, amo being used 51 times and amor 20. Instead of these words, diligo, dilectio and caritas were used. Diligo occurs 422 times, and dilectio and caritas 144 times in all; dilectio 43 and caritas 101 times).  In gen.: : :  : : : : : : .—So, amare aliquem ex animo, to love with all one's heart, : : : : .—Amare in ccntr. with diligere, as stronger, more affectionate: Clodius valde me diligit, vel, ut  dicam, valde me amat,  :  id. Fragm. ap. ; .—But diligere, as indicative of esteem, is more emph. than amare, which denotes an instinctive or affectionate love: : : : diligis () me plus his? Etiam, Domine, tu scis quia amo () te,  sqq., ubi v. Alford, Gr. Test. al.—Hence in asseverations: ita me dii ament or amabunt, so may the gods love me, by the love of the gods, most assuredly: : : : .—Hence also ellipt.: ita me Juppiter! , .—And as a salutation: Me. Salvus atque fortunatus,  Euclio, semper sies. Eu. Di te ament, Me gadore, the gods bless you! — Esp.  Amare se, of vain men, to be in love with, to be pleased with one's self, also, to be selfish : :  so  : .— Of unlawful love, :  et saep.:  : : :   Heind.;   al. — Trop., to love a thing, to like, to be fond of, to find pleasure in, delight in: : : : : : : : : : : : : amat Janua limen, loves to remain shut, i. e. is constantly closed,  so, —With inf. as object: : .— Amare aliquem de or in aliquā re, quod, etc., to like one for something, to be obliged to one for something, to be under obligation, be thankful.  With de: : .— With in: .— With quod: : amas me, quod te non vidi? Domit. Afer. ap. .—Also without prep. or quod: soror, parce, amabo. Anter. Quiesco. Adelph. Ergo amo te, I like you, am much obliged to you, : .—Hence in the eilipt. lang. of conversation, amabo or amabo te , lit. I shall like you .—Hence in entreaties = oro, quaeso, precor , be so good, I pray, entreat you (in Plaut. and Ter. very freq.; in the latter always amabo without te; : :  et saep.: :  al.; :  : : .—With ut or ne foll.:  : : .— With inf., to do a thing willingly, to be wont or accustomed to :  cf. :  so    .—Hence, ămans, antis, P. a., with gen. or absol.  Fond, loving, kind, feeling kindly to, benevolent, pleasing; and subst., a friend, patron: : : :  : : :  ib. Amos, 5, 11: amantissima eorum non proderunt iis, their most   pleasant things,  so .— Trop., of things, friendly, affectionate: : — Sometimes in a bad sense = amator or amica, a paramour; cf. Wolf ad  cf. :  : : : .— Hence, ămanter, adv., lovingly, affectionately,  .—Comp., .—Sup., .
, āre, v. a. , late Lat.  Lit., of places, to make pleasant: regio aut consita pomis aut amoenata lucis, Salv Gub. Dei, 7 med.— Trop., to please, delight: :

, ītus, 4, v. dep., to remove a person or thing from a place , to move or carry away: amoliri dicuntur ea, quae cum magnā difficultate et molimine summoventur et tolluntur e medio, Don. ad .  Lit., Att. ap. :  so : impedimentum omne, Sisenn. ap. : : : .—Hence, amoliri se , to take one's self away, to go away: non tu te e conspectu hinc amolire? Pac. ap.   so  .— Trop., to put away, avert; in rhet., to refute, repel:  : : amolior et amoveo nomen meum, i. e. omitto, I pass over, lay no stress on, Liv 28, 28:  so  !*? Pass.: : .

, mōvi, mōtum, 2, v. a., to remove from, to put or take away, to withdraw : proprie amovetur saxum de loco, Don. ad  cf.:  v. amolior.  In gen. : me exinde amovit loco. : : : : : : : : : : :   .—Hence: se amovere, to retire, withdraw: : : : .—Trop. of abstract ideas, to put away, cast off, etc.: : :  so, : : : : : : : —Poet., of time, to take with itself: quaecumque vetustate amovet aetas, * .— Esp.  In and after the Aug. per., to take away by stealth, to steal : : : — In post-Aug. prose , to banish: : : :  14, 57.

, exus, 3, v. dep. .  Lit., to wind or twine round a person or thing , to surround, encompass, encircle; of living beings, to embrace : genua amplectens, Liv. And. Od. ap.  P. :  so : : : : : : :  so  et saep.: : : :  et saep.:  * : .— Of space, to embrace: : : .— Trop.  To embrace in mind or knowledge, i. e. to comprehend, to understand: : :  also simply to reflect upon, to consider: .— In discourse, to comprehend, i.e. to discuss, to handle, treat: : : : non ego  cuncta meis amplecti versibus opto, : .—Also of a name, to comprehend under:  cf.:  so of a law, to include: .— Of study, learning, to include, embrace: neque eam tamen scientiam, quam adjungis oratori, complexus es, but yet have notincluded in your attainments that knowledge which, etc., : .— To embrace in heart, i.e. to love, favor, cherish: : :  : :   : : : mens hominis amplectitur maxime cognitionem, delights in understanding, id. Ac. pr. 2, 10, 31: amplectentem eum fidelem sermonem, * : amplexus civitates , having fixed his mind on, i. e. intending to attack, seize, :  .— In circumlocution: magnam Brigantium partem aut victoriā amplexus est aut bello, embraced in conquest, i. e. conquered, .

, ātus, 1, v. dep. freq. , to embrace, encircle .  Lit.: : .—Esp., in love, at greeting, parting, etc.,  : mitto jam osculari atque amplexari, * : : :   .— Trop., to love, honor, cherish, esteem: :  so   : species mirifice Plato erat amplexatus, i. e. adamaverat, suas fecerat, : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make wide, to widen, extend, enlarge, increase .  In gen.: : dolorem, Pac. ap. : : : :  : : .— Trop.: : : . —Aliquem aliquā re: : : .— Esp., in rhet. t. t., to place a subject in some way in a clearer light, to amplify, dilate upon, enlarge upon:  cf.   v. amplificatio.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make wider, to extend, enlarge, increase, amplify .  In gen.: : rem , * :  so : : : — Trop.: : : . — Esp., judic. t. t., to delay judgment or decision, to adjourn, in order to make further investigation .  Absol.: : .— With acc. of pers., to defer his business: istum hominem nefarium ampliaveritis, Auct. ad : : .— With acc. of thing. causam, :  cf. ampliatio and comperendinatio.
, āre, v. a. , old form for amplifico, to extend, enlarge; trop., to make glorious: qui causam humilem dictis amplent, Pac. ap. .
, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to make use of a bombastic style of discourse, = : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to cut around, to cut away or off, to lop off, prune.  Lit., esp. of plants: amputata id est circum putata, Paul. ex  Müll.: : : .—  Müll.: : : : : :  et saep.—In Pliny also of things that are bitten off: .— Trop., to lop off, curtail, shorten, diminish: : : : : .—In rhet.: : .

verbParts: , antrŭo, and andrŭo, āre, v. n.
fullText: , antrŭo, and andrŭo, āre, v. n. , to dance around, in the Salian religious festivals: praesul ut amtruet, inde vulgus redamtruat, Lucil. ap.  Müll.
, āre, v. a. , to make according to rule, i. e. accurately, nicely:  Ritschl.
, āre, v. a. , to mix with starch : : .
, āre, v. a., = .   Lit., to anathematize, to put under the ban: .— In gen., to curse,  .— To detest: .—Form ănă-thĕmo,   .
, ātus, 1, v. dep. and n. , pr., to serve as handmaid; hence, in gen., to serve, to attend upon, to be subservient to, etc. : invita ancillans, Att. ap. : : .

or ancŭlo, āre, v. a. , to serve with, to bring something as servant, to have the care of : antiqui anculare dicebant pro ministrare, Paul. ex  Müll.: carnis vinumque, quod libabant, anclabatur, ap.  P.: florem anculabant, ap. Fest. l. c. .
, āre, v. a. .  Lit., to demand something as angaria, to exact villanage,  so  al. — Meton., to compel, constrain : :  so .

verbParts: , xi, ctum, and anxum, 3, v. a.
fullText: , xi, ctum, and anxum, 3, v. a. .  Lit., to bind, draw, or press together; of the throat, to throttle, strangle :  so :   .—Hence, of plants, to choke,  — Metaph.  To cause pain; hence, angi, to feel or suffer pain, . — Most freq. of the mind, to distress, torment, torture, vex, trouble; and angi, to feel distressed, to suffer torment, etc.: : cura angit hominem, *  * : : :  et saep.;  : : : : : : .—With de : : .—Sometimes with gen. (on this const. cf. Roby, II. § : . But Cic. also uses the abl.: : audio te animo angi, Fam. 16, 142; and acc. to some edd. Tusc. 1, 40, 96 Seyff. .
, āre, v. a. , to make angular or cornered, .—Hence, * angŭlātus, a, um, P. a., made angular; with angles, angular: .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , pr. to make narrow, to straiten; only trop. and in eccl. Lat. to straiten, hamper, distress: : :  6, 12; .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make narrow, to straiten : : : : : angustare aëris meatus. :  .—Trop., to circumscribe, restrain: : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. and a. .  Verb. neutr.  Pr., to move about for breath; hence, to draw the breath with great difficulty, to pant, puff, gasp, etc.: : : * : anhelans ex imis pulmonibus prae curā spiritus ducebatur, Auct. ad :  : : .— In gen., to breathe , .— Metaph., of fire: .—Of the earth: .—Of the foaming of the sea, .—Trop., of poverty panting for something: .— Verb. act., to breathe out, to emit by breathing, breathe forth, exhale: : de pectore frigus anhelans Capricornus, vet. poët. ap. :  so : : .—Trop., to pursue, pant for, strive after something with eagerness: : anhelans ex imo pectore crudelitatem, Auct. ad .!*? Some, as Corssen, Ausspr. II. p. 564, regard the prefix of this word as the Gr.  hence, pr. to draw up the breath; cf. antestor.
, āri, v. dep. , to become an old woman, App. de Mundo, p. 67, 39 Elm.

, ti, sum, 3, v. a. , to direct the mind or attention to a thing, to attend to, give heed to, to take heed, consider, regard, observe.  Lit.  In gen.: : : :  .—With ut, to think of: .— Esp., as t. t.  Of the lictor, whose duty it was to give attention, to see, that the consul, when he appeared, should receive due homage : — Of the people, to whom the lictor gave orders to pay attention, to pay regard to:  Ruhnk.— Transf., as a consequence of attention.  To remark, notice, observe, perceive, see .  With acc.: : utcumque animadversa aut existimata erunt, Liv. praef. med.:   et saep.:  Beier.: .— With acc. and inf.: : : .— With ind. quest.: quod quale sit, etiam in bestiis quibusdam animadverti potest, Cic.Am. 8, 27.— In a pregn. sense, to discern something, or, in gen., to apprehend, understand, comprehend, know : : : : .— To notice a wrong, to censure, blame, chastise, punish : : : : : .—Esp. freq. in judicial proceedings as t. t., constr. with in aliquem: qui institueras   animadvertere in eos, : :  so  :    4, 49;      .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. and n. .  Act.  To fill with breath or air : : .—More freq.,  To quicken, animate : quicquid est hoc, omnia animat, format, alit, auget, creat, Pac. ap.  : : . stellae divinis animatae mentibus,  . — To endow with, to give, a particular temperament or disposition of mind : : Mattiaci ipso terrae suae solo ac caelo acrius animantur, i. e. ferociores redduntur, are rendered more spirited, * .— In Ovid in a pregnant signif.: aliquid in aliquid animare, to transform a lifeless object to a living being, to change into by giving life : : .— Trop., of colors, to enliven: .—Of torches, to light or kindle: .—Sometimes = recreare, to refresh, revive: :  so  or in gen., to encourage, help: .—And with inf. = incitare, to move, incite to: .—Hence, ănĭmātus, a, um, P. a.  Animated : virum virtute verā vivere animatum addecet, Enn. ap. .— Brought or put into a particular frame of mind, disposed, inclined, minded, in some way : : avi et atavi nostri, quom allium ac caepe eorum verba olerent, tamen optime animati erant, Varr. ap. : : : : :  : : : : animatus in necem alicujus, Macr S. 1, 11.—In Plaut. with inf.: si quid animatus es facere, Truc. 5, 74.— Endowed with courage, courageous, stouthearted (cf. animus, II. 2. a. and animosus; : cum animatus iero, satis armatus sum, Att. ap. :  p. 233, 18.—* Sup. Auct. Itin. Alex. 13.— Adv. not used.— Neutr., to be animate, living ; so only ănĭ-mans, antis ,  P. a., animate, living: : : . —Hence,  Subst., any living, animate being;  an animal :   :  so    1, 1038; 2, 78; 2, 880; 2, 921; 2, 943; 2, 1063; 2, 1071; 3, 266; 3, 417; 3, 720; 5, 431; 5, 855;   fin.: : : .—Of animals, living beings, as opp. to plants: .— Of man: hic stilus haud petet ultro Quemquam animantem, * .—Comp., sup., and adv. not used.
, āre, v. n.  To swim to or toward:  Jan here reads adnant; .—With ad:  .— To swim along by or by the side of: .
, āre, v. n., to sail to or toward, to come to by ship.  Absol.: ,  § 76.— With quo: .
, nexui, nexum, 3, v. a., to tie or bind to, to connect, annex.  Lit.: corporibus nostris, * : :  Sall. Fragm. ap. : : , where Jan reads adjecit:  : — Trop.: :  cf. .
, āre. v. n., to wink with the eyes, to wink or blink to or at: alii adnutat, alii adnictat, Naev. ap. Paul. ex  Müll. .
, āre, v. a., to bring to nothing, to annihilate; introd. by Jerome: nullificāsti seu adnihilāsti vel adnullāsti, Hier Ep. 135 fin.

, nīsus or nixus, 3, v. dep.  Lit., to press upon or against, to lean upon; with ad or dat. : : : : .— Trop., to take pains about something, to exert one's self, strive; constr. with ut or ne. or a gerund with ad .  With ut or ne:  :   : — Ad ea patranda omnis civitas summo studio adnitebatur,  .—Other constructions:  With de:  .—  With pro: .—（) With acc. of pron., .—（) With inf.:  .—（) Absol.:  so  .!*? adnītendus, a, um, in pass. signif.: .

, āre, v. n.  To swim to, toward, or along; constr. with the dat., ad, or acc.  With dat.: :  Jan.— With ad: .— With acc.: .—Absol.: plures adnabunt thynni, * .— Trop.: .—  To swim with or along with: .
, āre, v. a. , to pass or live through a year,  cf. Anna.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to cut off knots, to cut away suckers or shoots of the vine, in the lang. of gardening and the vintage,  Schneid.; for which, as also in , other edd. have abnodo.
, āri, v. dep. , to collect provisions, .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to put a note to something, to write down something, to note down, remark, comment on .  In gen.: : :  so : : : —Hence,  = animadvertere, to observe, perceive: .— Adnotare librum, to give a book some title, to entitle, denominate: ausus est libros suos  adnotare, — Annotari, to be distinguished, noted for something: .— Judic. t. t.  To enter or register an absent person among the accused: .— To note or designate one, already condemned, for punishment:  so  7, 20;  Schwarz; .
, āre, v. a., to involve in clouds, to overcast: .—Trop., to obscure: .
, āvi, 1, v. a. , to annihilate, annul : : adnullabitur superbia, ib. ib.; v. annihilo.

, not an-nuncĭo , āre, v. a., to announce, make known, relate, proclaim .  With acc. and inf.: .— With quod: .— With ut and subj.:  .— With acc.: : : :  so, — With acc. and dat.:   .— With de:  ib. Job, 36, 33;  .

, ŭi , ūtum, 3, v. n. , to nod to, to nod.  In gen.: : : : :  to ask by a wink or nod , .— Esp.  To give assent or approval by nodding, to nod assent to, to approve, favor, allow, grant. promise to do : : adnuo Terram intuens modeste, * :  : :   : : : .—With acc. of thing:   4, 10.—With acc. and inf.: adnuvit sese mecum decernere ferro, Enn. ap.  P.:   .— Adnuere alicui aliquid; poet., to promise or grant something to one: : : : adnuite nutum numenque vestrum invictum Campanis, give your assent, etc., .— To designate a person or thing,  By a nod: .— By a wink:  so absol.:   .— By the hand: : . —Hence, in gen., to indicate, declare: .
, īre, v. a., to nourish or train up at or near to: .

, quīsīvi, sītum, 3, v. a. , to seek on all sides, to look about for, to search after.  Lit. and in gen.: anquirere est circum quaerere, Paul. ex  Müll.:  so  .— Trop., to inquire about, to examine into: :  so   — Esp. in judic. lang. t. t.  To institute a careful inquiry or examination: : .— To enter a complaint, to accuse one, with the word designating the punishment in the abl. or gen.: : :  .—Hence, anquīsītē, adv., carefully : , where Hertz now reads inquisite.—Comp.: , where Hertz now reads inquisitius.

, cēpi, ceptum, 3, v. a., to obtain before, to receive before.  In gen.: quam appellat  Epicurus, anteceptam animo rei quandam informationem, an inborn, innate idea,  B. and K. .— Esp.  To take possession of beforehand, to preoccupy:  Dietsch:  Halm.— To anticipate: : .

, cessi, cessum, 3, v. n., to go  before, precede , to take the lead, get the start; with dat., acc., or absol.  Lit.  With dat.: ubi ambitionem virtuti videas antecedere, Titin. ap. : .— With acc.: : biduo me Antonius antecessit, Brut. ap.  :   , and so Vulg. always.— Absol.:   : : antecedens scelestus, * .— Fig.  To precede, in time: haec ei antecessit, * : .— To have the precedence of any one, to excel, surpass; with dat. and acc. .  With dat.: :  so .— With acc. of person or thing and abl. or abl. with in: : : .— Absol., to distinguish one's self, to become eminent:  so .—Hence,  antĕcēdens, entis, P. a.  In gen.: :  so .— T. t. of philosophy, the antecedent :  .—In plur. as subst.: an-tĕcēdentĭa, ōrum, n.:  so   .— antĕces-sus, a, um, P. a., that goes before; only in the connection, in antecessum dare, solvere, accipere, etc.; t. t., to give, pay, receive, etc., beforehand, in advance : : : :

, ĕre , v. n.  lit., to project; hence, trop., to be prominent, to distinguish one's self; and with dat. or acc., to distinguish one's self above any one, to surpass, excel, be superior to; and with abl. of respect (a favorite word with Cic.;  so :  so     Corn. Fragm. ap.  P.; : :  so  , n. 1.—Without the oblique case of the person: : . —* Pass.: qui omnibus his rebus antecelluntur, Auct. ad .
, ĕre, v. n., to run before: .

verbParts: , īvi or ii, īre, v. n.
fullText: , īvi or ii, īre, v. n. .  In space, to go before, precede, to take the lead; with dat., acc., or absol.  With dat.: : .— With acc.: .— Absol.:  so     . — Trop.  To go before: anteibit faciem tuam justitia, * .—  To excel, surpass any one: : : :  : : : —Pass.: :  .—More rare,  To anticipate, prevent any thing:  .— To oppose, resist: .—*  Poet., to know beforehand, to foreknow: .

, tŭli, lātum, ferre, v. a.  To bear or carry before: .—More freq.,  Trop., to place before, to prefer, give the preference to, aliquem alicui:  so     :  .—*  To anticipate: quod dies est allaturus, id consilio anteferre debemus, i. e. to consider beforehand, to reflect upon , .
, gressus, 3, v. dep. , to go before, to precede : :   .
, ēre, v. a., to prefer: .
, ĕre, v. a., to send before, send forwards, send on (rare; , ubi v. Herz.:  .
, īre, v. a. , to furnish with a front or protecting wall, to provide with a rampart:  dub. .
, ēre, v. n., to be more powerful, to excel, surpass :  Elm.: , p. 189, 35 Elm.
, pŏsui, pŏsĭtum, 3, v. a., to set or place before.  Lit.  In gen.: : . — Esp., to set before one :  so  .— Trop., to prefer, give the preference to: : :   .← .

or anti-sto, stĕti, 1, v. n., to stand before, only in a trop. signif., to excel, be superior to; with dat. or acc.; also absol., to distinguish one's self, to be distinguished: :  B. and K.:  Halm: virtute ceteris, Claud, Quadrig. ap. : aliquem, Met. Numid. ap. : : Herculis antistare si facta putabis, *  Lachm.

, ātus, 1, v. dep , a word peculiar to judicial proceedings, to call up as a witness before the opening of the cause, to call as a witness ; so in 1 Fragm. in XII. Tab.: SI. IN. IVS. VOCAT. NI. IT. ANTESTATOR. IGITVR. EM. CAPITO: Ph. Licet te antestari? Th. Non licet,  cf.   so  : magnā Inclamat voce, et Licet antestari? Ego vero Oppono auriculam, * : .—In Cic. once, in gen. sense, not pertaining to judic. proceedings: te, magne, antestaretur, quod nunc etiam facit, Mil. 25 fin.—In a pass. signif., Liv. Andron. ap.  P.—Hence, antestātus, a, um, P. a.; subst., a witness, .

, vēni, ventum, 4, v. n., to come before, get the start of, anticipate.  Lit., with dat. or acc. : :  so : .—Pass.: omni tempore anteventum est, Cato ap. .— Trop., to exceed, surpass, excel : : .— Also, absol., to become greater, more distinguished: .
, ti, sum, 3, v. a. , to place one's self before, to go or come before, to precede.  Lit.: : : .—   Trop.  To anticipate: miror, ubi ego huic antevorterim, * : : .— To prefer, to place before: : .
, āre, v. n. , to go before, Ven. Fort. 4, 26.
, āre, v. n., to fly before; with acc. : : : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  To take before one or before the time, to anticipate something.  With acc.: : :  (cf. anticipatio; : : : — With inf. : .— Absol., to anticipate:  Varr. ap. : .—*  To surpass, excel: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  In class. Lat. only a t. t. of civil life, to leave it in its ancient state, to restore a thing to its former condition .—Hence of a bill, to reject it, not to adopt it:  so   et saep.:  cf.   cf.   : : .— In eccl. Lat., to make old: Dicendo novum, veteravit prius; quod autem antiquatur prope interitum est, * .
, āre, v. a. , to make uneasy or anxious : : : .

, ĕrŭi, ertum, 4, v. a. , to uncover, make or lay bare.  Lit.: : apertae surae, Turp. ap. : :  :  Sall. H. Fragm. ap. : :  and poet. transf. to the person: : —Trop., to make visible, to show, reveal, :  (cf. just before: : : : .—From the intermediate idea of making visible,  Metaph.  To unclose, open: aperto ex ostio Alti Acheruntis, Poët. ap. :  so : :   : : :  so : : : : :  so   : ;  : : : : : :  et saep.: aperire parietem, to open a wall, in order to put a door or window in it, : alicui oculos aperire, to give sight to ,   so, .— Trop.: : amicitiae fores. : : :   et saep.: alicujus oculos aperire, to open one's eyes, make him discern ,    so, : ventus   incendio viam aperuit, :  so : si hanc fenestram aperueritis , nihil aliud agi sinetis,  (cf. :  .— So of the new year, to open it, i.e. begin: :  Gierig and Schaef.—So also of a school, to establish, set up, begin, or open it:  so  .—Poet.: .— Aperire locum , to lay open a place, people, etc., i.e. to open an entrance to, render accessible ;  : : : : :   Cort.: : .— Transf. to mental objects, to disclose something unknown, to unveil, reveal, make known, unfold, to prove, demonstrate; or gen. to explain, recount, etc.: : : : : ne exspectetis argumentum fabulae; : : :  fin.; so  47, 1; : : : : .—So also, se aperire or aperiri, to reveal one's true disposition, character: : :  Quint. prooem. § 3.—Sometimes constr. with acc. and inf., a rel.-clause, or de: :  so : de clementiā, Auct. ad .—In a gen. sense in : de Oppio factum est, ut volui, et maxime, quod DCCC. aperuisti, you promised, i.e. that it should be paid to him ; cf. .—Hence, ăpertus, a, um, P. a.; pr., opened; hence, open, free.  Lit.  Without covering, open, uncovered :   cf. : centum tectae naves et quinquaginta leviores apertae, et saep.; v. navis.—Also, without covering or defence, unprotected, exposed: .—Poet., of the sky, clear, cloudless: : : .— Unclosed, open, not shut : : :  et saep.: : ; so : : : : : :  : : :  so  11, 555 et saep. —Poet., of a battle: nec aperti copia Martis Ulla fuit, an action in the open field, Ov.  M. 13, 208.—Very freq. ăpertum, subst., that which is open, free; an open, clear space: : : :  so : : : .— Trop.  Opp. to that which is concealed, covered, dark, open, clear, plain, evident, manifest, unobstructed:  so   : : : : : : :  et saep.—So, in rhet., of clear, intelligible discourse:  cf. .—Hence,  Esp. as subst.: in aperto esse,  To be clear, evident, well known, notorious, : .— To be easily practicable, easy, facile : : : .— Of character, without dissimulation, open, frank, candid:  : . —Hence, ironically: ut semper fuit apertissimus, as he has always been very open, frank , .—Hence, ăpertē, adv., openly, clearly, plainly.  In gen.: :   : : : : : : : .—Comp.:   : .—Sup.: : : : .— Esp. of what is set forth in words or writing, plainly, clearly, freely, without reserve:  : : : :  .—Comp.: : .—Sup.: : .

, aptus, 3, v. dep. , orig., to reach after something, in order to take, seize, or get possession of it ; hence, in gen.,  To pursue : .—And as the result of the pursuit,  To take, seize upon: .— To reach, attain to, get, gain, acquire , both lit. and trop.: quod ego objectans vitam bellando aptus sum, Pac. ap. : : cupere aliquid apisci, Lucil. ap.  so  p. 74, 23: aliquem, Sisenn. ap. : : laudem, Sulp. ap. : : : : : : :  al.— Once in Tacitus with gen. like the Gr. : dominationis, A. 6, 45.— Poet., to reach something in mind, i. e. to perceive, understand: .!*? Apiscendus, pass.,    cf. adipiscor.

, ĕre, v. a. .  To fasten, attach, join, bind, tie to : comprehendere antiqui vinculo apere dicebant, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. apex, p. 18 Müll.; cf. apex; used only in part. perf. pass. aptus : : : : .— Trop.: ex aliquā re , depending upon, arising from : :  : : : ; cf. .—Once also with pendere: .—Also without ex: : ,   40.— Joined, bound, or tied together, connected: :   : : : : :  . — Trop.: : : .—Poet., with abl., endowed, furnished, or ornamented with something: fides alma, apta pinnis, furnished with wings, winged, Enn. ap. : ; , and: : : : lucus opacus teneris fruticibus aptus, Varr. ap. : .—Hence,  aptus, a, um, P. a., pr., fitted to something; hence, suited, suitable, proper, apposite, fit, appropriate, adapted, conformable to .  In gen.: aptus is, qui convenienter alicui junctus est, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. apex, p. 18 Müll. ; constr. with ad or dat.; of persons always with dat.  With ad: : : : :  so  : : — With dat.: : : : :  so   :  so : : :  : : :  :  et saep.— Other constrr.:  With in : : : : .— With qui (cf. Zumpt, § : .—（) Poet., with inf: : .— Esp. freq., () Absol., Sall. H. Fragm. ap. : : : :  : .—So in prose: :  so — Esp., in rhet., of the fitness, appropriateness of discourse:  so apta oratio, which has the appropriate rhet. fulness and periodic rounding: numerosa et apta  oratio,  cf.  so : .—Hence, aptē, adv., closely, fitly, suitably, nicely, rightly.  Lit.  Absol.: : altera est nexa cum superiore et inde apteque pendens, id. ap. : .— With ad: .— Sup.,  With inter: .— Trop., fitly, suitably, properly, duly, rightly.  Absol.: : : : : : : . —Comp.: : .— With dat.: .—Sup.: .— With ad: : .
, āre, v. a., = , to thrust from one with the foot; hence, to spurn, scorn: apolactizo inimicos omnīs, * .
, āvi, 1, v. a., = , to reject, spurn : .
, āri, v. dep., = , to be in uncertainty, to doubt, vacillate ,   .
, āre, v. n., = , to forsake one's religion, to apostatize : :  .
, āre, v. a. , to lay up in a storehouse, Ven. Ep. praef. Carm. 6, 1, 5.
, āre, v. a. , to make ferment ,
, ĕre, v. a., to fasten to, Paul. ex  Müll.

, ui, itum, 2, v. n., to come in sight, to appear, become visible, make one's appearance .  Lit.: :   so : : unde tandem adpares, Cic. Fragm. ap.  P.; :  so : : : , —With dat.:  : .—Once in Varro with ad: quod adparet ad agricolas, R. R. 1, 40.— In gen., to be seen, to show one's self, be in public, appear: :  cf. :  : : : :  : : , so  al.;  cf.  and 162.—Hence, apparens , visible, evident: :  so .— Trop.: res apparet, and far more freq. impers. apparet with acc. and inf. or rel.-clause, the thing is evident, clear, manifest, certain, : :   fin.: : : : apparet atque exstat,  utrum simus earum rudes, :  :   : —Also with dat. pers.:  and, by attraction, with nom. and inf., as in Gr. , : , ubi v. Otto:  or without the inf., with an adj. as predicate:  .— To appear as servant or aid , to attend, wait upon, serve; cf. apparitor : : :  Drak.: : : tibi appareo atque aeditumor in templo tuo, Pompon. ap. : .
, ĕre, v. inch. , to begin to appear, .
, ĕre, v. a., to gain besides, acquire:  Lachm.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to prepare or make ready for something , to put in order, provide, furnish, equip, etc. .  Lit.: : :  *   cf. :  so : : : : :  .—With ad: .— With in: .— Trop.: : .—Constr. with inf. as object: : : .—Absol. : : .—With ut: .—Se apparare with inf. in Plaut.: .—Hence, appărā-tus , a, um, P. a., pr. prepared; hence,  Of persons, prepared, ready: : .— Of things, well supplied, furnished with every thing: .—Hence, magnificent, splendid, sumptuous : :  Drak.: : :  munus apparatissimum largissimumque, .—Trop., of discourse, too studied, far-felched, labored: ut non apparata oratio esse videatur, Auct. ad  so, .— Adv.: appărātē , sumptuously: : .—Comp.: Potes apparatius cenare apud multos; .
, āre, v. a. , to press to the breast,  dub.

verbParts: (adp-, Fleck., Halm ; app-, Merk., B. and K., Rib., Weissenb., Halm , pŭli, pulsum, 3, v. a.
fullText: (adp-, Fleck., Halm ; app-, Merk., B. and K., Rib., Weissenb., Halm , pŭli, pulsum, 3, v. a. and n., to drive, move or bring a person or thing to or toward.  In gen.  Lit., constr. with ad, or in, with the dat., with quo, or absol.  With ad: :  cf. : : visum in somnis pastorem ad me appellere, to drive toward me, i. e. the herd, the flock, Att. ap. : .— With in: .— With dat.: .— With quo: quo numquam pennis appellunt Corpora saucae Cornices, * .— Absol.: dant operam, ut quam primum appellant, Lucil. ap. : postquam paulo appulit unda , drove a little toward me, brought near, — Trop.: animum ad aliquid, to turn, direct, apply:  so .—Also to bring into any condition:  .— Esp. freq. as a nautical t. t., to bring or conduct a ship somewhere, to land ; constr.: appellere navem, nave, or absol. in act. and pass.; also navis appellit, or appellitur .  With navem.   abitu appellant huc ad molem nostram naviculam, Afran. ap. : :  Wernsd.: :  so :   — With nave:  cf. Gron. ad .— Act. absol.: huc appelle, * : : :  so .— Pass. absol.: : .— Seldom in a neutr. sense: :  : . —Poet.:  so .— Trop.: : .

, āvi, ātum, 1 , orig. v. n., as a secondary form of the preced. , to drive to or toward, to go to in order to accost, make a request, admonish, etc.; like adire, aggredi; hence like these constr. as v. a. with acc., to accost, address, to speak to, call upon .  In gen. adgrediar hominem, adpellabo, : :  cf.  :  : , 22: Lucil. ap.  aliquem hilari vultu, : : : : :  milites alius alium laeti appellant, , : senatu coram appellato, Suet Ner. 41; : —Also to address by letter: .— Esp  Freq. with the access. idea of entreating, soliciting, to approach with a request, entreaty, etc., to apply to, to entreat, implore, beseech, invoke, etc.:  quem enim alium appellem? quem obtester? quem implorem? :  : : : .— Aliquem de aliquā re, to address one in order to incite him to something : .—Also without de:  .— In judic. language, t. t., to appeal to one, i. e. to call upon him for assistance : :  so,  :  , praef. 10: mox et ipse appellato demum collegio , obtinuit, etc., :  et saep.— To address in order to demand something, esp. the payment of money, to dun:    and without de: magnā pecuniā appellabaris a creditoribus,   Alphius ap. .—Trop.: .—Later also appellare rem, to demand, claim something: .— To sue, inform against, complain of, accuse, to summon before a court:  so, — To accost by any appellation ; hence, to call by name, or to call, to term, entitle, to declare or announce as something :  so  : , pater a gnatis ne dulcibus umquam Appelletur,   : : : :  suo quamque rem nomine appellare, : : . quem nautae appellant Lichan,  victorem appellat Acesten, declares him victor, —Hence, to call by name: : multi appellandi laedendique sunt, id Verr 2, 1, 60;  so, .—Trop.: —*  Appellare litteras, to pronounce, .

, endi, ensum, 3 , v. a.  To hang something upon something, to suspend on : .— Commonly to weigh something to one, to weigh Lit.: : : : : :  so : :  Esdr 8, 33:  Jan; .—*  Trop., to weigh, to consider: non verba me adnumerare lectori putavi oportere, sed tamquam appendere, to have regard not to their number, but to their weight or force, : .
, ēre, v. n., to belong to, appertain to; with dat. or ad, Innoc. p. 221 Goes.; p. 232 Goes.

verbParts: , īvi or ii, ītum, 3, v. a.
fullText: , īvi or ii, ītum, 3, v. a. and n. ; act., to strive after a thing, to try to get, to grasp after .  Lit.  In gen.:  so :  so, adpetere manum osculis, to seize upon the hand with kisses, i. e. in order to kiss it,   hence , to go or come somewhere, to approach, arrive at: .— Of things without life: mare terram adpetens, pressing or rushing on, : : .— Esp., to attack, to fall or seize upon, assault, assail (syn.: :  :  : :   —Trop.: : : .— Trop.,   to strive after earnestly, to desire eagerly, to long for : aliut in dies magis adpetitur, * :  cf. : :  so   : : : : :  : : :  et saep.—Also of food, to have an appetite for : : .—Constr. with inf. as object:   .— Neutr., to draw on or nigh, to approach, be at hand (only of time and things having relation to it; : :  so  :  so  : : : : — Hence, appĕtens , entis, P. a. ; pr. striving passionately after something; hence,  In gen., desirous of, eager for; constr. with gen.: : :  so   :     4, 83; .—  Esp., eager for money , avaricious: : .—Adv.: appĕtenter , eagerly, in a grasping spirit or manner:   Elm.—Comp. and sup. not used.
, ĕre, v. a., to paint upon something : Delphinum silvis adpingit, fluctibus aprum, * :  , p. 257; Laud. Neglig. 2, 371.—In Cic. in epistolary style, also of writing, to add by writing, to  write: .
, ĕre, 3, v. a. , to fasten or joint to: aliquid alicui rei, Paul. ex  Müll.

, , si, sum, 3, v. a.  To strike one thing upon another, to clap: :  so :  so : terrae ,  , p. 236, 21.— Trop., to clap the hands in approbation, to applaud: : : : : cui generi civium maxime adplaudatur? * , where B. and K. read plaudatur.

verbParts: , āvi and ui, ātum and ĭtum, 1, v. a.
fullText: , āvi and ui, ātum and ĭtum, 1, v. a. ; orig., to join, fasten, or attach to, to affix; hence, to bring, add, put, place to or near to, etc. .  In gen.  Lit.; constr. usu. with ad; rarely with dat.  With ad: :  : : : : —  With dat.: : : : :  .—Also with local adv.: .— Trop.  To connect with, to add to a thing: : :  .— Se or animum, to attach, apply, or devote one's self or one's mind to a person or thing: :  : ad Siculos se adplicavit, Varr. ap.  P.: :  so   : : : : :  so : sese ad convivia, Cato ap. : : : : — Crimen alicui, to charge one with a crime, .— Esp., naut. t. t., navem, or absol. applicari, and in the act. as v. n. , to drive, direct, steer, or bring a ship anywhere, to land, to bring to land: . 51, 153: ad Heraeum naves adplicuit, Liv 33, 17;  Held.: :  Ruhnk. and Loers.—With in and acc.: : ad terram adplicant, Auct. B. Hisp. 37 fin.; so   .—With acc. of place whither: .—With abl.: .—Absol.: .—Poet.: quo accedam? quo adplicem? Enn. ap. : quae vis immanibus applicat oris, drives or brings you, etc., : .—Hence,  applĭcātus , a, um, P. a.  Placed upon, lying upon or close to, attached to: : , and : .— Inclined or adapted to, directed to: : .— Comp., sup., and adv. not used.— ap-plĭcĭtus , a, um, P. a., applied or joined to, attached to: : : vites arboribus adplicitae,   .—Trop.: .
, āvi, 1, v. n., to lament, deplore a thing, to weep at or on account of .  With dat.:  K. and H.— Absol.:  Haase.
, āre, v. a., to apply lead to, to solder; only found in the part. perf.: :  so  .

, pōsŭi, pŏsĭtum, 3, v. a. , to place, put, or lay at, near or by the side of a thing; to apply to, add, unite, etc. .  Lit.  In gen.: :  so : : Sy. Onus urget. Mi. At tu adpone, put it down then, : : :  so :  : :  so  cf. : manus ad os , Cael. ap. : : : adpositum in mensā lumen, :  et saep.: .—So freq. of the putting on of garments, crowns, etc.: :  Loers; cf. : : —  Esp.  Freq. as t. t. of food, dishes, to serve up, set before one (cf. Gr.  : : : :      :     :  al.;  — Aliquem alicui or alicui rei, to appoint or designate one to any service or duty, to place in any station, to join to as an aid:  so  cf.: adpositus custodiae ,   so , § 41 fin.: : :  cf. : :  so, : — To put to something by way of increase, to add to, superadd (rare; cf.  : : :  .— Trop.  Of the mind, to apply : : .— In eccl. Lat., after the Hebrew, of an act, to do  further, also to do something:  so :  .— With a dat. of end, to set down for something, count, reckon, or consider as, to hold as : : .—Hence, appŏsĭ-tus , a, um, P. a., put or applied to, etc.  Of relations of space, placed or situated at or near to, contiguous to, bordering upon; constr. with dat.: : : .—Trop.: .—  Metaph.  Fit, proper, suitable, appropriate, apposite, etc. ; constr. with ad (in this signif. very freq. in Varr. and Cic.; : : :    fin.; : : . —*  Inclined to; constr. with dat.: .— Subst.: appŏsĭtum, i, n., in rhet. and gram., an epithet, adjective:   .—Hence, appŏsĭtē, adv., suitably, fitly, etc.:  cf. Spald ad  praeclare et apposite et facete scribere, .

, āre, v. a., to entreat or solicit importunately: .

, āre, v. n., to make one's own, to appropriate:

, ātus, 1, v. dep. .  In gen., to be a hearer or beholder of something , to observe, perceive, hear, etc. :    , p. 138, 23; 7 init.: , p. 148, 8.—Hence of the mind, to examine, consider, weigh: .— Esp.  T. t. of judic. lang. , to make a decision, give judgment or sentence:  .—Hence, fidem alicui arbitrari, to adjudge, i. e. to give, credit to one, to put faith in, .—Of witnesses, as t. t., to testify, to declare or announce, give evidence: : qui primum   illud verbum consideratissimum nostrae consuetudinis arbitror, quo nos etiam tunc utimur, cum ea dicimus jurati, quae comperta habemus, quae ipsi vidimus, ex toto testimonio suo sustulit, atque omnia se scire dixit, :  .— In gen., to be of the opinion, to believe, consider as, = : Bene facta male locata male facta arbitror, Enn. ap. : : : :  Pet. 1, 13: :  : :        :  so   :  : : : : :  so — To think, suppose, as opp. to knowing: : : De. Sanumne credis te esse? Mi. Equidem arbitror, :  :  .!*?  Act. form arbĭtro, āre: : . — Arbitror in pass. signif.: :    cf. :  so  : ex scriptis eorum, qui veri arbitrantur, , Cael. ap.  P.

, ātus, 1, v. dep. .  To adduce proof of a thing, to prove:   :   — To adduce something as proof: : .— To make a conclusion, to conclude:  cf. Auct. ad .!*? Pass.: omnia argumentata nomina , Aufusius ap.  P.

, ŭi, ūtum , 3, v. a. .  In gen., to make clear, to show, prove, make known,  declare, assert, : : : : :  .—Pass., in a mid. signif.: : .— Esp.  With aliquem, to attempt to show something, in one's case, against him, to accuse, reprove, censure, charge with: Indicāsse est detulisse; : tu delinquis, ego arguar pro malefactis? Enn. ap. Rufin. § :  : : : : : :    — With the cause of complaint in the gen.; abl. with or without de; with in with abl.; with acc.; with a clause as object; or with ut .  With gen.: : : : : :  : : : : : : : : :  —  With abl.:  — With de: : :  .— With in with abl. : .—（) With acc.: quid undas Arguit et liquidam molem camposque natantīs? of what does he impeach the waves? etc., quid being here equivalent to cujus or de quo,  Munro.—（) With an inf.-clause as object:  : : :   :  .—（) With ut, as in Gr. , : .— Transf. to the thing.  To accuse, censure, blame: : :  :  : : : .— Trop., to denounce as false:  Roth.—With reference to the person, to refute, confute: .—Hence, argūtus, a, um, P. a.  Of physical objects, clear.  To the sight, bright, glancing, lively: : : :  : : aures breves et argutae, ears that move quickly , : .— To the hearing, clear, penetrating, piercing, both of pleasant and disagreeable sounds, clear-sounding, sharp, noisy, rustling, whizzing, rattling, clashing, etc. : linguae, Naev. ap. : : : : ilex, murmuring, rustling , :  al.—Hence, a poet. epithet of the musician and poet, clear-sounding, melodious: : : : forum, full of bustle or din, noisy, : : al.—Hence, of rattling, prating, verbose discourse: :  Ritschl.— Trop., of written communications, rattling, wordy, verbose: : vereor, ne tibi nimium arguta haec sedulitas videatur, Cael. ap. . —Transf. to omens, clear, distinct, conclusive, clearly indicative, etc.: : .— To the smell; sharp, pungent: .— To the taste; sharp, keen, pungent:  .— Of mental qualities.  In a good sense, bright, acute, sagacious, witty: : :  so, : : : — In a bad sense, sly, artful, cunning: : calo. : .—As a pun: ecquid argutus est? is he cunning? Ch. Malorum facinorum saepissime , .—Hence, adv.: argūtē .  Subtly, acutely: : : .—Comp.: .— Sup.: .— Craftily:  .

Lit., to furnish with weapons, to arm, equip, aliquem or aliquem aliquā re: : : : : :  : milites iis armis armare, Pomp. ap. : : : : :  so, : : —Followed by in, contra, adversus:   :  for adversus, v. infra. —That for which one is armed, with in or ad: : .— Trop.  To arm, equip, furnish: : : te ad omnia summum ingenium armavit, Caecil. ap. : : : : : :  Pet. 4, 1: : :  cf.  .— To excite, stir up, rouse, provoke; constr. with adversus, ad or in: : :  so : : :  .— To furnish with something needful, esp. with the munitions of war, to fit out, equip: : : Claudius triremes quadriremesque   et undeviginti hominum milia armavit, .—Hence, armātus, a, um, P. a., armed, equipped, fitted with armor ; also subst.: armātus, i, m., an armed man, a solier, = miles.  Adj.  Lit.: : cum animatus iero satis armatus sum, Att. ap.   ib. Judith, 9, 6: ab dracontis stirpe armatā exortus, Att. ap. :  so    cf. : : : : : : .— Meton.: .—Trop.: excitati, erecti, armati animis, armed, furnished, etc., .—In the sup. only twice, and referring to the pos. armatus in connection with it , : .— Subst.: gravidus armatis equus , Enn. ap. : armatos educere, id. ap. : :  so :    .

, repsi, reptum, 3, v. n., to creep or move slowly to or toward something, to steal softly to, lit. and trop.; constr. with ad; post-Aug. with dat.  Lit.:  so :  — Trop.: sensim atque moderate ad amicitiam adrepserat, * : leniter in spem Adrepe officiosus, * : : .

In gen., to seize, lay hold of, take possession of, secure: : : :  so : : : : : : : : .—Trop., of the mind, to seize upon with eagerness or haste, to learn quickly or with avidity: :  cf. : : : .— As a judicial t. t., to bring or summon before a tribunal, to complain of, accuse (cf. rapio; : : : : : : .—Hence,  In Horace, to attack with ridicule or reproach, to ridicule, satirize: Primores populi  arripuit populumque tributim, Sat. 2, 1, 69: .
, rōsi, rōsum, 3, v. a., to gnaw or nibble at, to gnaw .  Lit.: : : : .— Trop.: ut illa ex vepreculis extracta nitedula rem publicam conaretur adrodere, * : .

Brutus ap. : ingredi, * : .—Comp.: : : .—Sup.,  .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. and n.  Lit., to make one thing like another, to consider as similar, to compare : :  : : : : :  so  : :  : . — To represent something that is not, as real, to imitate, counterfeit, to pretend, to feign, simulate; constr. usu. with acc.; ante - class. with inf., acc. and inf., or with quasi; v. assimilis .  With acc.: : : : : : : : : .— With simple inf.: furere adsimulavit, Pac. ap. : .— With acc. and inf.: : :     :  — With quasi: : Ad. Ita nos adsimulabimus. Co. Sed ita adsimulatote, quasi ego sim peregrinus,  : .—And absol.: .—!*? The much-discussed question, whether adsimilo or adsimulo is the best orthog. , is perh. solved in the foll. remarks: Such is the affinity of the sound of ŭ and ĭ in Lat., that when they stand in two successive syllables, separated by the semivowel l, the u is accommodated to the i. Thus, from consŭl arises consĭlĭum; from exsŭl, exsĭlĭum; from famŭl, famĭlĭa; so the terminations ĭlis and ŭlus, not ŭlis and ĭlus ; and so it is also explained, that from the orig. facul and difficul arose faculter, facultas; difficulter, difficultas; not facŭlis, facŭliter, facŭlītas; difficŭlis, difficŭlĭter, difficŭlĭtas; but facilis, faciliter, facilitas; difficilis, difficiliter, difficilitas. This principle, applied to the derivatives of simul, shows the correctness of the orthography simulo, simulatio, simulator, with similis, similitudo, similitas; adsimulo, adsimulatio, adsimulator, with adsimilis; dissimulo, dissimulatio, dissimulator, with dissimilis and dissimilitudo, etc.; cf.  P.: Similo non dicimus, sed similis est. Sane dixerunt auctores simulat per u, hoc est . But since the copyists knew that the more rare signif. of making like was not generically connected in the words simulare and adsimulare with the more usual one of imitating, dissembling, they wrote, where the former was required, similo, adsimilo, and gave occasion thereby to the entirely unfounded supposition that the ancients wrote, for the signif. making like, similo, adsimilo; for that of imitating, feigning, simulo, adsimulo Fr.—Hence, assĭmŭlātus , a, um, P. a.  Made similar, similar, like: : : : : : : .— Imitated, i. e. feigned, pretended, dissembled: : : : :  —Comp., sup., and adv. not in use.—* assĭmŭlanter , adv. , in a similar manner: dicta haec, Nigid. ap. .

, ēvi, ētum, 3 , v. a., to use or accustom one to something, to habituate; or, more freq., v. n., to accustom one's self to, to be wont, to be accustomed to.  In gen.; constr. usu. with abl. or inf.; after the Aug. per. also with ad, in with acc., or dat.  With abl. (a constr. unjustly censured by Wunder, Rhein. Mus. 1829, II. p. 288 sq. Quam non adstricto percurrat pulpita socco, not drawn close, loose; poet. for a negligent style of writing, : : :  : :  so, alvum, to make costive ,  .—Of the contraction produced by cold:  so  : : :  .—Hence, also, to make colder, to cool, refresh: : corpus astringes brevi Salone, Mart.  1, 49, 11 .—Of colors, to deaden:  (diff. from alligare, which precedes; .— Trop., to draw together, draw closer, circumscribe; to bind, put under obligation, oblige, necessitate: : vellem, suscepisses juvenem regendum;  so,  Spald.: : : :  Wund.: :  : : : :  et saep.: : : : : :  :  :   so  perh. also  instead of this abl. of class. Latin, we sometimes find in comedy apparently the gen.: : .—Of reasoning or discourse, to compress, abridge, bring into short compass: ; :  Frotsch., Halm.—Hence, astrictus , a, um, P. a., drawn together, tight, narrow, close.  Lit.: : : : : .— Trop.  Sparing, parsimonious, covetous : : : .— Of discourse, compact, brief, concise, short : : :  .—Sup. not used.—Adv.: astrictē , concisely, briefly : .—Comp.: , and : : .—Sup. not used.

, struxi, structum, 3, v. a., to build near or in addition to a thing, to add .  Lit.: : : sicut ante secunda fortuna tot victorias adstruxerat; : .— In gen.  To add to: : victus ab   eo Pharnaces vix quicquam gloriae ejus adstruxit, :  so, : : : : : : : : .— To furnish with something : .—Trop.: .!*? The signif. affirmare, which Agroet. p. 2268 P., and Beda, p. 2334 P. give, is found in no Lat. author; for in , instead of adstruxerunt, it is better to read adseverant; v. Sillig ad h. l.; so also Jan.
, ēre, v. n., to be amazed at or on account of, to be astonished at (rare, and mostly poet.; : :  .—Of inanimate things: .
, āre, v. a. , to touch; and, in a bad sense, to attack, rob , .—Hence, also, to dishonor, contaminate, defile: : aliquem sacramentis Judaicis, Cod. Th. 3, 1, 5.—Trop.: .
, āre, v. a., to fit, adjust, accommodate : : .—Hence, * attempĕrātē, adv., opportunely, seasonably, = accommodate, commode: .

, tendi, tentum, 3, v. a., orig., to stretch something toward something; so only in Appul.: arcum, Met. 2, p. 122, 5.—Hence,  In gen., to direct or turn toward, = advertere, admovere: aurem, Att. ap.  Trag. Rel. p. 173 Rib. : ; so, manus caelo, to stretch or extend toward, : .—Far more freq.,  Trop.  Animum or animos attendere, or absol. attendere, also animo attendere, to direct the attention, apply the mind to something, to attend to, consider, mind, give heed to With animum or animos: animum ad quaerendum quid siet, Pac. ap. : : : : : praeterea et nostris animos attendere dictis atque adhibere velis, Lucil. ap. : .—With a rel.-clause as object: .— Absol.: : :  so    —With acc. of the thing or person to which the attention is directed: :  so    : me de invidiosis rebus dicentem attendite.  : :  Esdr. 9, 34; ib. Job, 21, 5; .— Pass.: .  —With inf. or acc. and inf. as object: quid futurum est, si pol ego hanc discere artem attenderim? Pompon. ap. : .—With a rel.clause or a subjunct. with a particle: : : : : : :    .— With de: .—With dat. : :  :  :   .—So in Suet. several times in the signif. to devote attention to, to study, = studere: : : .—With abl. with ab (after the Gr.  :    .— With animo : : : ut magis magisque attendant animo, Vulg. Eccli. prol.; so, .—*  To strive eagerly for something, long for: puer, ne attenderis Petere a me id quod nefas sit concedi tibi, Att. ap. .—Hence, attentus, a, um, P. a.  Directed to something, attentive, intent on: : : : : : : :  2, 19, 80;  Auct. ad : : .— Intent on, striving after something, careful, frugal, industrious: : : : : : :  Matth.: : .—Comp.: hortor vos attentiori studio lectionem facere, * Vulg. Eccli. prol.—Hence, adv.: atten-tē, attentively, carefully, etc.:     : : : .— Comp.: : : : :  Pet 1, 22.—Sup.: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., lit., to strive after something, to attempt, essay, try, make trial of; to solicit; to assail, attack : : : : : : : : :  so, : pudicitiam, to seek to defile or pollute, : .—Of a hostile attack: : : .—Trop.: Quae aegritudo insolens mentem attemptat tuam? Pac. ap. .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to make thin or weak; to thin, attenuate; to weaken, enfeeble; to lessen, diminish.  Lit.: aëna Signa manus dextras ostendunt adtenuari Saepe salutantūm tactu, * : : :  :  : : : : : : :  so .— Trop.:  : : : : hujusmodi partes sunt virtutis amplificandae, si suadebimus; attenuandae, si ab his dehortabimur, Auct. ad. : .—Hence, attĕnŭātus , a, um, P. a., enfeebled, weakened, reduced, weak.  Lit.: : continuatione laborum, August. ap. : fortuna rei familiaris attenuatissima, Auct. ad : : .—Comp. not in use. —Sup.: fortunae familiares attenuatissimae, Auct. ad .— Trop.  Feeble, destitute, poor :     Esdr. 5, 18. — Esp., of discourse.  Shortened, brief: ipsa illa juvenilis redundantia   multa habet attenuata, .— Too much refined, affected: .— Meagre, dry, without ornament: attenuata est, quae demissa est usque ad usitatissimam puri sermonis consuetudinem, Auct. ad : .—* Adv.: at-tenuātē, simply: .
, āre, v. a., to set bounds to, to measure, limit: .

, trīvi, trītum, 3, v. a. , to rub one thing against another; hence, in gen., to rub away, wear out or diminish by rubbing, to waste, wear away, weaken, impair, exhaust.  Lit. : insons Cerberus leniter atterens caudam, rubbing against or upon , * : : aures, * : :  so , and  so, : :    .—Poet., of sand worn by the water flowing over it: .— Trop., to destroy, waste, weaken, impair: : :  so     cf.  Drak.: : :  Rupert.: , prooem. 4: : .— Hence, attrītus, a, um, P. a., rubbed off, worn off or away, wasted.  Lit.  In gen.: ut rictum ejus ac mentum paulo sit attritius, * : :  cf.  Rupert.:  .— In medicine, attritae partes or subst. attrita, ōrum, n. , bruised, excoriated parts of the body: : .— Trop.: attrita frons, a shameless, impudent face ,  Rupert.; so, .—Sup. and adv. not used.

, ātus, 1, v. dep., to bear witness to, to attest, prove, confirm, corroborate (very rare, and not before the Aug. per.; for in  the reading should be, with Cod. Erf. and Lambin., ad testandam omnium memoriam; v. Frotsch. ad h. l.; : Plin.  H. N. praef. § : attestata fulgura, in the lang. of omens, lightnings which confirm that which was indicated by previous lightnings, confirmatory : : attestata dicebantur fulgura, quae iterato fiebant, videlicet significationem priorum attestantia, Paul. ex  Müll.; cf. Müll. Etrusk. 2, p. 170.
, texui, textum, 3, v. a.  To weave on or to something : : .— In gen., to add: :
, āre, v. n., = , to imitate the Athenian manner of speaking:  App. Flor. n. 18, p. 362, 12.
, āre, v. a. , to tickle, please, .

, tĭnui, tentum, 2, v. a. and n. .  Act., .  To hold to, to bring or hold near: .— To hold or detain at some point , to hold fast, keep hold of, to hold, keep, detain, hold back, delay:  : :  :  2, 10; 3, 71 fin.:  3, 36 fin.; 12, 68; 13, 15; 13, 27; :    14, 56 fin.; 16, 19; — To hold possession of, to occupy, keep, guard, preserve: Quamque at tinendi magni dominatūs sient, Ter. Fragm. ap. : .— Neutr.  To stretch out to, to reach to: .—Hence, of relations of place, to extend or stretch somewhere: .— To belong somewhere; only in the third person: hoc attinet ad me , or absol. hoc attinet, this belongs to me, concerns me, pertains or appertains to me, relates or refers to me; cf. Rudd. II. p. 209; Roby, § 1534 .  Attinet ad aliquem: : :  : : , and :  et saep.:  :     :  : :  so  :  : : : Do. Hae quid ad me? Tox. Immo ad te attinent: : : .—And with nunc = ad hoc tempus : Quod nunc attinet, vade, and for this time , .— Attinet aliquem: neque quemquam attinebat   id recusare, : de magnitudine vocis nihil nos attinet commonere, Auct. ad : , n. 14.— Hoc attinet , and more freq. attinet with an inf. as subject , it concerns, it matters, is of moment, is of consequence, is of importance: ea conquisiverunt, quae nihil attinebant, Auct. ad : : : : :    6, 38; 34, 3; 36, 11; —And in pregn. signif., it is serviceable, useful, or avails for, etc.: : : : .

, tĭgi, tactum, 3, v. a. , to touch, come in contact with; constr. with the acc.; poet. with ad.  Lit.  In gen.: mento summam aquam, vet. poët. ap. : vestem, Att. ap. :  Rib.: : : : : : : : .—Poet.: miles erat Phoebes, nec Maenalon attigit ulla Gratior hac Triviae, : .— With partic. access. ideas.  To touch by striking, to strike; rarely in a hostile manner, to attack, assault:  : : .—Of lightning: ICTV. FVLMINIS. ARBORES. ATTACTAE. ARDVERINT., Fragm. Fratr. Arval.  cf.  so .— In mal. part., aliquam, to touch:  .— To touch in eating, to taste, crop: .— Of local relations, to come to a place, to approach, reach, arrive at (class.; : : : : : : :   — Transf., to touch, lie near, border upon, be contiguous to: :  : : : : .— Trop.  In gen., to touch, affect, reach: : : : : , A: :  Claud. B. Get: 412; .— Esp.  To touch upon in speaking, etc., to mention slightly: : : :  : : : :  — To touch, i. e. to undertake, enter upon some course of action , to apply one's self to, be occupied with, engage in, to take in hand, manage:  cf.  : : :  so : : : : : : : .— To arrive somewhere: .— To come near to in quality, to be similar; or to belong to, appertain to, to concern, relate to: : :   : : : :   .—*  Si quid eam humanitus attigisset , if any misfortune had happened to her, .!*? Ne me attiga atque aufer manum, Turp. ap.  dub. : custodite istunc, ne attigat, Pac., Trag. Rel. p. 105 Rib.

verbParts: , no perf. or sup., 3, v. a.
fullText: , no perf. or sup., 3, v. a., to lift or raise up, raise, elevate, lift on high .  Lit.: : : pallium attollere, i. e. accingere , * : : Nec semel irrisus triviis attollere curat Fracto crure planum, to raise up the juggler, to help him up, *  Schmid: : : : : : : : : : : :  :  cf.: : : : : : .— : .—Of buildings, to raise, erect, build: : : : .—Poet.:  cf. .— Trop., to raise, elevate, exalt, sustain; also, to enlarge, aggrandize, to render prominent or conspicuous, to extol : : : : : : :  Ruhnk. ; so,     : : his contrahitur, attollitur , demittitur, : : : .— Form attolo, of doubtful meaning:  p. 105 .

, tondi, tonsum, 2, v. a. , to shave, shear, clip, crop (rare, and mostly poet.; :  and :  so, .—Poet., to gnaw at, nibble: : : .—Trop.: consiliis nostris laus est attonsa Laconum, shorn,   i. e. diminished, lessened, vet. poët. ap. : : attondere aliquem, i. e. to cheat, fleece ,   : .

, ŭi, ĭtum, 1, v. a., to thunder at; hence, to stun, stupefy : altitudo attonat, Maecen. ap. :  .—Hence, attŏnĭtus , a, um, P. a., thundered at; hence trop. as in Gr. .  Thunderstruck, stunned, terrified, stupefied, astonished, amazed, confounded: : :  : :    9, 409 and 574; 11, 127; 8, 681 al.: alii novitate ac miraculo attoniti, Liv 1, 47; 2, 12; 5, 46; 3, 68 fin.; 7, 36; 30, 30; 39, 15;  so  3, 13. —With de: .—Also without an abl.:  6, 600; : : : : :   :  .—Poet., with gen.: .—Also poet. transf. to inanimate things: : :  Drak.: . — Seized with inspiration, smitten with prophetic fury, inspired, frantic: : : Vates, * .—* Adv.: attŏnĭtē, frantically, etc.: .
, ēre, v. a., to hurl or swing upward : .
, ēre, v. a., to bake, roast (cf. assicco;  .

, traxi, tractum, 3, v. a., to draw to or toward, to attract, drag with force, draw .  Lit.: adducitur a Veneriis  atque adeo attrahitur Lollius, is dragged by force, : : : : : :  so, : : : : : : :  : .— Trop., to draw, lead, bring, move, attract, etc.: : recepi causam Siciliae; : : : .—Hence, * attractus, a, um, P. a., drawn or attracted; of the brow, contracted, knit: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to touch, handle, freq. in an unlawful manner .  Lit.: : : : : : : : alienam rem, Sabin. Jus Civ. ap. : .— To feel after, grope for : .— Trop.: Facilis est illa occursatio et blanditia popularis; aspicitur, non attrectatur;  Wund.—Also, to appropriate to one's self: : : .—To feel after, seek to find : .
, ĕre, v. n., to tremble at a thing : : .
, āre, v. n., to hobble along: .
