fullText: , no perf., ātum, āre, v. a., to press hard, to thresh: .

, ŭi, ūtum, 3, v. a., to associate, add or join to, to annex, assign, bestow, give .  In gen.  Lit.: : : : : : : pontifici sacra omnia. : possessionem,  : .—Of the assigning of state domains or other possessions belonging to the public treasures: —Hence of appropriations from the exchequer: :  fin.; .—Hence also aliquem, to assign, make over to any one: .— Trop.: : : : .— Esp.  To join in addition, to add: .— Aliquid alicui, to attribute or impute to one, to charge with, ascribe to : : : : .— T. t., to lay as a tax or tribute: .—Hence, attrĭbūtus , a, um, P. a., lit. that is ascribed or attributed to a thing; hence, subst.: attrĭbūtum, i, n. Money assigned from the public treasury,  Müll.— In gram. lang., a predicate, attribute:   sqq.;
, ĕre, v. a., a very ancient form for affero, to bring to: dotem ad nos nullam attulas, Nov. ap.  P. .
, ēre, v. a. , to observe attentively: .
, āre, v. a. , to increase, enlarge; in the lang. of sacrifice , to honor by offerings : :  so  p. 223.
, ātus, 1, v. dep. .  Neutr., to hold an auction or public sale, make a sale by auction: : : : .—*  As v. a., to buy at auction: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  To become security for, to give a pledge as bondsman,  .—Trop., in the pass.: .— More freq. se auctorare, or pass. auctorari, to bind or oblige one's self to something, to hire one's self out for some service (mostly post-Aug.; .—Esp. of gladiators: Quid refert, uri virgis ferroque necari Auctoratus eas, *  (qui se vendunt ludo auctorati vocantur;  Bip.:  .—Hence, in the pun: .—Hence,  In gen., to bind:  .— *  Sibi mortem aliquā re, to bring death to one's self by some means, .
or -nascit , v. inch. impers. , autumn approaches, is coming on, .
, āre, v. n. , to cause or bring on autumn : : .

, ātus, 1, v. dep. and act. , to go bird-catching or fowling.  Lit.:  .—Also of taking bees: .— Trop., to chase, give chase to, strive for, be on the look-out for, lie in wait for; watch for, etc. (a favorite figure in prose and poetry; in Cic. perh. twenty times; : : : :      19, 63; :  : occasionem, Auct. B. Afr. 3 fin.: obtrectatione alienae scientiae famam sibi, Plin. H. N. praef. § 30; : : : .!*?  Act. form aucŭpo, āre, to watch for, etc.: fructus verborum aures aucupant, Enn. ap. : :  so : : : .—*  Pass. form aucupor: .

, ausus, 2, v. a. and n. , to venture, to venture to do, to dare; to be bold, courageous ; constr. with acc., inf., quin, in with acc. or abl., and absol.  With acc. :  so,   : quid domini faciant, audent cum talia furesl :  :    : :  4, 49; 11, 9; 12, 28; 14, 25;         hence also pass.: : :  : .—Also ausus, a, um, pass., — With inf. (the usual constr.; : : : :    : :   by poet. license transf. to things: Vitigeni latices in aquaï fontibus audent Misceri, the juice from the vine ventures boldly to intermingle with the water,  : : : ut de Ligarii non audeam confiteril : audeo dicere, I dare say, venture to assert, = ,  et saep.:  : : : : :   ib. Job, 29, 22; 37, 24;    et persaepe.—* With quin: .— With in with acc. or abl. : Rogo vos ne praesens audeam in quosdam , : In quo quis audet, audeo et ego , .—（) Absol.: : : : : : .—With an object to be supplied from the context:   Frotsch.; 1, 5, 72: Judaei sub ipsos muros struxere aciem, rebus secundis longius ausuri , : 2, 25, cf. .— Hence, P. a.,  audens, entis, daring, bold, intrepid, courageous; mostly in a good sense : :  so  : :   audentissimi cujusque procursu.  — Adv.: audenter, boldly, fearlessly, rashly: liceat audenter dicere, — Vulg Act. 2, 29; —Comp.:  progressus, : : : .—Sup prob not in use.— ausus, a, um, ventured, attempted, undertaken, hence subst.: au-sum, i, n., a daring attempt, a venture, an undertaking, enterprise :  : :    9, 621; 10, 460; 11, 242;  : .

verbParts: , īvi or ii, itum, 4, v. a.
fullText: , īvi or ii, itum, 4, v. a. (cf. the Lacon.  =  auris; Lith. ausis; Goth. auso; Germ. Ohr, and Engl ears   the Fr. ouïr, and Lat. ausculto; Curtius also compares the Gr. , to hear, perceive, and the Sanscr. av, to notice, to favor; v. ausculto, 1. aveo init., and cf.  Müll.], to hear, to perceive or understand by hearing, to learn .  In gen.  Aliquid: :  : : : : : :    : : : : :  : ait se omnia audivisse, Titinn. ap. : : : : : : :  : clangorem tubae, ib: :   persaep.  Constr., the person from whom one hears or learns any thing, with ex , ab, de, acc. and part., acc. and inf., cum or dum.  With ex:  so     : : :  so  . saepe audivi ex majoribus natu mirari solitum C. Fabricium etc.,  so .— With ab: .— With de:  so  .— With acc. and part. pres. (cf. Zumpt, Gr. §  so    — () With acc. and inf.: : :  : :   : : . —Hence also pass. with nom. and inf. (cf. Zumpt, Gr. §  so .—（) With cum or dum (cf. Zumpt, Gr. § :  so     : . —Diff. from the preced. constr. with de is audire de aliquo ; more freq. in pass. sense, to hear any thing concerning any one: :  so   cf.: — In conversation.  Audi, as a call to gain attention, hear, attend, give ear, listen, = hoc age: : : : Hoc audi, id. And.  3, 4, 11; : .— Audis or audin = audisne? do you hear? atque audin? :  : :  : : .— Audito, with a clause for its subject, as abl. absol. in the histt., upon the receipt of the news that, at the tidings that: audito, Q. Marcium in Ciliciam tendere, when news came that Q. Marcius etc., Sall. H. Fragm. ap.  P.: : .— Esp.,  In a pregnant signif., to listen to a person or thing, to give ear to, hearken to, attend:  so :   :        — Aliquem, of pupils, to hear a teacher, i. e. to receive instruction from, to study under: :  so   :  —Absol.: possumne aliquid audire? tu vero, inquam, vel audire vel dicere, : .— De aliquā re or aliquid, aliquem, of judges, to listen or hearken to, to examine: :  —Trop.: : :  so         et saep.— Of prayer or entreaty, to hear, listen to, lend an ear to, regard, grant: : : : : : : :  : —Also aliquem, to hear one, to grant his desire or prayer:  so  :  :  : .— Aliquem, aliquid, or absol. audio, to hear a person or thing with approbation, to assent to, agree with, approve, grant, allow: :    : audio :   : .— To hear, to listen to, to obey, heed; orig. and class. only with acc., but also with dat.— With acc.:  : : :   : —Poet.  transf. to inanimate things:  so : :  so    . —; With dat.: nam istis qui linguam avium intellegunt, magis audiendum censeo, Pac. ap. :  so, dicto audientem esse, to listen to one's word, to be obedient to one's word, to obey :    : ' sunt illi quidem dicto audientes, : .—And, on account of the signif. to obey, with a second personal dat.: dicto audientem esse alicui, to obey one ; cf. : si habes, qui te audiat;  . 12; 2, 5, 32; :   :    .— To hear thus and thus, i. e. to be named or styled somehow ; and with bene or male , to be in good or bad repute, to be praised or blamed, to have a good or bad character: : :  so       : —In a play upon words: erat surdaster M. Crassus;  so, .— As it were to hear, to hear mentally, i. e. to understand, to supply, something : cum subtractum verbum aliquod satis ex ceteris intellegitur, ut, stupere gaudio Graecus. Simul enim auditur coepit, is understood, is to be supplied,  .—Hence, audĭens, entis, P. a. subst. A hearer, auditor ' ad animos audientium permovendos,  : —Hence, in eccl. Lat., a catechumen, .— With the gen.: tibi servio atque audiens sum imperii, a hearer of, i. e. obedient to, your command, .

, abstŭli, ablātum, auferre, v. a. , to take or bear off or  away, to carry off, withdraw, remove .  In gen.  Lit.: : : : : : : :    3, 717; 5, 205; 5, 725; 6, 622; Turp. ap. : : : .—So of sick persons, or those unable to walk:  (cf. : . —Auferre se, in colloquial lang., to remove one's self, to withdraw, retire, go away: : .—  Of bodies that are borne away by wings, by the winds, waves, or any other quick motion, to bear or carry away, sweep away, etc. : : : :  al.:  : : : : .— Trop., to carry away, mislead: : : :  Jan: : : .— Esp.,  To take or snatch away; in a good, but more frequently in a bad sense, to take by force, to remove, withdraw, take away violently, rob, steal, etc.: : :  so, : : : : : : : : : : : : : :  and so : : :  : : —  To take off or away, to destroy, consume, kill, slay, etc. : :  so  :  : :  :  .— Of places, to separate, sever, divide: : . — To lay aside some action, manner of  speaking, etc.; to cease from, desist from, leave off: proinde istaec tua aufer terricula, Att. ap. : :  : : Ge. Id nosmet ipsos facere oportet, Phaedria. Ph. Aufer mi "oportet:" quin tu, quod faciam, impera,  Ruhnk. : :  so absol.: Insanis? Aufer! away! , .—With inf. as object: .— Meton., effect for cause, to corry off , to obtain, get, receive, acquire:       : : paucos dies ab aliquo, to obtain a few days' respite, :  so, : , A: : . —Also with ut: ut in foro statuerent , abstulisti, you have carried the point that they etc., .—Trop., to carry away the knowledge of a thing, to learn, understand: quis est in populo Romano, qui hoc non ex priore actione abstulerit? has not learned, does not know, Cic Verr. 2, 1, 8.

, fūgi, 3, v. n. , to flee or run away, to flee from (very rare, but class.; not used by Catull., Tib., Lucr., Verg., Hor., or Ovid, nor by Sall., and used only twice in Cic. Oratt., and once in Tac.; :   :  : : :  so : :  B. and K: : : Aufugit mihi animus, Q. Cat. ap. .

, auxi, auctum, 2, v. a. and n. .  Act., to increase, to nourish .  To increase, enlarge, augment, strengthen, advance that which is already in existence : Quicquid est hoc, omnia animat, format, alit, auget, Pac. ap. : :    :   so, : : : : : :  so : : : : : : , and : :  : : :  vitium ventris, : : : : animum alicujus, to increase one's courage,  so, :  ' hostias, to increase, multiply, : —Poet.: .— Trop., to magnify, to exalt, to extol, embellish, to praise (syn.: :  so, : — Aliquem aliquā re, to furaish abundantly with something, to heap upon, give to, to enrich, endow, bless, load with: lunae pars ignibus aucta, the part that is entirely filled with fire, Lucr 5, 722: 3. 630: Tantā laetitiā auctus sum, ut nil constet, poët, ap.  oaque vos omnia bene juvetis, bonis auctibus auxitis, old form of prayer in : : : : : : :  so :  : augeri damno, to be enriched with a loss , : : : :  et saep.—Also without abl.: , and : :  solum te commendat augetque temporis spatium, honors,  so  .— In the lang. of religion, t. t. , to honor, reverence, worship by offerings: : .— Neutr., to grow, increase, become greater : eo res eorum auxit, Cato ap. : :  (Fragm. Orat. Philipp. contra Lepid. § :  : .—Hence, auctus, a, um,  P. a., enlarged, increased, great, abundant; in posit. only as subst.:  Müll. —Comp.: : :   : .—* Sup.: auctissima basis, Treb. Gall. 18.—Adv. probably not in use, for in  Oud., altius is the correct reading.

, ĕre, v. inch. , to begin to grow, to become greater, to grow, increase ; lit. and trop.: qui rem Romanam Latiumque augescere vultis, Enn. ap, Acron. ad :    5, 251; 5, 334; :   :  : : mihi cotidie augescit magis De filio aegritudo, * : :  : :
, āre, v. a. , to increase: numeros, Enn. ap. .
, āre, v. a. , to increase: thesauros, Firm. Math. 5, 6.

, ātus. 1, v. dep. .  To perform the services or fill the office of an augur, to take auguries, observs and interpret omens, to augur, prophesy, predict :  so  :   : :  .—Transf from the sphere of religion,  Ingen, to predict, forebode, foretell; or of the internal sense , to surmise, conjecture, suppose: : : : Recte auguraris de me nihil a me abesse longius crudelitate, Caes. ap. , A: : : . 95; so, : : .!*? The act. subordinate form auguro, āre . Sacerdotes salutem populi auguranto, .—Trop.: oculis investigans astute augura, look carefully around you like an augur, Plant. Cist. 4, 2, 26.—Pass.: res, locus auguratur, is consecrated by auguries: certaeque res augurantur, Lucius Caesar ap.  P.:  so : augurato , after taking auguries :   dub. Roth.— Hoc conjecturā auguro, Enn. ap. ; so Pac. ap. Non. l. l.; Att. ib.; : .
, āre, v. a. , to render venerable, to glorify: .—P. a.: augustātus, a, um, adj., made venerable, i. e. consecrated: mensa, Jus Pap. ap.  dub.
, ĕre, v. inch. , to become of the color of gold:  Müll.
, āvi, ātum, 1 , v. n. , to be a charioteer or a contender in the chariot-race, to drive a chariot, to contend in the chariot-race.  Lit. (post-Aug.;      53;   .— Trop., to rule, direct: .

, āre, v. a. , to overlay with gold, to gild: a metallorum quoque nominibus solent nasci verba, ut ab auro auro, auras;  P.—As finite verb only in one example in .—But very freq. aurā-tus, a, um, P. a.  Furnished, overlaid, or ornamented with gold, gilded, gilt: auratus aries Colchorum, Enn. ap. : : , and : : : sinus, ornamented with a golden buckle, clasp, pin, etc., : . 448: : stolae, * : —Comp.: — Of gold, golden:  :  cf.: :  — Gold-colored: .—Hence, subst.: aurāta, ae, f. , a fish, the gilt-bream: Sparus aurata, Linn.; . 18; 2, 28;  .
, āre, v. n. , to be affected with the jaundice, to have the jaundice, .

, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to take the auspices.  Lit.  In gen.: :  :    sq. al.— Esp., aliquid or absol., also with inf., to make a beginning, for the sake of a good omen, to begin, enter upon : : : : : .— In gen., to begin, enter upon a thing:  : , prooem. § : .— Trop.: .!*?  Act. access. form auspĭco, āre, to take the auspices: : : : . — Pass.  Abl. absol.: auspĭcātō, after taking the auspices: : :   :     —  auspĭcātus, a, um, part., consecrated by auguries: : : — Acc. to auspicor, II., begun: . — auspĭcātus, a, um, as P. a., fortunate, favorable, lucky, prosperous, auspicious: .— Comp.: : .—Sup.:  : .—Adv.: auspĭcātō, under a good omen, auspiciously: : : .—Comp. auspicatius: : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. .  Lit., to say aye, to affirm ; hence, to assert, aver, say, name (chiefly anteclass.; esp. freq. in Plaut.; syn.: dico, affirmo, confirmo; : factum id esse hic non negat... et deinde facturum autumat, * : flexa non falsa autumare dictio Delphis solet, Pac. ap.  :       5, 2, 8;           : te esse Tiburtem autumant, *  :  Halm.—In pass.: .— Meton., effect for cause, to think, believe: bene quam meritam esse autumas, Dicis male mereri, auct. ap. .

, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to give help or aid, to help, aid, assist, succor .  In gen. , constr. with dat.: :         : nihil Numantinis vires corporis auxiliatae sunt, Auct. ad .— Esp., of the aid of a physician, to aid, to relieve, heal, cure; constr. with dat. or contra: : : .!*?  Act. access. form auxĭlĭo, āre, to give aid, etc.: alicui, Gracch. ap.  P.; cf.  P.— Auxilior in pass. signif.: .

, vexi, vectum, 3, v. a. , to carry off or away, to bear off : Pl. Rogas? Quine eam hinc avexti? La. Non avexi,  : : : : : :  so  : .—With the simple acc.:  Wagn.: .—Pass., to be carried away, to ride away, to depart: :

verbParts: , velli or vulsi, vulsum or volsum, 3, v. a.
fullText: , velli or vulsi, vulsum or volsum, 3, v. a. , to tear off or away, to pull or rend off .  In gen. : : :  so  : : : poma ex arboribus, si cruda sunt, vix avelluntur;  :  : : : : .— Esp.  To take away by force, to tear away: : : :  :   Ellis.— To separate from something by pulling, to part, to remove: : : : : : : se, to tear one's self away, .— And in pass. without the notion of violence, to withdraw:  Tisch.—Trop.: .

, ēre, v. a. , to wish, desire earnestly, to long for, crave : avere nihil aliud est quam cupere, Paul. ex  Müll.: ab ludis animus atque aures avent Avide exspectantes nuntium, Enn. ap. .—Constr. with inf., acc., and absol.  With inf.: : : : : :  : :     : : :   :  .— With acc.:  so  : : ; .—  Absol.: , where Lachm. and Munro read euntīs:  .— Avens = libens, Laev. ap. .—ăventer, adv., eagerly, earnestly ,  v.  and 19.

, ēre, v. n. , to be or fare well; except once in Mamert., used only in the imper. ave, aveto, avete, and inf. avere, as a form of salutation, both at meeting and separating, like salve and .  In gen., Hail! God bless thee, farewell! adieu : Caesar simulatque, Have, mihi dixit, statim exposuit,   i. e. had saluted me, Cael. ap. : : : .—    .—Haveto at the end of a letter, Cato ap.  and Ave at the beginning, August. ap. :  — Esp.  As a morning greeting (diff. from vale, a greeting at separating in the evening; cf. :   fin.; 4, 79, 4; 7, 39, 2.— As a farewell to the dead, = vale: Atque in perpetuom, frater, ave atque vale, *    4735; . And thus the ambiguity of avere in the anecdote in  is to be explained: Emissurus Fucinum lacum naumachiam ante commisit. Sed cum proclamantibus naumachiariis, Ave , Imperator, morituri te salutant: respondisset, Avete vos , neque post hanc vocem, quasi venia data , quisquam dimicare vellet, etc.— As a mere expression of goodwill : .!*? As finite verb: aveo plane Imperator et avebo... cum is avere jubeat, qui jam fecit, ut averem, Mamert. Grat. Act. ad Julian.
, verri, ĕre, v. a., to sweep or brush off or away; hence, in gen., to take away, Licin. Macer. ap.  P.

, āre, v. n., a very ancient word, peculiar to the lang. of religion, to avert, remove: : di averruncent, Att. ap. , A.:  : .—So in the old Optat. form averruncassint = averruncent, Pac. ap.  Müll.; in Paul. ex Fest. s. v. verruncent, p. 373 Müll. ; and in the very ancient inf. fut.: possum ego istam capite cladem averruncassere, Pac. ap. .

, ātus, 1, v. dep. freq. , to turn one's self from, to turn away .  In gen.: nulla vis tormentorum acerrimorum praetermittitur; : — Esp.: aliquem or aliquid, to turn away a person or thing from one's self, to send away, repulse, reject, refuse, decline, shun, avoid:  Drak.: : :  Halm:   : :  Schwarz; so, : : :  Oud.: : : .—With inf.: aversati sunt proelium facere, declined, Auct. B. Hisp. 14.!*? Pass.: .

, ti, sum, 3, v. a., to turn something away from a place, to avert, turn off, remove, etc. .  Lit.  In gen.  Constr. aliquem ab or with the simple abl.; the limit designated by in with acc. : : Jup. Te volo, uxor, conloqui. Quor ted avortisti? Alc. Est ita ingenium meum: :  : :  so : quod iter ab Arari Helvetii averterant,  had turned aside their march from  et saep.: : : : : : se alicui, instead of ab aliquo. .—And poet. with acc.: . —With dat.:  so .—Also without an antecedent ab with in with acc.:  hence absol.: .— Pass. in mid. signif. with the acc., in the Greek manner, to turn away from: :  .— As v. n. avertere = se avertere, to turn one's self away, to retire: : : : : — To take away, drive away, carry off, steal, embezzle, to appropriate to one's self: : : : : : : : : .— Trop.  To turn, divert a person from a course of action, purpose, etc.: : : : : : : .— Aliquem, to turn away from one in feeling, i. e. to make averse or disinclined to, to alienate, estrange: : : : : : .—Hence, āver-sus, a, um, P. a.  Turned off or away: aversum hostem videre nemo potuit, turned away, i. e. turned in flight,  hence, backwards, behind, back , distant: :  : ne aversos nostros aggrederentur, fall upon our troops in the rear, Galba ap. : : : aversi vulnerantur, Auct. B. Alex. 30; :  (cf. : : , and so al.—Trop.: . —Subst.: āversum, i, n., the hinder or back part, the back :  Ruhnk.: : ad aversa insulae, id.   37, 27, 2: : aversa Indiae, the back or remoter parts of India, .—So in adverb. phrase: in aversum, backwards: : . — Disinclined, alienated, unfavorable, opposed, hostile, averse; constr. with ab, with dat., or absol.  With ab : : : :  : .— With dat.: : : .— Absol.: : : :  et saep.: : .—Adv. not used.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to call off or away.  In gen.: : : Consul ab omnibus magistratibus et comitiatum et contionem avocare potest. Messala ap. .—With dat. : nec avocare alius alii posset, si contionem habere volunt, Messala ap. .— Trop.: : : .— Esp.  To call one off from an action, purpose, wish, etc., i. e. to withdraw, divert, turn, remove, separate : : : : :  so :   hos a bello avocas, :  .— To withdraw the attention, to distract, divert.  To withdraw by interrupting, to interrupt, hinder: .— To divert by cheering, to divert, cheer, amuse:  hence, se, to divert, entertain one's self,  and pass. with mid. sense: illic avocare et illic lude, * .— In the Lat. of the jurists = revocare, to reclaim, recall:  so,  also with dat. : .— Trop.: : .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n., to fly forth or away: :  .—Hence, of persons, to flee away, to go away quickly, to hasten away : : : .—So of dying: .—Of the vanishing of pleasure: .

, ātus , 1, v. dep. .  Lit., to celebrate the festival of Bacchus: :  : .—Hence, P. a. as subst.: bacchan-tes, um, f., Bacchae, the Bacchantes: passis Medea capillis Bacchantum ritu, Ov.M. 7, 258; 3, 703;  gen. Bacchantium, .— Pass. of the place in which the orgies of Bacchus were celebrated:  Heyn.: : : ita obsoletum sono furenter ab omni parti bacchatur nemus, Santra ap. : .— Transf., in gen., to revel, rave, rant, like the Bacchœ : :  :  Col. poët. 10, 198; *   .—Of murderous fury: .—So of poet. inspiration,   cf.:  .—Also, to go or run about in a wanton, wild, raving, or furious manner: animans Omne, quod in magnis bacchatur montibu' passim, * : :  .—Hence,  Transf. to inanimate things, to be furious, rage with fury, etc., to be impetuous, etc.  So of a vessel of wine that is filled very often:  Lorenz ad loc.— Of winds:  .—Of violent rain, ,  632.— Of a rumor: concussam bacchatur fama per urbem, spreads rapidly, Verg A. 4, 666.— Of enthusiastic, raging discourse: : .
, āre, v. a. , to carry a burden, to bear something heavy, :    :  Auct. ap.  .— Trop.: .

, īre, v. n. and a. .  Neutr., to stammer, stutter:  : lingua, Cod. 15, 6, 22. —Transf., of birds, not to sing clearly: . — Trop., to speak upon something obscurely, not distinctly or not correctly:  .— Act., to stutter, stammer, or lisp out something: illum Balbutit Scaurum pravis fultum male talis, he, lisping or fondling, calls him Scaurus, .—Trop., as above: .
, āre, v. n. , to dance, .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. , to bleat,    .—Poet.: balantes hostiae = oves, Enn. ap. :  and absol. balans = ovis , :  .—Facetè, to speak of sheep: .— Trop., to talk foolishly: .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., = , only in eccl. Lat., to baptize,    and Tert. Aug. Hier. al. saep.
, īre, 4, v. n. , to raise a beard , .
, īre, v. n , to cry; of elephants. barrire elephantes dicuntur, sicut oves dicimus balare, utique a sono ipso vo cis:  Auct. Carm. Phil. 53; cf. Paul. ex Fest p. 30 Müll.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to kiss, to give a kiss (poet. and rare; most freq. in Cat.;    sq.;     .

, ui, ĕre, v. a. and n. , to strike, beat, hit : battuit , Gloss.; Naev. ap.  * .—Of bruising in a mortar, Marc. Emp. Medic. c. 36.—Of pounding flesh before cooking it,  cf. .— Neutr., of fencing : battuebat pugnatoriis armis, he fenced with sharp weapons ,  .—In mal. part., .
, āri, v. dep.  of dogs, to bark gently or moderately : et quom desertei baubantur in aedibus.  v. the context, and Munro ad loc.
, āre, v. a. , to make happy, to bless ,   .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to wage or carry on war, to fight : nec cauponantes bellum, sed belligerantes, Enn. ap. ; Poët. ap. :  : excitandus nobis erit ab inferis quoniam nobis non solum cum his... sed etiam cum fortunā belligerandum fuit, * : :    .— Trop.: : .

, āvi, ātum, āre, 1, v. n. .  Prop., to wage or carry on war, to war, to fight in war .  Absol.:   :   : : :    : : .— With prepp.  With cum: : :      .—  With adversum or adversus: : .— With contra: .— With de: .— With pro: .— With inter se, .— With dat. :  cf. .— Impers. pass.:  : .— With acc. : . — Transf., poet., in gen., to fight, contend: .—Esp., with abl. of weapon, etc. : : :   cf. bellor

, xi, ctum, ĕre, v. n. and a., to speak well of any one, to commend, praise.  In gen., in class. Lat. always as two words, v. bene, I. B. 1.— Esp.  In late and eccl. Lat. with acc.  Deum, to bless, praise, or adore , App. Trism. fin.; .—Pass.: : Deus benedicendus, App. Trism. fin.;  .— Rarely with dat.: — Of men and things, to bless, consecrate, hallow ' requievit die septimo eumque benedixit,  cf.  : altarium, Sulp. de Vita S. Martini, 2, 2: benedictum oleum, Hier. Vit. Hilar. med.:  Grut. 875, 3 al.—Sometimes with dat.:  .—  Herba benedicta, the plant also called lagopus or leporinus pes, .—  Hence,  bĕnĕdictum, i, n. , v bene, I. B. 1. g.— bĕnĕ-dictus, i, m., an approved person, blessed one :
, fēci, factum, 3, v. n., better written as two words, v. bene, I. B. 2.

, ŭi, ĭtum, 2, v. n., to  please: .—Hence, P. a.: bĕnēplăcĭtus, a, um, pleasing, acceptable,  Ambros. lsaac et An. 7, 57 init.—As subst.: bĕnē-plăcĭtum, i, n., good pleasure, gracious purpose,  et saep.
, āri, 1, v. dep. , to rejoice, take delight :  Esd. 4, 39.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make happy, to bless .  In gen., to gladden, rejoice, refresh: : : .—Hence, in colloq. lang. beas or beasti, that delights me, I am rejoiced at  that,  .—  Aliquem aliquā re, to make happy, reward with, enrich: : : : .—Hence, bĕātus, a, um, P. a.  Happy, prosperous, blessed, fortunate (very freq. in prose and poetry; cf.: : : :  Afran. ap. : : : .— Transf.: .— Subst.  bĕāti, ōrum, m., the happy, fortunate persons: : .— bĕātum, i, n. , happiness, blessedness: : .— Esp.  Of outward prosperity, opulent, wealthy, rich, in good circumstances: :  :     3, 16, 32; 3, 29, 11; -8, 1;  .— As subst.: bĕāti, ōrum, m., the rich: .— Poet., of inanimate things, rich, abundant, excellent, splendid, magnificent: : : : : .—With abl., :  : argentum felix omnique beatius auro, Ov P 2, 8, 5.— Trop.: : : .— Late Lat., blessed, i. e. deceased, dead: :  cf.: si nobis, cum ex hac vitā emigraverimus, in beatorum insulis inmortale aevum, ut fabulae ferunt, degere liceret, Cic. ap. .— Beatissimus, in late Lat., a title of the higher clergy, Cod. 1, 4, 13; Auct. Collat. 9, 6; Novell. 123, 3 al. —Hence, adv.: bĕātē, happily, :     .—Comp., .—Sup., .
, ĕre, v. n. , to go : in pugnam baetite, Pac. ap. :  : .

, bĭbi , 3, v. a. , to drink .  With acc.  Of the liquid drunk: : : : eapse merum condidicit bibere; : : : : : : : : :   .—Also nutricem bibere , .—Poet.; : .— Pocula or cyathos bibere.  Poet., = vinum : : :  so, .— Of the number of cups drunk at a merry-making: vide quot cyathos bibimus: St. Tot quot digiti sunt tibi in manu, .—Esp. of the custom of drinking names, i. e. as many cups as there are letters in a name proposed; the number is frequently expressed by fractional parts of the as could demand unconditional submission to the drinking laws (), .
, ĕre, v. n. , to make a noise like that of a liquid agitated in a vessel: bilbit factum est a similitudine sonitus, qui fit in vase. Naevius Bilbit amphora inquit, Paul. ex  Müll. : bilbit , Gloss.

, no perf., ītum, 4, v. a. , to divide into two parts, to bisect : ver bipartitur, is divided ,  so,  Schneid. N. cr.—Mostly part. pass.:  Müll.: : : .—Hence, bĭpartītō , adv., in two parts or divisions, in two ways:  : signa inferre, to attack in two parties or divisions,  Oud. N. cr.: : : .—With esse or fieri :  B. and K.: .
, āre, 1, v. a. , to cover or impregnate with bitumen , Ambros. Hexaëm. 6, 9, 72; cf.: bitumino, , Gloss. Lab.—Hence, P. a.: bĭtū-mĭnătus, a, um, impregnated with bitumen, bituminous: .
, āre, v. n. , to bleat, of the ram, Auct. Carm. Philom. 56.

, ītus, 4, v. dep. .  Prop., lit., to cling caressingly to one, to fawn upon, to flatter, soothe, caress, fondle, coax .  With dat.: .— With inter se, .— With ut and subj.: .— Absol.: : : .— Transf.  In gen., to flatter, make flattering, courteous speeches, be complaisant to.  With dat.: : : : :   .— Absol.: : : : : qui cum dolet blanditur, post tempus sapit, Publ. Syr. v. 506 Rib.— With per: , 2.—  With abl.: .— In partic.  Blandiri sibi, etc., to flatter one's self with something, to fancy something, delude one's self: .—So often in Dig. et Codd.; cf.: .— Pregn., to persuade or impel by flattery .  With subj.:  Lachm.— With ab and ad: — Trop.  Of inanim. things as subjects, to flatter, please, be agreeable or favorable to; to allure by pleasure, to attract, entice, invite.  With dat.: : . — Absol.: :   .— With abl.: opportuna suā blanditur populus umbrā, Ov M. 10, 555.— Of things as objects: : .—Hence,  Subst.: blandĭens, entis, m., a flatterer: .— blandītus, a, um, P. a., pleasant, agreeable, charming : , 6, 72: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  To talk idly or foolishly, to babble, prate , Pac. ap.  Afran. ap. :  Plaut. ap. : desine blaterare, Caecil. ap. : cum magno blateras clamore, furisque, *  :  so  .— Of the sounds of frogs, Siā   Ep. 2, 2 med.; and of camels, acc. to Paul. ex  Müll.
, īre, v. a. , to utter foolish things, to babble, prate :  so    cf.
, āre, v. n. , to buzz, hum; of bees , Auct. Carm. Phil. 36;  Eyssenh.
, āre or ĕre, v. n. , to cry aloud, roar .  Bŏvo, āre: clamore bovantes, Enn. ap. . 1. .— Bŏo, ĕre: clamore et sonitu colles resonantes bount, Pac. ap. . 1. .—  Bŏo, āre :   .
, īre, 4, v. n., to swarm: .
, āri, v. dep. , to bellow at, brawl, revile: bovinatur = conviciatur, Paul. ex  Müll.: bovinator = conviciator, inconstans. Bovinari = conviciari, damnare, clamare, Vocab. Vet.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to shorten, abbreviate, abridge,  brevio, Gloss. Vet. ;  : :  Spald. N. cr.:  Sev. : : : .— Transf.: .
, ĕre, v. inch. , to become brutish, rough, unreasonable ,   Ven. Ep. praef. carm. 6, 5.
, ĕre, v. n., to cry like a bittern, Auct. Carm. Philom. 42 .
, āre, v. n. , to be a herdsman, to keep, feed, or drive oxen .  Lit.:  App. Flor. n. 6, p. 343, 14.— Trop., to cry or bawl like an ox-driver, Varr. ap. .
, āre, v. n. , to cry, hoot, or screech like an owl, Auct. Carm. Phil. 37.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. , to blow the bucina, to sound or give a signal with the trumpet : : : , 4:  cf. bucina, II. C.
, āre, āvi, ātum (), 1, v. n., to have bulimy or insatiable hunger, Pelag. Vet. 10; .
, ĕre, 3, v. inch. n. , to bubble, form bubbles, .

verbParts: , āre, and bullĭo, īvi, ītum, 4, v. n.
fullText: , āre, and bullĭo, īvi, ītum, 4, v. n. , to be in bubbling motion, to be in a state of ebullition, to bubble.  Form bullo, āre:      ,  74, § 317.— Form bullio, īre:     .—As v. a. in part. pass.: ammoniacum cum vino et melle mittis in ollam et bullita atteres, dabisque ad bibendum, .— Trop.: : .
, āre, v. n., to cackle; Gr. , as the natural cry of the partridge: cacabat hinc perdix, Carm. Philom. 19
, īre, v. n. desid. , to desire to go to stool, .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. , to laugh aloud, laugh immoderately.  Lit. :   : ridere convivae;   .—With the acc. of that which one laughs at: .—*  Poet. of the sea, to plash, ripple, roar: suavisona echo crepitu clangente cachinnat, Att. ap. .

, cĕcĭdi, cāsum, 3 , v. n. .  Lit.  In an extended sense, to be driven or carried by one's weight from a higher to a lower point, to fall down, be precipitated, sink down, go down, sink, fall (so mostly poet.; in prose, in place of it, the compounds decĭdo, occĭdo, excĭdo, etc.; cf. also ruo, labor; : praecipites cadunt in terram aut in aquam, fall headlong to the earth or into the water,  cf.  : :  so with in,    6, 1125; , 4, 64: .—With a different meaning:  cf.: : : .—Less freq. with ad: : .—The place from which is designated by ab, ex, de: : : : :   : : :  cf.: : :  : .—With per: : :  cf.: .—With the adverb altius: altius atque cadant summotis nubibus imbres, and poured forth from a greater height, etc., .—And absol.:   : :  : : quaeque ita concus   sa est, ut jam casura putetur, : : : .— Esp.  Of heavenly bodies, to decline, set , :   :  cf. : : .— To separate from something by falling, to fall off or away, fall out, to drop off, be shed, etc.: :   : : :  cf.  : : : : : : : .— Of a stream, to fall, empty itself:   : : : .— Of dice, to be thrown or cast; to turn up:  .— Alicui ad pedes, to fall at one's feet in supplication, etc. ,    — Super collum allcujus, to embrace , .— In a more restricted sense.  To fall, to fall down, drop, fall to, be precipitated, etc.; to sink down, to sink, settle : : : :  cf.  : : : : : : : :  : : languescunt omnia membra;   so, :  cf.: : : :   cf. II. F. infra.— In a pregn. signif. , to fall so as to be unable to rise, to fall dead, to fall, die , , 28, 42 (usu. of those who die in battle; :   : :  :  so         and 19; 21, 7, 10; 23, 21, 7; 29, 14, 8;   : : : : : .—Not in battle: .—With abl. of means or instrument:  cf. : : : :  cecidere justā Morte Centauri, cecidit tremendae Flamma Chimaerae, : : .—With abl. of agent with ab:  so  : .—And without ab:  imitated by Claudian, IV. Cons. Hon. 89; .—  Of victims, to be slain or offered, to be sacrificed, to fall : :      .— In mal. part., = succumbo, to yield to,   .— Matre cadens, just born ,  cf. of the custom of laying the new-born child at the father's feet: tellure cadens.  . Trop.  To come or fall under, to fall, to be subject or exposed to something ; constr. usually with sub or in, sometimes with ad: : : in cernendi sensum. : : : :  so : :  so, : : : : : : : : : : .—  In gen.: in or sub aliquem or aliquid, to belong to any object, to be in accordance with, agree with, refer to, be suitable to, to fit, suit, become : :  so  : : :  57, 191; 27, 95;     6, prooem. § 5; 7, 2, 30 and 31; :       6, 3, 52; 7, 2, 31; 9, 1, 7; :  .— To fall upon a definite time : : .—Hence, in mercantile lang., of payments, to fall due: in eam diem cadere nummos, qui a Quinto debentur, .— Alicui, to fall to one , fall to one's lot, happen to one, befall; and absol. , to happen, come to pass, occur, result, turn out, fall out .  Alicui: :  :   : : : : : : verba cadentia,  uttered at random, .— Ab sol., Afran. ap.  P.; : : :   Cael. ap.   ,  Dähne:    38, 46, 6;     : : .—With adj.: : .— With in and acc.: nimia illa libertas et populis et privatis in nimiam servitutem cadit , .—Esp.: in irritum or cassum, to be frustrated, fail, be or remain fruitless:  :  so :  cf. with irritus, adj.: : .— To fall, to become less , to decrease, diminish, lessen: : .—More freq. in an extended signif. ,  To lose all one's strength, worth, value, etc., to fall, to perish, vanish, decay, cease.  In gen.: pellis item cecidit, vestis contempta ferina. declined in value, :  so : : : :  : :   cf. : :  cf. .—Esp., to fail in speaking: :  —So in the lang. of the jurists, causā or formulā, to lose one's cause or suit:  so     :  .—With in: .—Also absol.:  and: : : : ; cf.: :  —Hence of theatrical representations, to fall through, to fail, be condemned (opp. stare, to win applause; .—Impers.. periculum est, ne cadatur, .— Esp. of the wind , to abate, subside, die away, etc.: : : : :  cf.: :   Serv. and Wagn.— Rhet. and gram. t. t. of words, syllables, clauses, etc., to be terminated, end, close:  : qua nullum Graece verbum cadit, :  so : : :  Spald.: similiter cadentia = , the ending of words with the same cases or verbal forms, diff. from similiter desinentia = , similar endings of any kind,     cf.    1, 7, 23; Aquil. Rom. Figur. §§ 25 and 26.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make blind, to blind.  Lit.: ;  : .—Hence, in gardening:   cf. caecus, I. C., and oculus.—  Trop.: : : : : : : : .— Transf., to make dark, to obscure: .— Trop., of   discourse: .
, āre, v. n. , to be like one blind, to be dim-sighted: caecultare est caecos imitari, Paul. ex  Müll.: caeculto , Gloss.; Plautus: numnam mihi oculi caecultant? Paul. ex  Müll.; cf. caecutio.

, cĕcīdi , caesum, 3, v. a. .  Lit.  In gen.  To cut, hew, lop, cut down, fell, cut off, cut to pieces: caesa abiegna trabes, Enn. ap. : :  :  : . 63: silvam, Varr ap.      :  cf.  9, 230; 9, 374; : : : : :  so, , prooem. § : : : : caedunt securibus umida vina, with axes they cut out the wine , : volutas, to carve or hollow out volutes, : tineae omnia caedunt, Lucil. ap. .— Prov.: .—  Ruta caesa; v ruo, P. a.— In gen., to strike upon something, to knock at, to beat, strike, cudgel, etc.: : : : :  cf. :  so : ,   43: :  cf. :  : : : :    :  Dietsch: : : .— Prov.: .—  Trop.: .—  Pregn. To strike mortally, to kill, murder: :  :    12, 590; 12, 603;  —Poet., transf. to the blood shed in slaying: .—Esp. freq.,  In milit. lang., to slay a single enemy; or, when a hostile army as a whole is spoken of, to conquer with great slaughter, to cut to pieces, vanquish, destroy : :  :   and 9;    : : : : :  Kreyss.: :  so   .— And poet., the leader is put for the army: .—In poet. hypallage: .— To slaughter animals, esp. for offerings, to kill, slay, sacrifice: : : :               Ov.M.13, 637;    12, 3 al.: inter caesa et porrecta; v. porricio.— Hence, since security for a person was anciently given by the deposit of sheep belonging to him, which were slaughtered in case of forfeiture, leg. t. t.: pignus caedere , to declare the for feiture of a security, to confiscate a pledge: non tibi illa sunt caedenda, si L. Crassum vis coërcere, Crass. ap. .— In mal. part. ;   .— Trop.: caedere sermones, a Grecism, acc. to  P., = , to chop words, chat, talk, converse,  cf. , and  P.:  Aquil. Rom. §§ 18 and 19;  .—Hence, caesum, i, n.; subst. in gram. synon. with comma, a stop, pause, comma,  Aquil. Rom. § 19; .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  Lit., answering to the Gr. , to engrave in relief upon metals or wory, to make raised work, to carve, engrave; later also, to cast ' ab initio sic opus ducere, ut caelandum, non ex integro fabricandum sit, : : : :  cf.  13, 684: scuta auro, argento, Liv 9, 40, 2; :    : libidines in poculis, id. prooem. § 4 al.;     : : .— To carve or engrave on other materials ;   cf.:  .— Meton. of other works of art.  Of skilful weaving or embroidering: .— Of poetry: carmina compono, hio elegos. Mirabile  visu Caelatumque novem musis opus, * .— Trop.: .
, āre, v. a., to beat, cudgel, Fulg. Cont. Virg.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to furnish with shoes, to put on shoes, to shoe : calceati et vestiti, *  : : : calceandi pedes, *  : : calceabat ipse sese,  — Of animals : : : : .—  Trop.: : .

, āre, v. n. .  Lit., to strike with the heels, to kick, of animals ,  cf. calcitratus.— Trop, to resist, to be stubborn or refractory: calcitrat, respuit, * .— Prov.:    cf. 1. calx. —* In gen., to strike convulsively with the feet, of one dying, Ov M. 12, 240.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to tread something or upon something, to tread under foot.  In gen.  Lit. To tread down, to oppress, trample upon :  cf. : : : .—  To scorn, contemn, spurn, despise, abuse: : : .— Esp. , āre, v. a. , to calculate, compute, reckon .  Lit., Prud. . 3, 131.— Trop., to consider as, to esteem, .

verbParts: , or contr. calfăcĭo , fēci, factum, 3, v. a.
fullText: , or contr. calfăcĭo , fēci, factum, 3, v. a. .  Lit., to make warm or hot, to warm, heat: ventus ubi percaluit calefecitque omnia, *: : : .—Pass.:  Müll.: : : : : : : .— Trop.  In colloquial lang., to trouble, vex: : si Parthi vos nihil calfaciunt, nos hic frigore frigescimus, Cael. ap. : .— Poet., of the passions, to heat, to rouse up, excite:  : .— To pursue something with zeal:  Ruhnk.

, ui, 2, v. n. , to be warm or hot, to glow .  Lit.: calet aqua; : : : : : : : : : : : .—Poet. sometimes for aestuare, subject., to feel warm: : :  cf.: caluit et hodie Faustina, Aur. ap. .— Trop.  To glow in mind, to be roused, warmed, inflamed   (class.;  cf.  Hirt. ap. : : : : : :  cf.: : :  : :  also, to be troubled, perplexed: haec velim explices;  Cael. ap. : alio mentis morbo, to labor under ,  :  .— With inf.:   .—  With ad: , 3, 62.— Of abstract things, to be carried on warmly, to be urged on zealously: : : : : : .— To be yet warm, new, or fresh : : illi rumores de comitiis caluerunt, Cael. ap. .— Of a place, to be eagerly sought, to be frequented : .
, ĕre, v. inch. n. , to grow warm or hot.  Lit. : :  :  .— Trop., of the mind, to become excited, to glow, be inflamed; esp. with love ,  Don.:  so : .

, āre, v. n. .  To emit vapor or steam, to steam, reek: : ; cf.: .— Transf.  To be involved in darkness, to be dark, gloomy:   . — Poet.: .— Trop., of the understanding, to be blind, to be surrounded by darkness, to grope about: : :   : .—Prov.: .— In medic. lang., of the eyes, to suffer from weakness, be weak,   cf. .—Transf., of the person, to be dim-sighted:  .

, ēre, v. n. and a. .  Neutr.  Lit., to be callous, to be thickskinned :  Caecil. ap. :  .— Trop. *  To be hardened, insensible, unfeeling: in illis rebus exercitatus animus callere jam debet atque omnia minoris existimare, Serv. Sulp. ap.  cf. callisco.— To be practised, to be wise by experience, to be skilful, versed in; in a pun on the literal sense A. supra:  cf.  v. 1; so : ; : melius quam viri callent mulieres, Att. ap. :  p. 258, 6 : : :   : : arte, Ser. ap.  : : fidibus, App. Flor. n. 18.— Act., to know by experience or practice, to know, have the knowledge of, understand (freq., esp. in the poets;  cf.  : : : istaec malitiosa non tam calleo, Afran. ap. : :  : : :  — With inf. as object: multaque de rerum mixturā dicere callent, *    .—  With acc. and inf.: quem Marcellini consiliarium fuisse callebant, Sisenn. ap. .— With rel.-clause: .—Hence, callens, entis, P. a., acquainted with, versed in, skilful, expert : : : .—* Adv.: callenter, skilfully, cunningly; for the class. callide, .
, ĕre, v. inch. , to become dull, insensible: aures nobis calliscerunt ad injurias, Cato ap. .

, āre, v. a. , to call, call out, proclaim, call together, summon, convoke; only as t. t. in reference to religious matters; v. Kalendae, and the ancient formulary in  Müll.; cf. : calata comitia, a kind of comitia held for the purpose of consecrating a priest or a king. Of these, some were curiata, others centuriata, Laelius Felix ap. :  .—Hence, sarcastically, on account of bribery, calatis granis ,  Orell.

, ātus, 1, v. dep. act. .  Jurid. t. t.  To accuse falsely, bring false information against a person.  Absol.:  cf. : : : : : : : : .— With acc.: : .— To practise chicanery, trickery, or subterfuge: : .— In gen., to depreciate, misrepresent, calumniate, to blame unjustly.  With personal object:  cf.: : , 3, 23.—With dat. : .— Esp., with se, to depreciate one's self, be unduly anxious or careful: , proocm. § .— Absol.: sed calumniabar ipse;  cf. A. 2. supra.— With things as objects, to misrepresent, interpret injuriously, set in a false light: non calumniatur verba nec voltus; : : : : .
, ēre, v. n. , to be bald, .
, ĕre, v. inch. n. , to become bald ,   .— Transf. to plants, to grow up thin or far apart, .

, 3, v. dep. a. .  To devise tricks, use artifice, attack one with artifice, to intrigue against, to deceive : SI. CALVITVR. PEDEMVE. STRVIT., Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. Fest. s. v. struere, p. 313 Müll.; the same law is fragmentarily mentioned by Lucil. ap. , and .— In gen., to deceive, delude: me calvitur suspitio, Pac. ap. : calamitas arvas calvitur, Pac. ap. ; : sed memet calvor, Att. ap. .!*? Pass. : te vocis calvi similitudine, Pac. ap.   Dietsch, and  P.
, īre, v. n. , to exchange, barter: muto, , Charis. l.l. ,  Sicul. Flacc. Cond. Agr. p. 13 Goes.
, āre, v. a. , to vault or arch over, . —Trop.: .
, no perf., ātum, 1, v. a. , to make like an oven or furnace (very rare; : .
, āre, v. a. , to turn around a place, to sail by, to double: Leucatam, Enn. ap.  P. .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  In gen., to make like a lattice, to lattice: :  cf. . — Esp., in the Lat. of the jurists, to strike out a writing lattice-wise (), to strike or cross out, to cancel: : :    Cod. 6, 33, 3.
, āvi, 3, v. inch. n. , to become cancerous, be afflicted with a cancer, to suppurate like a cancer ,   .—Hence, cancĕrātus, a, um, cancerous: : .
, fēci, factum, 3, v. a. . To make dazzlingly white :   cf. atramentum.— To make glowing, to make red hot : :   .

, ui, 2, v. n. , to be brilliant, glittering, to shine, glitter, glisten .  Lit.  Verb finit.: : : . — Part. and P. a.: candens, entis, = candidus, shining. dazzling, white, bright, glowing: : : : : : : .—Comp.: .—Sup.: .— Esp., = albus, white: : : : : : : : : : :  al.— Transf., to glow with heat, be glowing hot .  Verb finit.:  .— Part. and P. a.:  imitated by : candenti ferro, Varr. R. R. Fragm. ap.  P.: : ; : . — Trop., glowing with passion, excited : : .
, ui, 3, v. inch. n. , to become of a bright, glittering white, to begin to glisten or radiate :  .— To begin to glow, to grow red hot:    fin; cf. candeo fin.
, āre, v. n. , to be whitish or white ,       : , praef. § : : :  Jan. dub.; cf. Sillig ad loc.
, āvi, 1, v. a. , to make glittering or bright, to make white : : .—P. a.: candĭdans, antis, brilliantly white,  cf. 1. candidatus, I. A.
, āre, v. a. , to make dazzlingly white, Aug. Civ. Dei, 21, 7.
, ui, 2, v. n. , to be gray or hoary, be white ; P. a.: cānens, entis, gray, grayish, hoary, white:  cf. : : :   : :  : ; .

. ĕre, v. inch. n. . to grow white, whiten.  Lit., to become gray or hoary:  : :  :  : in cujus aede ignes numquam canescunt  in favillas, .— Transf., = senescere, to grow old, : .—Trop., of discourse:  cf.  .

, cĕcĭni, cantum , 3, v. n. and a. , orig. v. n., to produce melodious sounds, whether of men or animals; later, with a designation of the subject-matter of the melody, as v. a., to make something the subject of one's singing or playing, to sing of, to celebrate, or make known in song, etc.  Neutr., to utter melodious notes, to sing, sound, play.  Of men:  : :    :  cf.:    : :  : :  :   .— Of the faulty delivery of an orator, to speak in a sing-song tone:  cf. canto and canticum.— Of animals ,  Müll.:  :  : .—Of the raven, .—Esp., of the crowing of a cock:  v. the whole section; , § 57; ,  2, 11; : .— .— Transf., of the instruments by which, or of the places in which, the sounds are produced, to sound, resound: : , 11, 9:  . Act., to make something or some person the subject of one's singing or playing.  With carmen, cantilenam, versus, verba, etc., to sing, play, rehearse, recite: : : :   : canere versus, Enn. ap.  Müll. ;  : : idyllia , : :  Spald.—The homog. noun is rarely made the subject of the act. voice: .— Prov.  Carmen intus canere, to sing for one's self, i. e. to consult only one's own advantage,   v. Aspendius.—  Cantilenam eandem canis, like the Gr. , ever the old tune,  v. cantilena.— With definite objects.  In gen., to sing, to cause to resound, to celebrate in song, to sing of, :  Müll.:    : : : , ext. 8.—So with de: : :  Wagn. N. cr.: : :  :   cf. :  Wagn.: et veterem in limo ranae cecinere querelam, croaked ,  : : : .— With pers. objects : : : : : :   : : : .—Very rarely, to celebrate, without reference to song or poetry: .—Esp. of fame, to trumpet abroad: : —And prov., to sing or preach to the deaf: : praeceptorum, quae vereor ne vana surdis auribus cecinerim. .— Since the responses of oracles were given in verse, to prophesy, foretell, predict.  In poetry:  cf.: . 99; 3,   444:  cf.    cf.   :  .— In prose: : :     :   sq.; 1, 7, 10;   cf.  cf.  Orell. ad loc.; cf.: . In milit. lang., t. t., both act. and neutr., of signals, to blow, to sound, to give; or to be sounded, resound.  Act.:  : .—Absol. without signum, etc.: tubicen canere coepit, Auct. B. Afr. 82; cf. .— Neutr.: :  and 5; 23, 16, 12;    : .— Receptui canere, to sound a retreat:  .—Poet.: .—And in Livy impers.: : .—  Trop.: : : .!*? Examples for the signif. to practice magic, to charm, etc., found in the derivv. cantus, canto, etc., are entirely wanting in this verb.
, āre, v. a. , to  put into the list or catalogue of saints, to canonize, Alex. III. P.P. Ep. 3.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. and a. , freq. in form, but mostly agrees in meaning with cano.  Neutr., to produce melodious sounds , to sound, sing, play .  Of men: : : :  :  : :  : non est Cantandum, there is no occasion for singing, i. e. for imagination, fiction, .—Of an actor:    cf. : : .—Less freq. of instrumental music, and only with abl. of the instrument :   praef. § 1; : : : ad manum histrioni, in comedy, to sing and play while the actor accompanies the song with gestures or dancing,  cf. .—Pass. impers.: .—Prov.: , 8, 47, and ad surdas aures, , to preach to deaf ears; cf. cano, II. B.— Of the singing pronunciation of an orator, to declaim in a singing tone, to sing, drawl: si cantas, male cantas, si legis, cantas, C. Caesar ap.    11, 3, 58; 11, 3, 59; 11, 3, 60; cf. .—Hence, to recite, declaim: .— Of birds and fowls:  so, : , 9, 30.— Transf., of instruments, to sound, resound: , 10, 30: — Act., to make some person or thing the subject of one's singing, playing, or song .  With the song itself, carmen, versus,  etc., as object, to sing, play, recite: : :  cf.: : .— With particular persons or things, the subjects of song, as objects, to sing, to celebrate or praise in song, sing of, write poetry upon, etc.: : : : : : : :   cf.: : : . —Esp.,  Of an actor, to represent a part, to act : : : :  fin.:  fin.— Hence, because the oracles were of old uttered in verse, of any mysterious, prophetic, or warning utterance, to predict, warn, point out, indicate, make known, say: . —Of inanimate things: :  .— To bring something repeatedly to recollection, to reiterate, harp upon, forewarn of or against: : : , 1: : .— In the lang. of religion, as v. n. or a., to use enchantments, charms, incantations, to enchant, to charm,  : : , 5, 13: : : : .— To call forth, produce by charms: : .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. and n. .  Act., to wrinkle, to draw together in wrinkles: : frons caperata, Pac. ap. : : vela, furled, id. Flor. n. 23.— Neutr., to be wrinkled, .

, cēpi, captum , 3, v. a. .  Lit.  In gen., to take in hand, take hold of, lay hold of, take, seize, grasp (cf.: : : : : : : : , 9, 57: : : :   Gai : : rem manu, Gai :  cf. : : : cape vorsoriam, seize the sheet, i. e. take a tack, turn about, .—Very freq. of arms ; so in gen.: arma, to take up arms, i. e. engage in war or battle,           52, 27;      :  5, 366 et saep.—Of food, to take, partake of:   : .— In partic.  Of living objects.  To take into possession, take captive, seize, make prisoner.  Of persons: : summus ibi capitur meddix, occiditur alter, Enn. ap. Paul. ex  Müll. : : :  : :    : : : .—Hence, P. a. as subst.: captus, i, m., = captivus, a prisoner, captive: : : :    .—Also, capta, ae, f., a female captive: .— Of animals, birds, fish, etc., to catch, hunt down, take: quid hic venatu non cepit? Varr. ap. :  Müll.: :  cf.:  v. 18;  : acipenserem, Cic. ap. :  cf.: .— To win, captivate, charm, allure, enchain, enslave, fascinate; mostly with abl. of means: Ph. Amore ardeo. Pa. Quid agas? nisi ut te redimas captum quam queas Minumo, : :   animum adulescentis... pellexit eis omnibus rebus, quibus illa aetas capi ac deleniri potest, :  : : : : ut pictura poësis; : : : : :     8, 124; 8, 435; 9, 511; 10, 529; :  : : : : : : : : ne oculis quidem captis in hanc fraudem decidisti; .— To cheat, seduce, deceive, mislead, betray, delude, catch: : : uti ne propter te fidemque tuam captus fraudatusque sim, form. ap. :  id. ap.  cf.: : : : : : : : .— To defeat, convict, overcome in a suit or dispute : : : .— To deprive one of his powers or faculties, to harm.  Of the physical powers, to lame, mutilate, maim, impair or weaken in the limbs, senses, etc. : : : : : : :  : :  : :  cf.:  .— Of the mental powers, to deprive of sense or intellect; only in part. perf. captus, usu. agreeing with pers. subj., and with abl. mente, silly, insane, crazy, crazed, lunatic, mad: :    so,  very rarely with gen.: .— Absol.: .—Less freq. agreeing with mens or animus: :  cf.: .— To choose, select, elect, take, pick out, adopt, accept a  person for a particular purpose or to sustain a particular office or relation: : : : :  cf.: : .—So the formula of the Pontifex Maximus, in the consecration of a vestal virgin: sacerdotem Vestalem, quae sacra faciat... ita te, Amata, capio, Fab. Pict. ap.  cf.: :   : :  Weissenb. ad loc.— Of places. , ui, cēnsum , 2, v. a. .  To tax, assess, rate, estimate.  In reference to the census .  Of the censor . By a figure directly referring to the Roman census: aequo mendicus atque ille opulentissimus Censetur censu ad Acheruntem mortuus, will be rated by an equal census, i.e. in the same class, without considering their property, : vos qui potestis ope vostrā censerier, referring to a part of the audience, you, who may be rated according to your intelligence, analog. to capite censi , : : id in quoque optimum esse debet cui nascitur, quo censetur, according to which he is rated, i.e. his worth is determined, .—And with two acc.: quintus Phosphorus, Junonia, immo Veneris stella censetur, is ranked as the fifth, App. de Mundo, p. 710.— With direct reference to the census.  = aestimo, to estimate, weigh, value, appreciate.  With gen. of price: .— In the pass.: si censenda nobis atque aestimanda res sit, utrum tandem pluris aestimemus pecuniam Pyrrhi? etc., if we have to weigh  and estimate a thing, etc., : : , 3, 47.— = honorari, celebrari, with de aliquo, = for the sake of somebody : : .— Censeri, dep., = to distinguish, with acc. only once or twice in Ovid : .— Censeri aliquā re.  = to be appreciated, distinguished, celebrated for some quality, as if the quality were a standard determining the census, analog. to capite censeri , very freq. in post-class. writings: , ext. 4: , ext. 3 med.: te custode matronalis stola censetur , the stola, etc., is appreciated for thy custody,  prooem.: : : non vitibus tantum censeri Chium, sed et operibus Anthermi filiorum, is celebrated not only for its grapes, but, etc., : : : : : censetur Apona Livio suo tellus, = for the fact that Livy was born there, : : : .—Hence,  = to be known by something : : , p. 106: pro studio bibendi quo solo censetur, either known by, or distinguished for, : .— And,  As gram. t. t., to be marked by some peculiarity, according to which a word is classified: neque de armis et moeniis infitias eo quin figurā multitudinis perpetuā censeantur, that they are marked by the form of constant plurality, i. e. that they are pluralia tantum,   . Of transactions in and by the Senate, to judge .  To be of opinion, to propose, to vote, to move, referring to the votes of the senators when asked for their opinions .  With a inf.-clause, denoting what should be decreed by the Senate : rex his ferme verbis patres consulebat... Dic, inquit ei, quid censes? tum ille Puro pioque duello quaerendas censeo, I am of the opinion that satisfaction should be sought, etc., ancient formula ap. : :  5, 6, 16; 5, 12, 31; 5, 12, 34; 5, 13, 36; 5, 14, 38; 5, 19, 53; 6, 1, 2; 9, 6, 14; 11, 15, 40; 12, 7, 17; 14, 1, 1; 14, 13, 35; cf.  :   : :    10, 12, 1; 34, 4, 20; 38, 54, 6: cum ejus diei senatus consulta aureis litteris  figenda in curiā censuisset, :  so       . Of the emperor's vote in the Senate:  so  .—And with the copula expressed : .—Sometimes referring to sententia as subject: .—Sometimes with oportere for the gerundial predic. inf.: .—With pres. inf., inst. of a gerundial: .—If the opinion of the senator does not refer to the chief question, but to incidental points, the predic. inf. may have any form: : .—  With ut, and negatively, ut ne or ne, generally when the clause has an active predicate, but also with passives instead of the gerundial inf.-clause: : : : : : : : .—And an inf.-clause, with neu or ut: : .— With a subj.-clause, without ut (rare in this connection; .— And ironically with regard to incidental points: vereamini censeo ne... nimis aliquid severe statuisse videamini, I propose you should be afraid of having decreed too severe a punishment = of course, you will not be afraid, etc., : misereamini censeo—deliquere homines adulescentuli per ambitionem—atque etiam armatos dimittatis, I propose that you pity them, etc., or I advise you to be merciful, .— Ellipt., with a gerundial clause understood: : quod ego meā sententiā censebam , Cato ap. : :   sq.; 11, 12, 29 sq.; 14, 14, 36 sq.— = sententiam dicere, to tell, to express one's opinion in the Senate .  Absol.: Priscus Helvidius .. contra studium ejus censuerat, had voted, or had expressed an opinion against his wishes, : : : .—  With adjectives in the neuter, substantively used: nec quoquam reperto qui... referre aut censere aliquid auderet, who dared to express an opinion on any   thing, : .—  With interrog. or rel.-clause: : . Of the decrees or resolutions of the Senate, = decernere, placere, to resolve, decree.  With inf.-clause.  With gerund, without copula : :  so  : :  :    7, 19, 7 et saep.— With pres. inf. pass. or act., with the force of a gerundial: :  so : : .—With both act. and pass. inf.: .—With both pres. pass. and gerund. inff.: .— .— With ut or ne.  In the words of the Senate, according to formula: quod L. Opimius verba fecit de re publicā, de eā re ita censuerunt uti L. Opimius consul rem publicam defenderet, etc., ancient S. C. ap. : quod, etc., de eā re ita censuerunt ut M. Pomponius praetor animadverteret curaretque ut si, etc., S. C. ap.  .—And with gerundial inf.-clause: quod C. Julius pontifex... de eā re ita censuerunt, uti M. Antonius consul hostiis majoribus... procuraret... Ibus uti procurasset satis habendum censuerunt, S. C. ap. .— As related by the historians, etc.: : :   quater.—With ne: .—And with inf -clause: .— With a subj.-clause : .— With neutr. acc. pron. in place of a clause: : : : .— With accusative of a noun, or a noun as passive subject, to decree or vote a thing : : : cum censeretur clipeus auro et magnitudine insignis inter auctores eloquentiae , .— With both acc. and dat.  The dat. = against: .— The dat. = in behalf of: .—And with ut: . Transf.  Of the opinions and resolutions of other deliberating bodies, or  of their members, to resolve, or to be of opinion.  With inf.-clause.  Gerundial: :  so    : : nunc surgendum censeo, I move we adjourn , : : : :    : .—And with oportere inst. of a gerundial clause : .—With opus esse : .— With ordinary pres. inf.  In place of a gerundial: .— Denoting opinion about an existing state: : .— With ut or ne: : : : : antiquos audio censuisse, ne cui ejusdem gentis patricio inderentur, resolved , .— With subj.-clause: : censeo relinquamus nebulonem hunc, eamus hinc protinus Jovi Optimo Maximo gratulatum , Scipio Afric. ap. .— With acc. neutr. of a pron. or adj. substantively used: : .— Ellipt.: :  so . Of the orders of persons in authority .  Of commanders, etc., by courtesy, inst. of velle, imperare, or a direct imperative sentence.  With gerundial inf. - clause: non tam imperavi quam censui sumptus legatis quam maxime ad legem Corneliam decernendos, I said, not strictly as an order, but as an opinion that, etc. , .— With subj.-clause: arma quae ad me missuri eratis, iis censeo armetis milites quos vobiscum habetis, you had better, etc., Pomp. ap. , A, 4. — Of an order by the people (rare; .— Of the later emperors, in their ordinances .—With inf.clause, ut, ne, and subj.-clause: , 7: , 13: , 1: censemus vindicet, remaneat, ib.  11, 48 , 23: . Of advice, given by one person to another .  Ante-class. formula: faciundum censeo = I advise, with ut-clause, with quid, sic, etc.: censeo faciundum ut quadringentos aliquos milites ad verrucam illam ire jubeas, etc., I advise you to order, etc., Cato ap. : :  : :  : .— With ordinary gerundial inf.-clauses: : :   : :  .—Sometimes by aequum censere with an inf.-clause : : qui homo cum animo... depugnat suo, Utrum ita se esse mavelit ut eum animus aequom censeat, An ita potius ut parentes ... velint i. e. as his mind prompts him,  cf. E. 1. b. 8.— With a subj.clause : censen' hominem interrogem? do you advise me to ask the man? etc., : : : : : : tu, censeo, Luceriam venias: nusquam eris tutius, Pomp. ap.  , A: , C: ad Caesarem mittas censeo, et ab eo hoc petas, Anton. : sed hos tamen numeros censeo videas , : .—Of an advice given to an adversary, with irony: : : : : .—And in jest: : :  so  12, 61, 7.—For ironical senatorial advice, by which the contrary is meant, v.  , quoted II. A. 3.— With an ut-clause (with monere; .— With a clause understood: quo me vortam nescio: Pa. Si deos salutas, dextrovorsum censeo , : quo redeam? Pe. Equidem ad phrygionem censeo , : : : : tu   potes Kalendis spectare gladiatores, et ita censeo, : : quid igitur censet ? What is wisdom's advice? : : : . Of opinions and views on general questions, to be of opinion, think, believe, hold .  With inf.-clause: : : : :  so      3, 21, 70; 4, 7, 17; 5, 7, 17;    1, 13, 35 and 37; 1, 43, 120; 1, 44, 121; 2, 22, 57; 2, 16, 44;      1, 45, 108; 3, 5, 11; 3, 22, 52; 4, 7, 14; :    19, 12, 6.—If the opinion refers to what should be observed, oportere or debere is used, or a gerundial predicate with esse : :    : : .— An inf.-clause understood: : : .— With neutr. acc. of a pron.: hoc amplius censeo, in addition to the opinions mentioned I hold, etc., : .— With a rel.-clause: .— Absol.: . In gen., = arbitror, puto, existimo, judico .  To judge, think, believe, suppose .  In gen.: : : : :  so      sq.;       : aut domino, cujum id censebis esse, reddes, Cincius, Re Mil. l. iii., de ap. : : : : : Alexander, tam memorabili victoriā laetus, quā sibi Orientis  fines apertos esse censebat,  so .— With reference to an erroneous opinion, to imagine, suppose, falsely believe: : : : :  so              et saep.: censuit se regem Porsenam occidere, Cass. Hem. ap. : .—And ironically: : : .— Referring to what should take place.  With gerundial inf.-clause: : :  so    : .— With oportere, debere, or an ordinary inf.-clause: : : : impudens postulatio visa est, censere... ipsos id advertere in se, agrosque suos pro alienis populandos obicere, to entertain the idea that they should direct that war against themselves and their own lands, etc., : : .— By aequum censere with ordinary inf.clause, expressed or understood, either = it is fair to do something, or something ought or should be done : non ego istunc me potius quam te metuere aequom censeo, I do not think it right to fear him, etc., : quid me aequom censes pro illā tibi dare? What do you think I should give as a fair price? etc., : meum animum tibi servitutem servire aequom censui, I thought it my duty that my mind should, etc., : ecquis est tandem qui vestrorum... aequom censeat poenas dare ob eam rem quod arguatur male facere voluisse? Cato ap. , 3, 36:  so   .—And without emphasis upon the idea of fairness or right:  so       :  so  : : intercedebant; : .— Very freq., esp. in Cic., when a question, rhetorical or real, is addressed to a second person, often referring to erroneous opinions: : : :  so    . 82;     :  continuo dari Tibi verba censes?  so  4, 4, 55;    : : : : : :  so               11, 1, 3; 11, 5, 10; 12, 3, 7; 12, 6, 13; 12, 8, 21; 12, 9, 22; 13, 2, 4; 14, 4, 10; :  sqq.; so .—With conditional period inst. of an inf.-clause: .—   .— With an inf.clause understood: itane tu censes? Pa. Quid ego ni ita censeam? : quid ergo censes? Tr. Quod rogas, Censeo, : quid illum censes? :  so   .—So, very freq. in the comic poets, censeo, absol., as an approving answer; also sic censeo, istuc censeo, ita censeo to be variously rendered: ego divinam rem intus faciam... So. Censeo, that will be right! : auscultemus quid agat: Ph. Sane censeo, so we will, indeed, : quid si recenti re aedis pultem? Ad. Censeo, do so! : quin eloquamur? Ag. Censeo, hercle, patrue, : patri etiam gratulabor? Tr. Censeo, I think so : etiamne complectar ejus patrem? Tr. Non censeo. Pl. Nunc non censet quom volo,  sqq.;      : male habeas! Mu. Sic censeo, : aliquem arripiamus, etc.: Ly. Hem, istuc censeo, ; .— To resolve, as a merely mental act, with gerundial inf.-clause : quibus rebus cognitis, Caesar maturandum sibi censuit, resolved to hasten, lit., thought he must hasten , : .— To consider, i. e. after carefully weighing the circumstances, with inf.-clause : .— = pu tare, habere, judicare, to consider as, to hold, with two acc., or inf.-clause.  With double acc.: . 32: : , 16, 6: cum Priscum nobilitas hostem patriae censuisset, judged, declared him the enemy, etc., .— In the pass. with nom. and inf., = haberi : :  so    3, 96; so, sub aliquo censeri, to be considered as being under one's influence,   cf. .—  To wish, with subj.-clause or ne : .   p. 117: .
, āre, v. a. , to take out every hundredth for punishment, to centesimate: .

, 1, v. a. , to increase a hundredfold: . —Hence, centŭplī^cātus, a, um, Part., increased a hundredfold, centuple: .—Subst.: cen-tŭplī^cāta, ōrum, n., a hundredfold: .—And adv.: centŭplĭcātō vēnire, to be sold a hundred times dearer, .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to divide into centuries .  Of land:  Goes.; cf.  Müll.— Of the army , to arrange in centuries, assign to companies: : rem gerit palam ; centuriat Capuae; : :  :  so : , n. 8: mulus centuriatus, for carrying provisions, Aur. ap. .— Facetiously:  cf. .— Of the people in the meeting of the council, only part. perf.: comitia centuriata, in which all the Roman people voted according to centuries , :   .—Facetiously:  Lorenz ad loc.—Hence, P. a.: centŭrĭā-tus, a, um, of or belonging to the comitia centuriata: Centuriata lex, advised in the comitia centuriata, .

, crēvi, crētum , 3, v. a. .  To separate, sift :  cf.   :  cf.: : .—Far more freq.,  Trop.  To separate, distinguish by the senses, mostly by the eyes, i. e. to perceive, see, discern ; rarely by the ears; v. infra: lumen jubarve in caelo cerno?   Enn. ap.  Müll.; :  :  v. also   cf. :  cf.: :  —Hence, sometimes opp. to hearing:  : :  cf. : : : :  : : : : : :   .—With acc. and inf.: sensumque inesse et motum in membris cerno, Canius ap.  Müll.: : quos ad resistendum concucurrisse cernebat, * : : : .—Impers. with acc. and inf.:  Herz. N. cr.— So impers. with rel. -clause: . —Ante-class., of the hearing: vox illius certe est: idem omnes cernimus, Att. ap. , and perh. also, Titin. ap.  P.—Hence,  Cerni aliquā re or in aliquā re, to become distinguished or known in something:  so : amicus certus in re incertā cernitur, Enn. ap. : .—*  Have before the mind, have respect to, regard any one: .— Transf. to intellectual objects, to perceive, comprehend, understand (syn.: :     :  : .—Hence,  Rarely of future events, to foresee, discern beforehand: : .— To decide something that is contested or doubtful , to decree, determine : : , § 6: jurati cernant. Pac. ap. : : : .—Hence,  To decide by contending or fighting : ferro non auro vitam cernamus  utrique, Enn. ap.  id. ap. , and ap.  Müll.; Pac. ap. : nisi esset qui armis secum vellet cernere, Att. ap. : ; so,   : pro patriā, pro liberis, pro aris atque focis suis, *  Kritz N. cr. : .—Humorously, .—  In gen., to decide for something, to conclude upon, resolve : praesidium castris educere, Lucil. ap. :  p. 261, 6: ; .—Hence,  In judic. lang. t. t., of inheritances.  To resolve to enter upon an inheritance,  Müll.; cf. Tit. 22, 27, and cretio.— To make known this determination, Tit. 22, 28 and 30; .— = adire, to enter upon an inheritance,      .— Trop.:  so  , ext. 3.—P. a. v. certus.
, āre, v. a. , to throw down: .

, cīvi, cĭtum, 2 , v. a. .  Lit., to put in motion; hence, to move, stir, shake (syn.: moveo, commoveo, concito, excito al.; : : inanimum est omne, quod pulsu agitatur externo; : : : .— In judic. lang. t. t.:  cf. erctum.— Trop., to put in motion, to rouse up, disturb: natura maris per se immobilis est,  et venti et aurae cient, : : fontes et stagna, Cic. poët. ap. : :  cf.:  Lachm. N. cr.— With reference to the terminus ad quem, to move, excite, or call to : :  : : : : : : : .— To call upon for help, to invoke; of invoking superior beings: : : : : .— In gen., to call upon any one by name, to mention by name: : : : :  so : triumphum nomine ciere, i. e. to call Io triumphe! .—Hence,  In a civil sense: patrem, to name one's father, i. e. show one's free birth, .— To put any course of action in progress or any passion in motion, i. e. to excite, stimulate, rouse, to produce, effect, cause, occasion, begin : :  : :  Lachm. N. cr.: : : : : : :  :    : : :  :  cf. :    :    :  cf. : — In medic.: : :  al.—Hence, cĭtus, a, um, P. a., lit. put in motion; hence, quick, swift, rapid , sooner or later, .— Sup.:  al.— With the negative, sometimes equivalent to non facile, not easily : : : quem tu non tam cito rhetorem dixisses quam ,  § 265.— Sometimes in comp. without the negative, = potius, sooner, rather: :    .—*  cĭtē, quickly, .
, ĕre, v. inch. n. , to turn  to ashes , ,  .

, xi, nctum, 3, v. a. , to go round in a circle, to surround, encompass, environ, gird, wreathe, crown, etc. .  Prop  In gen.: :  cf.:  : cincta serpentibus Hydra, id. ib 7, 658: pennae ritu coepere volucrum Cingere utrumque latus, to cover, Ov M. 6, 718, apio fasces et secto cingere porro, .— Esp.  To surround the body with a girdle, to gird on , to gird; esp. freq in pass. with abl., to be girded, encircled with something. iam quasi zonā, liene cinctus ambulo, Plaut Curc. 2, 1, 5;  cf.: : :   : : ense, Ov F. 2, 13: cingor fulgentibus armis, Verg A. 2, 749; 11, 188, 11, 536; his cingi telis, id : ense latus cingit, Ov F. 2, 784; cf. : .—Poet., in pass with acc. (cf. accingor, II., and Zumpt, Gr § : cinctaeque ad pectora vestes Bracchia docta movent, Ov M. 6, 59.—Without case: Syrinx, Ov M. 1, 695; .—Hence, in late Lat. cinctus = armis instructus, armatus, armed, equipped, enrolled:  cf. .—As a girding up of the Roman dress was necessary in pursuits requiring physical action, hence, cingor , to make one's self ready for any thing, to prepare:   cf.  Hor S. 2, 8, 10; .— To encircle with a garland or crown, to crown .  Of the head:  cf.   et saep.:  cf.:  : de tenero cingite flore caput, Ov F 3, 254.—Poet.: , 1, 61.— To encircle other parts of the body: .— Of places, to surround, encircle, invest, enclose : oras maris undique cingens,    :  provincia mari cincta, :  Zumpt: :   Ov A. A. 2, 469: cingitur insula tribus millibus passuum, i.e. has a circuit of, etc., .—Poet.: : .—Trop.; .— In milit. lang., to surround a place or army for defence or in a hostile manner, to fortify, to invest, be set, besiege: : castra vallo, id 7, 39, 8 equites cornua cinxere. covered, : :  : :  , , 3, 42.—Trop Sicilia multis undique cincta persons. Cio. Imp. Pomp 11, 30.— To escort, to accompany inermi item regi praetor Achaeorum et unus ex purpuratis latus cingebant, Liv 32, 39, 8: :  — To peel off the bark around:  Pr, cf. Plin 17, 24, 37, § 234 sqq.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make round, to round :  : : —Poet.: inclinat cursus, et easdem circinat auras, flies through in a circular course, * : .
, āre, 1, v. a. . = circumeo.  To go about, traverse: montem, Gromat. Vet. p. 326, 17; v. also circito fin.— To wander through: TOTAM REGIONEM, Inscr. ap. Hermes, 1, 343.
, āre, v. a. , to make circu lar or round, App. flor. 9, p. 346, 21. circulatus gressus, Cael. Aur Tard. 1, 1: digitos. bent in, .— Esp., to encircle, encompass: :   cf. Neue, Formenl. 2, p. 269.
, ātus, 1, v. dep. .  To form a circle about one's self, or to gather in a company or circle for conversation, * : .—Hence,  Of mountebanks, to collect people around one's self,  .

, cīdi, cīsum, 3, v. a. , to cut around, cut, clip, trim (orig. in agriculture; :  : : : : : : :  cf.   — Trop., to cut off, shorten, diminish, abridge, circumscribe (very freq. in prose;   :  so, : : .—Of discourse, to lop or cut off, to remove: :   Spald.:  : .—Hence, cir-cumcīsus, a, um, P. a., lit. cut off around, cut off; hence,  Of localities = abscisus, abruptus, cut off from connection with the region around, steep, precipitous, inaccessible: : : . — Trop., abridged, short, brief : .—Of discourse:  cf. . —Adv.: circumcīsē, briefly:  *  .

Prop., to go around, travel or march around, etc. :  sparsis Medea capillis Bacchantum ritu flagrantes circuit aras, :  cf. : : an quasi mare omnes circumimus insulas? i. e. from one to another , : : : : : : :  and 7: : : : : : : : : : Leucada continuam veteres habuere coloni; : : .— Esp.  To surround, encircle, enclose, encompass.  Esp. in milit. lang.: :  sq.:    Gall. ap. : .— In gen., absol.: .—With acc.: : , 5, 26.— To go from one to another, soliciting, canvassing, admonishing, etc., qs. to go the rounds (stronger than ambire, which signif. to go to this one and that; most freq. after the Aug. per.; :  Cael. ap. : :   :     :  cf.:  .— Trop. Earnest, anxious : : interim me   quidam ... secreto curatoque sermone corripit, monet, etc., .— Taken care of, managed, attended to: : : .—Adv.: cūrātē, carefully, diligently; only in comp.:    .

, cŭcurri , cursum, 3, v. n. , to run, to move quickly , to hasten, fly .  Lit.  Of living beings: : : : : : , 26, 17 al.: , 10 et saep.: : : :  cf.: : : .—With acc. of distance:  cf.  cf.  infra.—Poet., of flight: .—With inf.: , ext. 1.—Impers.: : : — Rarely  with the homogeneous objects iter, stadium, campus, etc.: : .—Hence pass.: unde et campus curritur et mare navigatur, Auct. ap. .— Prov.: currentem incitare or instigare, etc., to spur a willing horse, i. e. to urge one who needs no urging,   :   cf.  so,  : : .— Transf., of inanimate objects :       :  cf. :  et saep.: :  , §§ : :   Garet.— Trop.: : : : :  cf. : : : .— With acc., to run, traverse : : .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to shorten, diminish : : .— Trop., to diminish:  cf.: .
