, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to crook, bend, bow, curve .  Lit.: : : , 22, 38:   cf.: : : :  cf. :  cf. poet.: : : : :  cf.  and: .—Of persons:  so, : .—*  Trop., to make to yield, to move: .
, no perf., ātum, 1, v. a. , to make pointed, to point :  cf. .

verbParts: , īvi, or ĭi, ītum, 4 , v. a.
fullText: , īvi, or ĭi, ītum, 4 , v. a. , to watch, protect, keep, defend, guard .  In gen.  With material objects: Q. Caepio Brutus pro consule provinciam Macedoniam, tueatur, defendat, custodiat incolumemque conservet,  : :  cf.: : : : : : : : : : : : .—Esp.: se, to be on the watch: : , A, 8.— With ab: : : .—  With immaterial objects , to keep, preserve, regard, take heed, observe, maintain: :  cf.: :  : : : : : : : :  et saep.— With ab: .— With ut or ne: :   : .— With the access. idea of hindering free motion, in a good or bad sense.  In gen., to hold something back, to preserve, keep: : : : : : .— Esp., to hold in custody, hold captive:  Cic. Fragm. ap. : : : :  et saep.—Hence, * cu-stōdītē, adv. , cautiously, carefully: .
, āre, v. n., = , to fill a cyathus,   Auct. de Verb. 8, § 14 Jan.
, āre, v. n., = , to strike the cymbals, Cass. Hem. ap. .
, āre, v. a., to injure: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  Gen., to occasion loss or damage to, to harm, damage = damno   afficere: .—  Esp. a judicial t. t., to condemn, doom, sentence one to any punishment = condemno, v. .—Constr. with acc. of person, either alone or with gen., abl., de, in, ad, etc., of the crime and punishment: damnatur aliquis crimine vel judicio, sed sceleris, parricidii, etc., Lachm. ad  cf. Munro, ad : Zumpt, Gr. § 446 sq.; Roby, Gr. § 1199 sq.  With acc. pers. alone:  : : ego accusavi, vos damnastis, Dom. Afer ap.  et saep. —Transf., of things: causa judicata atque damnata, Cic. Rab. perd. 4; .— With acc. pers. and gen. :  : : : : :   Zumpt N. cr., et saep.:  : :  cf.: .— With abl.:  so, : : :  cf.:  morti damnare, , v. Weissenb. ad loc.— With de: : :  cf. —（) With in or ad: :  :  .— () With ut, .—（) With quod: , ext. 7: .—（) With cur: . Transf.  To bind or oblige one's heir by last will and testament to the performance of any act.—Constr. with ut, ne, or the inf.:  with ne,  with inf.: : . In a non-legal sense, to condemn, censure, judge: aliquem summae stultitiae, : : : damnare aliquem voti , to condemn one to fulfil his vow, i. e. by granting his prayer : , Serv. and Heyne: voto, Sisenn. ap. :  :   (cf.: voti, Titin. and Turpil. ap.  and 10;   cf.: :  et saep.; cf.  Heyne: : : .—Of inanimate objects, to condemn, reject:  cf.   et saep.—Part. fut. pass. as subst.: . Of the plaintiff, to seek or effect a person's condemnation : quem ad recuperatores modo damnavit Plesidippus,   :   cf. condemno, no. II., and condemnator, no. II.—Hence,damnātus, a, um, P. a.  Prop., condemned: .— Meton. , reprobate, criminal: : .— Hateful, wretched: , 15.
, āre, v. a. , to serve up, as food: .
, āvi, v. a. frequent. , to give away, administer : evectionem, Cato ap. : : : . Obscenè,  cf. datatim.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to whiten over, to whitewash, to parget, plaster : :   .—Prov.: duo parietes de eadem fidelia, Curius ap.  v. fidelia.—In eccl. Lat., to purify, cleanse: .—Pass., to be white, —Hence, dĕalbātus, a, um, P. a., whitewashed, plastered:  cf. .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n., to walk abroad, walk much, to take a walk, to promenade :  : eamus deambulatum, id. ap.  so in the supine, * .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to be desperately in love with, to love dearly or passionately , "vehementius amare," .  Prop.:   Afran. ap. Non. l. l. : Laber. ap. Charis. l, p. 84 P. .— Transf.  Of things, to be quite in love with, delighted with:  cf.: : deamo te, Syre, I am greatly obliged to you, * .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. . *  To deprive of money : depeculassere aliqua sperans me atque deargentassere, Lucil. ap. . — To silver over, to plate with silver : : : .
, āri, v. dep. n., to decide finally : .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a.  Aliquem, to disarm : . 10, 7.— Aliquid, to deprive of power, blunt: .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. . Lit., to dismember, to rend limb by limb; hence, trop., to ruin: "quasi per artus concidere," : :  cf. Non. l. l.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to hew or cut with an axe, to smoothe.  Lit. : deasciato stipiti, wrought, smoothed, Prud. . 10, 381.—  To rub out, efface: hunc titulum, Murat. Inscr. 1203, 9.— Trop.: aliquem, to cheat, to chouse , .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to gild, to gild over : cassidas et tegerent argento et deanrarent, Cod.   Theod. 10, 22, 1; : : : SIGNVM DEAVRATVM, Inscr. Orell. no. 3173 .
, ātus, 1, v. dep. n., to rave like the Bacchantes, to rage without control, revel wildly :  .— Poet., of inanimate things, to rage: qua parte debacchentur ignes, * .
, ĕre, v. a., to beat or thrust severely , .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. and a. .  Neutr., to bring a war to an end, to finish a war. So rare in the act. form:  cf.   . But exceedingly common as an impersonal:  cf. : :   fin. Drak.; cf. :   :    :  and in the part. perf. absol. debellato, after the war is ended :  so  — Act. . *  With a homogeneous object, to fight out: .— With heterog. object, to conquer completely, to vanquish, subdue:  : : : : : Indiam, *   .— Trop.: : .

, ŭi, ĭtum, 2, v. a. , , to owe . Lit., of money and money's worth.  Act.,  with acc.:  cf. :  so,  et saep.: :  so, : quadringenties HS. : :  et saep.— Without acc.: : : : Cal. Jan. debuit;   et saep.—Part. pres. as subst.: debentes, ium, m., debtors,  cf. .— Pass.:   cf.: :  :  cf.:  et saep.—Hence,  Dēbĭ-tum, i, n., what is owing, a debt, Cic.  : : : : , pr. 1. Prov.: . Trop., to owe something, i. e. to be under obligation, both to and for something. To owe, i. e. to be bound or under obligation to render, pay, etc., something .  In gen.  Act.  with acc.: :  so,  cf. no. b: : ; cf. no. b: : :  cf.  :  cf. : navis, quae tibi creditum Debes Vergilium finibus Atticis,  :  Wagn. N. cr.; cf. :  cf. infra b fin.—  With inf., to be bound, in duty bound to do something; I ought, must, should, etc., do it : : : : :  et saep.:  fin.: :  et saep.—Poet. for necesse est, oportet, it is necessary, it must needs :    1, 232 Munro.— Pass., to be due or owing: :  :  et saep.: : : : :  et saep.:    cf. supra, a .—Hence, Dēbĭtum, i, n., what is due, debt, duty, obligation : : :   Cor. 7, 3: .— Poet. and in post-Aug. prose like the Gr.  and .  To owe, i. e. to be bound or destined by fate or by nature .  Act.. urbem et jam cerno Phrygios debere nepotes, i. e. are destined to found, :  cf. ,  530.—More usually,  pass., to be due i. e. to be destined:  cf.  7, 120; : : : : ; cf. so absol.: : : DEBITVM NATVRAE PERSOLVIT, etc., Inscr. Orell. no. 3453;  no. 4482.— So, because what one is destined by the fates to suffer is regarded as his debt (): . To owe something to some one, to be indebted to or to have to thank one for something.  With acc.:  so magna beneficia mihi, Cael. ap.  :  cf.    et saep.:     so, . — Absol., to be indebted, obliged, under obligation to one:  cf. . To continue to owe something; i. e. to withhold, keep back: , init.—So pass.:
, ĕre, v. a., to drink of: .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to lame, cripple, maim; to debilitate, unnerve, disable, weaken . Lit.  Of personal objects: : : : : lapsu debilitatus, * : qui filium debilitavit, ut inhabilis militiae sit,  : .— Of inanimate objects: : : lingua Debilitata malis, * : :  Bait. .—Poet.: quae nunc oppositis debilitat pumicibus mare Tyrrhenum, i. e. breaks its waves , . Trop.  Of personal objects: quo metu debilitaret nostros, Varr. ap. :  cf.: : : : :  et saep.: debilitati a jure cognoscendo, i. e. dispirited, discouraged , .— Of inanimate objects: :  so : : nimis effrenatam vim fame, id. fragm. ap.  cf.: vires animi , * : : :  et saep.: : .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to prate of a thing, to babble, blab out :  .—With acc. and inf.,  Lucil. ap. .
, āre, v. a., to trumpet forth , trop., Tert. virg. vel. 13.
, āre, v. a., to deride, laugh to scorn , .
, āre, v. a., to cut the top off, to top and lop : : .
, āre, v. a. , to deprive of one's hood, to plunder one: decalanticare, eburno speculo depeculassere, Lucil. ap.  dub.
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. (calvus], to make bald, to remove the hair : : :  1 Cor. 11, 6.
, ĕre, 3, v. a., to celebrate by singing: Cererem, Prob. Cath. 1492 P.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  To sing a thing off, to repeat in a singing manner .  Usually with the secondary idea of something trite, worn out, absurd; to repeat often, to say over and over again ( = semper repetere, in ore habere; cf. :     — Without this unfavorable idea: :  Ilii in scenico habitu, to recite, rehearse, * : .— Esp., to repeat as a charm, and hence to bewitch, enchant, charm: : , p. 165, 6; , p. 137, 12; — Intr. To leave off singing: .— To play : .
, avi, 1, v. a. , to make prose of verse, to disarrange the order of the words in a verse: .
, āre, v. a. , to take off the flesh ,    .
, ĕre, v. n. , to form a stem, run to stalk: .

, cessi, cessum, 3 , v. n., to go away, depart, withdraw. —Constr. absol. with de, ex, or merely the abl.; rarely with ab. Lit.  In gen.: : : :  cf.: :  : :  : :  so, : . Esp.  t. t.  In milit. lang., to retire, withdraw from a former position:   fin.; : : : :  so with abl., Auct. B. Alex. 34; 35 ; 70 al.—  In official lang.: de provincia, ex provincia, provinciā, or absol. , to retire from the province on the expiration of a term of office: ;  Drak.:  so, : : :  Zumpt N. cr.:   :  so absol., :  cf.:  . —Rarely with a:  Decedere de viā; also viā, in viā alicui, alicui, or absol., to get out of the way, to give place, make way for one :  cf.: ; cf.: :  cf. : : .—Also, to get out of the way of, avoid:  cf.: .—By zeugma, in the pass.: . Pregn., to depart, disappear .  Of living beings, to decease, to die: :   Mac. 6, 31; but commonly absol.: :  , and 3;      et saep.: : : : .— Of inanimate things, to depart, go off; to abate, subside, cease: :   cf.: :  cf.:  :   cf.: : :   :  so with dat.,    .—Poet.: .—In the Aug. poets sometimes of the heavenly bodies, to go down, set:  so   hence also of the day, to depart:  . Trop.  De possessione, jure, sententia, fide, etc. , to depart from; to give up, resign, forego; to yield, to swerve from one's possession, station, duty, right, opinion, faith, etc.  With de:  cf.:    : : : :  cf. impers.: — With abl. alone : : : :  :   : .— Very rarely with ab: .— Absol.: si quos equites decedentis nactus sum, supplicio adfeci, Asin. Pol. ap. C. Fam. 10, 32, 5. De via, to depart, deviate from the right way: :  so, . To give way, yield to another : : . To avoid, shun, escape from : nec serae meminit decedere nocti, to avoid the late night, i. e. the coldness of night, Varius ap. Macr. S.  6, 2, 20;  : . To fall short of, degenerate from: : a rebus gestis ejus et gloriae splendore, Justin. 6, 3, 8.
*  For the simple verb , to go off, turn out, result in any manner: .
, ĕre, v. a., = declino, to turn aside, deviate,  Lachm. ex conj. .

, crēvi, crētum, 3 , v. a. and n. To decide, determine any thing disputed or doubtful. For syn. cf.: scisco, jubeo, statuo, constituo, dico, sancio, consilium capio, destino, obstino, definio, determino. Prop., of a judge, magistrate, etc., to pronounce a decision respecting something; to decide, judge, determine, decree; to vote for any thing .—Const. with acc., with acc. et inf., a relat. clause, with de, or absol.: : : , C, § 11: decernere vindicias secundum servitutem, in favor of slavery, i. e. restore the slave to his master,  cf. :  cf.   : :    :  : :  cf.: :  et saep.:  et saep.: : cum pontifices decressent ita; : : in  jure dicundo, ita decrevit, ut, etc.,  cf. .—Impers.: .—Esp. of the emperor, to determine the law by deciding a case:  . Transf., beyond the judicial sphere, to decide, determine, judge: qui nequeas nostrorum uter sit Amphitruo decernere, Plaut. fragm. ap. :  cf.:  : :  : :  : : : aliquem decernere hostem, to proclaim one an enemy by a formal decree, .—Absol.: . Milit., to decide by combat; hence , in gen., to fight, combat, contend:  : : :  cf. : de bello decernere, Auct. B. Hisp. 5 fin. Oud. N. cr.:  cf.: :  12, 282; 695 : : :  et saep.:  : : :  fin.—Absol.:  cf. . Transf., beyond the milit. sphere: —So of a judicial contest:  cf.  : : :  . With reference to one's own acts, to decide, determine on doing something; to determine, resolve on something .—Constr., with inf. and with acc. and inf.: :  et saep.:    cf.: : . With ut and subjunct.: .—With accus.: —Hence, dē-crētum, i, n. A decree, decision, ordinance of any political or judicial body (for syn. cf.: :  cf.  §  :  et saep.: .—Esp. leg. t. t., a decision of the emperor as judge, a precedent ,  .—  Transf., in philos. lang. as a translation of the Gr. , principle, doctrine, precept,   § 29; cf.   and 95, 9 sq. decretis suis paret? .

, psi, ptum, 3, v. a. , to pluck off, to tear, pull, or break off, to crop, gather .  Lit.: :   cf.: :  cf.  :   cf.:   : :  et saep.—Absol.:  Catull. 64, 316.— Trop.: :  cf. : : .—Poet.: oscula mordenti semper decerpere rostro, Catull. 68, 127 ;  Sillig.—Hence,  Transf. To enjoy: : : :  cf.: : .— To destroy:  prooem. § 10; cf.:

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. and a., to go through a decisive contest, to fight it out .  In the milit. sphere.  With abl.:  so     cf.: : :  : : — Without abl.:  :  so absol.,    : de salute omnium, Auct. B. Alex. 16, 3.—Pass. impers.:  Auct. B. Alex. 16, 6; Auct. B. Afr. 19 fin.— Poet. like certo as v. a., to fill with strife or contention, to fight for, to achieve by fighting, contending: : :  cf.: . Beyond the milit. sphere, to contend: erat non jure, non legibus, non disceptando decertandum; : decertare contentione dicendi, to contend, to strive, to vie with one,  cf.: : :  in the gymnasium, ludicra virginum inter se   decertantium, Mela, 1, 7, 4.—*  Poet. of inanimate subjects: Africus Decertans Aquilonibus, * .

, cuit, 2, v. impers. . It is seemly, comely, becoming,; it beseems, behooves, is fitting, suitable, proper :  cf. also nunc quid aptum sit, hoc est, quid maxime deceat in oratione videamus, .—Constr., with nom. or inf. of the thing, and with acc.; less freq. with dat. of the pers.; sometimes absol. With nom. rei  and acc. pers.: Ph. Quin me aspice et contempla, ut haec me decet. Sc. Virtute formae id evenit, te ut deceat, quicquid habeas,  cf.:     cf.: :  cf.:   et saep.: : :  et saep.: :  et saep.—In plur.: : :   et saep.:  :  et saep.: .— Without acc. pers.:  cf.: : ,  20;  et saep.:  cf. .—In plur.: :    et saep. — With dat.: : certa est ratio quae deceat philosopho, Apul.   cf. infra. — With inf.  and acc. pers.: : :    so freq. with inf. pass.: :  . — Without acc.: :  :   .— With dat.: : : . Absol.  with acc. pers.:  cf.:  :  cf.: :  et saep.— Without case:  cf. : : : : : perge;  et saep.— With dat.:  : — Hence, dĕcens, entis, P. a. , seemly, becoming, decent, proper, fit:  cf.:  : :   cf.:  :  et saep.: :  cf. 8, 6, 6.— Esp. of corporeal fitness and symmetry, regularly, symmetrically, handsomely shaped; well-formed; noble:  cf.: : : :  cf.: : : : pulcher et decens toto corpore, Suct. Dom. 18; cf. :   et saep.—Adv.: decenter , becomingly, decently, properly, fitly:  cf.: :  cf.: .—Comp.:  —Sup., a false reading for diligentissime, .
, āre, 1, v. a. , to un-Charmidize, i. e. to destroy one's identity as Charmides, also to end his happiness: .

, cĭdi, 3, v. n. , to fall off, fall down . Lit.  In gen.:  so, :  cf.: :   : : :  so, :  so, : :  et saep.: :  : : : : : : : : . — Pregn. , to fall down dead, to sink down, to die : : : :  cf.  and : Decidit; . Trop., to fall, drop, fall away, fail, sink:    : : : : oculis captus in hanc fraudem decidisti , :  cf.: : : : : :  med.: in maximis necessitatibus, ad quas libidine deciderat, Schol. .

, cīdi, cīsum, 3, v. a. , to cut off.  Lit. (rare in ante-Aug. per.; more freq. abscīdo; : : : :  : :   et saep.— Transf., to cudgel, beat soundly: . Trop., to decide a disputed, or, indeed, any matter ; to determine, settle, terminate, put an end to .  With acc.: damnum, XII. Tab. 12, 4;  :  cf.: :  :    cf. : : ego pol istam jam aliquovorsum tragulam decidero, I will now dispose of this dart one way or another, i. e. I will now put an end to this attack, these tricks, .— With praepp.: , §   79; 2, 1, 48, § 125;  :  cf.: :    : decidere jactu coepit cum ventis, to compound with the winds by throwing overboard , .— Absol.:   .— To cut down, reduce, diminish: .

verbParts: or dĕcŭmo, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a.
fullText: or dĕcŭmo, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  To select by lot every tenth man for punishment, to decimate , : : cohortium militem, Frontin. Strat. 4, 1, 37 al.— Absol., .— To cause to pay tithes, to collect tithes from a person. —Pass.: .— To select the tenth part as an offering, to pay tithes of anything,  Müll.; .—Hence, dĕcŭmātus, a, um, P. a., selected, excellent, choice:  and 51.—Sup.: .
, ĕre, v. n., to be wholly reduced to ashes :

, cēpi, ceptum, 3, v. a. , primarily signifies to catch away, catch up, seize an animal while running, fleeing, etc. ; but occurs only in the trop. sense , to catch, ensnare, entrap, beguile, elude, deceive, cheat (for syn. cf.: :   et saep.: :  cf.:  : homines imperitos et per colloquium deceptos crudelissime interfecisse, Caes. B.  C. 1, 85, 3;  fin.; : . Praef. 18:   cf.: : :  et saep.: .—Poet., in Gr. construction: Prometheus dulci laborum decipitur sono, is beguiled of his sufferings , .— Of inanimate objects:  cf.: :  cf. : : : : :  cf.  Loers.;  : .—  Absol.: :  .
, āre, v. a., to make of a circular form, to round off : : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n. and a.— Rhetor. t. t., to exercise one's self in rhetorical delivery, to practise speaking, to declaim. For syn. cf.: dictito, concionor, pronuntio, palam dico, praedico, recito, declamito. In a good sense.  Neutr.:  id. fragm. ap. : dum tu declamas Romae, * : : et saep.— Pass. impers.: .— Act. : .— Poet., in gen., to speak oratorically, to declaim: .— In a bad sense, to speak as an orator with violence, to declaim, to bluster, bawl:  :

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a., to make clear, plain, evident , to show, manifest, declare, etc., . For syn. cf.: monstro, demonstro, probo, confirmo, ostendo, ostento, significo, indico, defero; exsisto, appareo, eluceo. — Lit.  In gen.: : .— In pub. law lang., t. t., to announce any one  in public session as elected to an office , to declare or proclaim publicly: ; cf.       et saep.:  : : : : . — Trop., to make clear to the mind, to manifest, demonstrate, prove, show, explain: .—Constr. with acc., acc. and inf., a relat. clause, or absol.  With acc.:  cf.  : : : nullum inveniri potest, quod magis idem declaret Latine, quod Graece , quam declarat voluptas,  cf.   : : .— With acc. and inf.:   :   prooem. § 15 et saep.— With a relative clause: : : : cf.  et saep.— Absol.: :

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. and n. , orig. to bend from the straight path; to turn aside or away .  Lit.  Act.:  cf.:  and: se a terris omnia numina, Poët. ap. :  : .—Poet. of the eyes, to bend down, i. e. to lower, close them in sleep: nec dulci declinat lumina somno, * .— Neutr.:   .—So of the oblique motion of atoms : si omnes atomi declinabunt, nullae umquam cohaerescent;  cf. : .— Trop.  In gen.  Act., to turn aside: neque declinatam quicquam ab aliarum ingenio ullam reperias, who has departed, deviated, *  cf.:  : : . — Neutr., to turn aside, deviate, turn away:  cf.: : : : : : : :  cf. : : : :  cf. .—Absol.: : : . — In partic. grammat. t. t., to vary, inflect a part of speech.  In the older grammarians, of every kind of inflection ,   sq.; cf. also   — In the later grammarians, to decline, in the strict sense, Charis, p. 8 sq. et al. — Transf., with an object denoting that from which one turns aside; to avoid, to shun ;  cf., D. fin.; and: : : : : :  cf. :  : : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. . *  To take off from the neck: : in tuo collo est: decolles cave, Caecil. ib.— Trop., to deprive, rob of a thing: quibus fructibus me décolĺavi, Lucil. ap. , P.— , to decollate, decapitate, behead : piratas, Fenest. ap. To put in order, arrange, set right: : :  :  cf. : : :  cf. in a pun respecting a scholar unable to pay his debts: omnes solvere posse quaestiones, Unum difficile expedire nomen, Bibacul. ap. :  cf.: : : .— Of speech, to disclose, unfold, explain, relate, narrate (mostly poet. and in post-Aug. prose; : id ego aequum ac jus fecisse expedibo atque eloquar, will show, Enn. ap.  : : : : : : : : .— Reflex. of events, to develop, run their course, proceed:  cf.: .— Absol., res expedit, or impers., expedit , it is serviceable, profitable, advantageous, useful, expedient : :  cf.: :  cf.: : : —With an inf. clause as subject:  cf.: : : :   et saep.—With subj. clause as subject after ut or ne :  Benecke ad loc.: : .—Absol.: : : .—Hence, ex-pĕdītus, a, um, P. a., unimpeded, unincumbered, disengaged, free, easy, ready, at hand. , ŭi, ĭtum, 2 , v. a. and n. , to have, in the widest sense of the word, to hold, keep, possess, cherish, entertain, occupy, enclose, contain .  In gen.  Of personal subjects.  With persons or things as objects: SI INTESTATO MORITVR, CVI SVVS HERES NEC SIT, AGNATVS PROXIMVS FAMILIAM HABETO, Fragm. XII. Tab. ap. : ex tui animi sententia tu uxorem habes? Cato ap.  cf.: : : : : : : :  so,  and: : : : : : : : faenum habet in cornu; : : : : :  cf.: :  cf. :  cf.: : .— With abstr. objects: quid illos, bono genere gnatos, opinanimi animi habuisse atque habituros dum vivent? Cato ap. : : : : :  cf.:  so,  32; :  cf.: : : : : nimiam spem, Cato ap. :  cf.:   cf. : : , 6: consolationem   semper in ore atque in animo,  cf.  Müll.: :   cf.: : fidem, gratiam, honorem, rationem; v. these nouns.—In a play on the word lumen: Arge, jaces; quodque in tot lumina lumen habebas Exstinctum est, the light for so many lights , .— With inf. , to have something to do, be able to do something: : .—So with inf. or with the part. fut. pass. , to have or be obliged to do something, I must do something: : : : : : : : : : .— Of inanim. or abstr. subjects: : : : :  cf.: : : :  cf.: : : :  et saep.:  cf.:  :  cf.: : :  : : . In partic.  Pregn., to have or possess property :  cf. : qui habet, ultro appetitur: qui est pauper, aspernatur, Cic. Fragm. ap.  P.:  so, :  cf. : nos quod simus, quod habeamus, etc., Curius ap. :  cf.:   prol. 21; : quid habentibus auri nunquam exstincta sitis?  so, habentes = , the wealthy, . — With an object- or relative-clause, to have the means, ability, or knowledge, i. e. to be in a condition, to be able, to know how to do or say any thing.  With an objectclause: : : ,  39, 93; cf.: : : : .— With a relat.-clause .— Also, with a double object, to make, render: :  :  : : .— Hence: : :  cf. .— To have or hold a person in any manner, to treat, use: :  cf.  :  Kritz; cf.:  :   : : :  : : .— With se, and sometimes mid. or neut., to hold or keep himself or itself in a certain manner, i. e. to be constituted or situated, to find one's self, to be, in any manner.  Habere se: : : : : : praeclare se res habeat , si, etc., :  cf. :  cf.: : :  cf. :  cf.: .— Mid.: : .— Neutr. : Tullia nostra recte valet: Terentia minus belle habuit, Dolab. ap. : : qui bene habet suisque amicis est volup, id.   Mil. 3, 1, 130: :  : : illasce sues sanas esse habereque recte licere spondesne? Formula emendi, ap.  .— To hold, account, esteem, consider, regard a person or thing in any manner or as any thing; to think or believe a person or thing to be so or so: : : : : :  : : :  cf.  fin.: non habeo nauci Marsum augurem, Poët. ap. : :  cf. :  so,  : :  : :  fin.: : : : :  :  cf. also : : :  cf.: : : .—Hence: sic habeto, or sic habeas aliquid, or with an object-clause, hold or judge thus, be convinced or persuaded, believe, know: :  fin.: :  so with an object-clause,  .—Without sic: : .— To take, accept, bear, submit to, endure: : : :   Weissenb.— To hold, have possession of, occupy, a place: :   cf. : :  12, 54.— More freq. neutr., to dwell, live anywhere : quae Corinthum arcem altam habetis, Enn. ap. : : quis istic habet?  : :  Müll.; cf.: .— To spend, pass : :  al.— To have in one's mind, to know, be acquainted with: : habes consilia nostra; : :  cf. :  cf. . — To have as a habit, peculiarity, or characteristic:  .— To hold, to make, do, perform, prepare, utter, pronounce, produce, cause:  cf.:  so,  3, 11, 2; 3, 106, 1; : : :   : : : :    :  cf.: :  fin.:  : : : :  et saep.:  cf. : .— Habere in animo , with an objectclause, to have in mind, to intend, to be disposed, inclined to do any thing :  : :  dub , v. Drak. ad h. l.— Habere sibi or secum aliquid, to keep to one's self : :  cf. ib. § 5; .—So the formula used in divorces:  : . —Comic. transf.: .— Trop.: : .— Of a sweetheart, to have, to possess, enjoy: , 22:  : cum esset objectum, habere eum Laida; .— Gladiatorial t. t., of a wounded combatant: hoc habet or habet, he has that , he is hit:  .— Transf.:  : egomet continuo mecum; .—Hence: hăbĭtus, a, um, P. a., held or kept in a certain condition, state, humor .  In gen.  Lit.: equus nimis strigosus et male habitus, Massur. Sabin. ap.  v. in the foll.— Trop.: .— In partic., physically, well kept, well conditioned, fleshy, corpulent: : : equum nimis strigosum et male habitum, sed equitem ejus uberrimum et habitissimum viderunt, etc., Massur. Sabin. ap. .

, haesi, haesum, 2, v. n. , to hang or hold fast, to hang, stick, cleave, cling, adhere, be fixed, sit fast, remain close to any thing or in any manner ; usually constr. with in, the simple abl. or absol., less freq. with dat., with ad, sub, ex, etc.  Lit.:  so, : :  cf.: :  :  cf. : : :   cf.:  and: : : : : :  cf.:  and: : : :  cf.:     and: :  : :  § : .— Prov.  Haerere in luto, i. e. to be in trouble, difficulty: ; cf. haesito, I.—In salebra: proclivi currit oratio: venit ad extremum: haeret in salebra, runs aground, i. e. is at a loss, .—In a like sense,  Aqua haeret, the water stops; v. aqua. Trop.  In gen., to hold fast, remain attached or fixed, to keep firm, adhere:  cf.: : :  cf.:  and: : : : : : .—With dat.: : : : : cum ante illud facetum dictum emissum haerere debeat, quam cogitari potuisse videatur, must have hit , : in quos incensos ira vitamque domini desperantes cum incidisset, haesit in iis poenis, quas, etc., fell into, incurred those penalties , : : in hoc flexu quasi aetatis fama adolescentis paulum haesit ad metas, hung back, was caught ,  .— In partic.  With the idea of nearness predominating, to keep near or close to a person, to join or attach one's self to, to follow :  cf.: : : :  : .— Poet.: .—Hence,  In a bad sense: in tergis, tergis, in tergo, to hang upon one's rear, i. e. to pursue closely: : :  11 Weissenb. .— With the idea of duration in time predominating, to remain fixed, to abide or continue anywhere, to keep at, stick to any thing : : :  cf.: : volitare in foro, haerere in jure ac praetorum tribulibus, to go loitering or dangling about, : et siccis vultus in nubibus haerent, hang upon, i. e. remain long looking at,  cf.: :  cf.: : :  cf.: : .— With the idea of hindrance to free motion predominating,  to stick fast, be brought to a stand-still, to be embarrassed, perplexed, at a loss, to hesitate, to be suspended or retarded .  Of persons:  cf.: : : :  cf.: : : : :     cf.: :  cf. :  .— Of things:    cf.: occisa est haec res; : :  cf.: : .

, ui, ēre, v. n. and a. , to stand on end, stand erect, to bristle.  Lit. (for the most part only poet.;  Müll.; cf.: : : : : : : : : : : : densantur campis horrentia tela virorum, Enn. ap.  P. ; cf.: hastis longis campus splendet et horret, id. ap. ; imitated  Serv.; : mare cum horret fluctibus, is ruffled, rough, Att. ap. : : . — Transf.  To move in an unsteady, shaking manner. To shake, shiver with cold, rigere : : : .— To tremble, shudder, quake with fright; more freq. as a verb. act., with an object, to shudder or be frightened at, to tremble at, be afraid of .  Absol.: : Ph. Extimuit tum illa? Me. Horret corpus, cor salit, : : .— With acc.: : :  cf.: , A, 2: : Ariovisti crudelitatem, * : : : : : : :  et saep.:  cf.: : :   : . — With an inf. or relat.-clause: : :    :  : .— With ne: .— To shudder with amazement, to be astonished, amazed : : :  cf. horrendus, 2.— To be of a rough or frightful appearance; to look rough, look frightful; to be terrible, dreadful, horrid : : quaedam loca frigoribus hiemis  intolerabiliter horrent, Col. 1, 4, 9;  cf.: nec fera tempestas toto tamen horret in anno. : .— Trop.: .—Hence,  horrens, entis, P. a. , bristly, shaggy, rough : : : : .— hor-rendus, a, um, P. a. Dreadful, terrible, fearful, terrific, horrible : : : : : : : : :  cf.: : : : : .—Neutr. adv.: :  .—Plur.: .— In a good sense, wonderful, awful, venerable : : : . —Adv.: horrendē, dreadfully,  .

In gen., constr. aliquem, aliquem ad or in aliquid, ut, ne, with the simple subj., de aliqua re, aliquid, with the inf. or absol. fullText: , lāvi, lautum, lăvātum and lōtum , 1 and 3, v. a. and n. , to wash, bathe, lave.  Lit.: : puerum, Enn. ap.  : : : cum jam manus pransores lavarent, Veran. ap. Macrob. verbParts: or lŭbet, libuit and libitum est , 2, v. n.
fullText: or lŭbet, libuit and libitum est , 2, v. n. and impers. , it pleases, is pleasing, is agreeable: mihi, I am disposed, I like, I please, I will.— Constr. with nom. of a demonstr. or rel. pronoun, with inf. or a subject-clause as subject, or impers. without a subject, and with or without a dat.  Id libet : : :  cf.: : : .—Once in plur.: .—Without a dat.: : : : : : .— With inf. or a subject-clause, with or without a dat.: :  : Qui lubitumst illi condormiscere? Lu. Oculis, opinor, : : :   .—Without a dat.: cum illuc ventum est, ire illinc lubet, Enn. ap. ; : : :   : : libet expectare quis impendat, etc., I should like to see who, etc., .—  Absol., with or without a dat.: : :   : :    : Ch. Quid in urbe reptas villice? Ol. Lubet,  : Pe. Qua fiducia ausus ... dicere? Ep. Libuit,  cf. .—Hence,  lĭbens , entis, P. a., that does a thing willingly or with readiness, willing, with good will, with pleasure .  Lit.  In gen.: : Ph. Complectere. An Facio lubens, :   : cum totius Italiae concursus facti illius gloriam   libens agnovisset, .—Freq. in the abl. absol.: me, te, etc., and animo libente or libenti, with pleasure, gladly, very willingly: :  :  Mos. N. cr.: : .—Sup.: : : : : .— In partic.: : : V. S. L. M., i. e. votum solvit libens merito, or V. L. S., i. e. votum libens solvit, very freq. in inscriptions. — Transf., glad, happy, joyful, cheerful, merry : : : .—Hence, adv.: lĭbenter or lŭbenter, willingly, cheerfully, gladly, with pleasure, Enn. ap. ; id. ap. : : :  :   :  : .—Comp.:  :  : .—Sup.: cui ego quibuscumque rebus potero libentissime commodabo, Cic. Fragm. ap. : cum lubentissime edis, Favorin. ap. :   .— Hence also,  lĭbĭtus, a, um, P. a.; only plur. as subst.: lĭbĭta, ōrum, n., lit., the things that please, one's pleasure, will, liking, humor : : : .

verbParts: , cŭit and cĭtum est, 2 , v. n.
fullText: , cŭit and cĭtum est, 2 , v. n. and impers. , it is lawful, it is allowed or permitted; one may or can, one is at liberty to do so and so; constr. with neutr. of the demonstr. or rel. pron., with inf. or a subject-clause, with or without a dat., or dat. and inf., with ut or with the simple subj., or entirely absol.  With neutr. of the demonstr. or rel. pron. as a subject, with or without a dat.: : :  cf.: : : neque idem ubique  aut licet aut decorum est, : : : :  :  cf.: .—Rarely in plur.: .— With inf. or a subject-clause, with or without a dat.: neque terram inicere, neque cruenta Convestire corpora mihi licuit, Enn. ap. : : : :  Sulp. ap.  : : .—Without a dat.: : : : :  : :  cf. :     : : : . —With inf. pass. : :  cf.:  : : : : :  .—The noun of the subject-clause is regularly in the acc.: : : :  cf.: : , § , § :  B. and K. .—So with esse:  cf.:    Klotz N. cr.; also with fieri: : : : .—So with acc. with a subject-inf., esse or fieri, even when licet is accompanied by the dat.: : :  Zumpt N. cr.: : is erat annus, quo per leges ei consulem fieri liceret  Oud. N. cr.—But more freq., in this case, there is an attraction of the predicate-noun to the dative dependent on licet.—Hence,  Licet alicui with inf., esp. with esse: : :  cf.: , A, 1: quare   judici mihi non esse liceat, : : : : : : .—With other verbs than esse: : — : : : . Cf. on this and the preced. construction, Krüger, Untersuchungen, vol. iii. p. 359 sq.; Ruddim. 2, p. 15; Zumpt, Gram. § 601; Madv. Gram. § 393, c. and obs. 1.— With ut, and more freq. with the simple subj.: : : : : : : : :  cf.  :  : :  . Cf. also under II. a.—（) As a v. impers. absol., with or without dat.: : : : : Ph. Sed quaeso, hominem ut jubeas arcessi. He. Licet, that may be or may be done, I have no objection, : : : :  cf.: : : . Transf. When licet introduces a subordinate proposition, which makes a concession, without abandoning the main proposition, it is used as a conjunction corresponding to quamvis, quamquam, etsi. In late Latin it is, like these, connected with the indicative, and in the class. per. it is not unfreq. opposed to tamen and certe in the main proposition; even if, although, notwithstanding.  With subj. : : : in comoedia maxime claudamus: licet Varro Musas Plautino dicat sermone locuturas fuisse, si Latine loqui vellent; : : . —With part. for subj.: .—With a corresp. tamen: : :   :   § 2: constet illi licet fides et benevolentia, tranquillitas tamen, etc., Sen.  Tranq. Anim. 7, 6.—With ellips. of subj.: .—With a corresp. certe: .— With indic. :  : : obduxi licet arma, sum Priapus, Poëta ap. Anth. Lat. 5, 218;  .— As an adv. with adj. or part., although : :   .—Hence,  lĭcens, entis, P. a., free, unrestrained, uncurbed, bold, forward, presumptuous, licentious.  Of persons : : : .— Of inanim. and abstr. things : : : : : . —Hence, adv.: lĭcenter, freely, according to one's own pleasure or fancy; and, in a bad sense, without restraint, boldly, impudently, licentiously : : : : .—Comp.: : : : : :  :  .— lĭcĭtus, a, um, P. a., permitted, allowed, allowable, lawful : : : : : .—In plur. as subst.: lĭcĭta, ōrum, n., things that are lawful: .—Hence, adv., in two forms: lĭcĭtē and lĭcĭtō, rightfully, lawfully .—Form licite, .—  Cod. Th. 11, 8, 3.

To sport, play with any thing, to practise as a pastime, amuse one's self with any thing: .—Esp., to play on an instrument of music, to make or compose music or song: : : : :  : .— To sport, dally, wanton : : affatim edi, bibi, lusi, Liv. Andron. ap. Paul. ex Fest. s. v. affatim, p. 11 Müll.; cf.:     .— Ludere aliquem or aliquid, to play, mock, imitate, mimic a person or thing : civem bonum ludit, Cael. ap.  cf.: : : : impia dum Phoebi Caesar mendacia ludit, Poët. ap. .— To trifle with: : .— To spend in play or amusement, to sport away: .—Hence, ludere operam, to throw away one's labor, to labor in vain, .— To make sport or game of a person, to ridicule, rally, banter:  a, 13: : .—Rarely with ad: .— To delude, deceive:  :  .—Comp.: .

, xi, ctum, 2 , v. n. and a. , to mourn, lament, bewail, deplore .  Lit.  Neutr.: :  : .—Impers. pass.: .— Act.: lugere mortem Trebonii, Cic. , āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to light up, brighten, illumine : : tellus floribus luminata, Marc. Cap. 1, § 27; .—Hence, lūmĭ-nātus, a, um, P a.: .

, lui, 3, v. a. , to wash, lave.—Lit.: : amnis moenia luit, Prud. . 3, 190.— Trop., to cleanse, purge: .

, lui , 3, v. a. , to loose, let go, set free.—Hence,  To release from debt: .— To pay a debt or penalty: : .— Luere poenas or poenam, to suffer as a punishment, undergo: : : : : .— To atone for, expiate : : : : : .— To satisfy, appease: .— To avert by expiation or punishment: : .
, āri, v. dep. n. , to associate with lewd women: cum meretrice per vias lupantur, Atta ap. : .
, āre, v. a., and lurcor, āri, v. dep. n. , to eat voraciously, to devour: : lardum, Pomp. ap. : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to purify by means of a propitiatory offering .  Lit.: : :  : : :  cf. : : : : non inveniatur in te, qui lustret filium tuum aut filiam tuam, nec divinus, Mos. et Rom. Leg. Coll. 15, 1, 1.— Transf., because, at the lustral sacrifice, the priest went around the person or object purified; hence,  To go around, encircle: .—  To go round, wander over, traverse: : latitudinem  lustrans signiferi orbis,  so : : : : : : .— Military term, to review:   cf.: .— To review, survey, observe, examine : : :    .— Trop., to review, consider: .— To illuminate, make bright:  :  :  : .
, āri, v. dep. n. , to frequent places of ill-repute: : : .
, ĕre, v. inch. n. , to turn to mud, become muddy: : cava terra lutescit, Furius Antias ap.  id. ap. .
, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to bedaub with mud or clay.  Lit., : : .— Transf., to bedaub, besmear: : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to put out of joint, to dislocate.  Lit.: : : : .— Transf., to put out of place, displace: : : .
, āri, v. dep. , to riot, revel, live luxuriously: luxantur a luxu dictum, id est luxuriantur, Paul. ex  Müll.; cf. :  Fleck.

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. n., and luxŭ-rĭor, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to be rank, luxuriant, abound to excess .  Lit.: : : : : .— Transf.  To wanton, sport, skip, bound, frisk: : : .— To have in abundance or excess, to abound in: : .— To swell, enlarge, grow rapidly: .— Trop.  Of style or language, to be luxuriant, to be too fruitful, to run riot:  cf.: .— To be wanton or licentious, to indulge to excess, to revel, run riot, be dissolute: : Capuam luxuriantem felicitate, id, 23, 2; cf. : : vereor ne haec laetitia luxuriet.   : .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. and n. .  To water, dilute with water: .— To drive out of one's senses, to distract with fear, to make mad: : : . —As neutr.: .—Hence, lymphātus, a, um, P. a., distracted, crazy, beside one's self, mad: : : : : : : : : .

, ēre, v. n. , to be lean, meagre:  cf. .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make soft or tender, to soften by steeping, to soak, steep, macerate .  Lit.: : : : : : : : : .— Transf., to weaken in body or mind, to waste away, enervate.  Of the body:  :  cf.: : : : : .— Of the mind, to fret, vex, torment, distress, torture, pain (syn.: :  cf. : : : : infelix sollicitudo persequitur nec oratorem macerat et coquit, * :  .—Poet., with a causal object-clause: .— Mid., to vex, torment one's self: : unum hoc maceror et doleo tibi deesse, Terenti, C. Caes. ap. Suet. Vit. Ter. fin.: ex desiderio magis magisque maceror, Afran. ap.  P.
, ĕre, v. inch. n. , to grow lean or thin, to become meagre :  : : : .

, ātus, 1, v. dep. a. , to contrive skilfully, to devise, design, frame, invent . , crŭi, 3, v. inch. n. , to grow lean, meagre:  : : : invidus alterius macrescit rebus opimis, grows thin at, pines away at, * : curionem agnum Plautus pro macro dixit, quasi cura macruisset, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. curionem, p. 60 Müll.

, fēci, factum, 3, v. a.; in pass.: mădĕfīo, factus, fĭĕri , to make wet, to wet, moisten, to soak, drench, water, etc.  In gen.: : ,  8, 23, § : : :  cf.:  : : .—Poet.: .— In partic., to drench with wine, to intoxicate, make drunk : eo vos vostrosque adeo pantices madefacitis, quom ego sim hic siccus, * :  cf.: .

In gen.: : campi, wet, marshy , : : : : :  so, : : .— In partic., drunk, intoxicated:  so absol.:  cf.: .— Transf., full, filled, imbued with something: jure madens, full of, i. e. skilled in law, : : .

Lit.: : tellus Nubibus assi   duis pluvioque madescit ab austro, : : nec madescimus nisi umore, * : spectare oportet, num tempora paulum madescant, become moist, i. e. perspire, —Poet.:  cf.: .—*  In partic., to get drunk, become intoxicated:  Mai.— Transf., to become soft:   .

Neutr., to be sad or mournful, to mourn, grieve, lament (class.; cf.: : nemo maeret suo incommodo; : : : : qui tuo dolore maerent, Sulp.  ap. : : :  § 64.— Impers. pass.: .— Act., to mourn over, bemoan, lament, bewail any thing :  : : : : : .— With acc. and inf.: : corpora Graiorum maerebat mandier igni, Matius ap. , āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to make sad or sorrowful, to sadden : :  .

, xi. ctum, 3, v. n. and a. , to speak ill of, to abuse, revile, slander, asperse; constr. absol., or with a dat. or acc. .  Absol.: .— With dat.: : : : :  .—Impers. pass.:  . — With acc.:  v. .— Esp., to curse, utter a curse upon : —Hence,  mălĕdī-cens, entis, P. a., evil - speaking, foulmouthed,  abusive, scurrilous : .—Comp.: .—Sup.: :  .— mălĕdictus, a, um, P. a., accursed : : : omnes incesti, Mos. et Rom. , fēci, factum, 3, v. n. , to do evil, harm, mischief to any one, to injure: : : .—With contra: .—Hence, mălĕfactum , i, n., an evil deed, injury: benefacta male locata malefacta arbitror, Enn. ap. : .
or mălfīo, fĭĕri, v. n. , to be injured , .
, 1, v. a., and mălignor, ātus, 1, v. dep. , to do or contrive maliciously, to malign .  Form maligno: : .— Form malignor: :  37, 8 sq.—P. a. as subst.: mălignan-tes, ium, m., the wicked,

, mālui, malle , v. a. , to choose rather, to prefer.  In gen., constr. with acc. of the person or thing, with an object-clause, or with subj. .  With acc. of the person or thing : bonos et senatum malet, Cael. ap. : : :  : :  .—In late Lat. also with acc. and dat.: .—  With object-clause : seseque ii perire mavolunt ibidem, quam, etc., Naev. ap.  Müll.; Enn. ap.  Müll.; : :   : : .— With nom. and inf.: : .—  With subj. : : : : .—Sometimes with comp. abl. instead of quam : : .—Sometimes followed pleonastically by potius: :  id. Cat. ap. Fam. 15, 5, 2; Anton. ap. , A, 3.—Also by quam: —Strengthened by multo or haud paulo: : .— In partic., to be more favorable to one: : .—Hence, mālens, entis, P. a., preferring , , ad 14, 4; Aug. c. Jul. 4, 14, 68.
, āre, 1, v. a. , to cement, to varnish , , Schol. Juv, 5, 48 Cramer.
, āre, 1, v. n. , to give suck : vae tunc praegnantibus et mammantibus, S. S. Marc. 13, 17, ap. .

, āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. .  To make over or deliver up as property by means of the formal act of purchase , to dispose of, transfer, alienate, sell .  Lit.: :  : : . — Trop., to give up to, deliver up, subject: : : de ignaviae latebris retractus curiarum functionibus mancipetur, Cod. Th. 12, 1, 83.—* I. q. manu capere, to seize, catch: .

Alicui aliquid: : : : : .—With ellipsis of dat.: : : .— With ut or ne: : : .— With simple subj.: .— With object-clause: : .—（) Impers. pass.: .— Transf.  In gen., to commit, consign, enjoin, confide, commend, intrust any thing to a person or thing: : : :   : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : .—Absol.: .—  To charge a person to announce something, to send word to a person or place only poet. and in post-Aug. prose): : : : : .—P. a. as subst.: mandā-tum, i, n., a charge, order, commission, injunction, command.  In gen.: : .—More freq. in plur.: : : : : : : : :  :  : : : : : : : : : legatis occulta mandata  data sint, ut, .—Poet., with inf.: .— Esp. as legal term.  A commission constituting a mutual obligation; hence, in gen., a contract:  sqq.: : .— An imperial command, mandate,  Traj. ap. : .—Esp. of the secret orders of the emperors:  : :  3, 16; .— In eccl. lang., the law or commandment of God: : : .

, di, sum , 3, v. a. , to chew, masticate .  Lit. : :  .—Poet.: : .—In part. perf.: mansum ex ore daturum, Lucil. ap.  : : .— Transf., in gen., to eat, devour : quom socios nostros mandisset impiu' Cyclops, Liv. Andr. ap.  P.; Enn. ap. , āvi, ātum, 1, v. a. , to set off, deck, adorn an article for sale : . —In part. perf.: .— In gen., to set off, adorn: .

Neutr.: manat omni corpore sudor, Enn. ap. ; cf.: : : : : : : : : : : : .— Act., to give out, shed, pour forth: : .—Poet.: fidis enim manare poëtica mella Te solum, to distil poetic honey, i. e. to be a poet, .—  Transf., of things not fluid, to flow, diffuse or extend itself, to spread: : : :  Müll.: manare  solem antiqui dicebant, cum solis orientis radii splendorem jacere coepissent, Paul. ex  Müll.— Trop., to diffuse or extend itself, to spread, get abroad:  cf.: : : : : : : .— Esp., to flow, spring, arise, proceed, emanate, have its origin, originate from any thing: : : : .— To escape, be forgotten: .

, fēci, factum, 3, v. a.; pass. mansŭēfīo, factus, fiĕri , to make tame, to tame .  Lit.: : uri assuescere ad homines et mansuefieri, ne parvuli quidem excepti, possunt, grow or become tame, : : : .—Transf.: .— Trop., to make gentle, to soften, civilize, pacify: a quibus mansuefacti et exculti, *: : : .

, 1, v. dep. , to steal : .— Transf., to act slyly, go cunningly to work: manticularum usus pauperibus in nummis recondendis etiam nostro saeculo fuit. Pass.: maritari, to be coupled, i. e. to have a mate: .— To impregnate:  so in pass., to be impregnated:   .— Of plants, to wed, i. e. to tie or fasten to another tree: :  :  cf. .—Hence, mărītātus, a, um, P. a., of or pertaining to a wife.—Comic.: A. To earn, gain, get, obtain, acquire: : iste, qui meret HS. vicenos, Varr. ap. : non amplius duodecim aeris, Cic.   Rosc. Com. 10, 28: : : : :  : : : : . —With ut : quem ego ut non excruciem, alterum tantum auri non meream, would not give up torturing him for, etc., : neque ille sibi mereat Persarum montes ... ut istuc faciat, would not do it for, etc., .—  To get by purchase, to buy, purchase: : : : : : .— In milit. lang., mereri and merere stipendia, or simply merere , to serve for pay, to serve as a soldier, serve in the army: : : : : : : : : : mereri aere publico, Varr. ap. .— Mereri de aliquo, or de aliquā re, to deserve or merit any thing of one, to behave in any manner towards one, in a good or bad sense : : : : saepe (erga me; .—Esp.: bene, male, optime, etc., mereri, to deserve well, ill, etc.: : : : : : : : : : : : :  cf.: .— Hence,  mĕrens, entis, P. a., that deserves or merits any thing; in a good sense, deserving; in a bad sense, guilty; that has rendered himself deserving towards any one or of any thing; with de, rarely with dat.; esp. with bene, well-deserving : : : quem periisse, ita de re publicā merentem, doleo, Cic. Rein. cl. 5, 35. — Pass., deserved, due, fit, just, proper, right: : : : : noxia, committed, perpetrated,  : meritis de causis, for merited, i. e. just reasons, .— Sup.: .—Hence,  mĕrĭtum, i, n.  That which one deserves, desert; in a good sense, reward, recompense; in a bad sense, punishment : : : .— That by which one deserves any thing of another, a merit; esp. in a good sense, a service, kindness, benefit, favor : : : : : :    .—In Plaut. also in the sup.: : : .—Also demerit, blame, fault: : : : :  cf.: .— Transf., worth, value, importance of a thing : : : aedificia majoris meriti, of greater value, Cod. Th. 15, 1, 30: : .— mĕrĭtō, adv., according to desert, deservedly, justly, often connected with jure : :  cf.: : :  . —Sup.: meritissimo te magni facio, Turp. ap.  :   S. C. ap.  ap. .—Post-class.: meritissime, .— In partic.: libens merito, a form of expression used in paying vows; v. libens, under libet.

fullText: , īvi or ĭi, ītum, 4, v. a., not to know, to be ignorant : : : : : : : : :  : :  .—With acc. and inf.: : .—With inf. alone: :     .— Pass.: : : .— Nescio quis, nescio quid, nescio quomodo, nescio an, used in an assertion to express uncertainty with regard to some particular contained   in it; and usually without influencing the mood of the following verb: nescio quis, I know not who, some one, somebody, a certain person: nescio quid, I know not what, something, some, a certain: : : :  in affected ignorance, to denote that a thing is insignificant, small, mean, etc.: : : : : : : : : : : nescio quid praeclarum, remarkable or extraordinary excellence, : : :  : :  :  cf.: : nescio an, I know not whether, probably, perhaps: : :  v. the art. an.— In partic. , pĕpendi, 2, v. n. , to hang, hang down, be suspended.  Lit., constr. with ab, ex, or in and abl.; also , with abl. alone, or with de: pendent peniculamenta, Enn. ap. : in candelabro pendet strigilis, Varr. ap. : : , § , § : : : : .—Of garments: : .—Of slaves, who were strung up to be flogged, : :   cf. : quid me fiet nunciam? Theo. Verberibus caedere pendens, :  .—Poet., of suspended votive offerings: , 3, 17; : : : .—Of one who hangs himself, : : .—Of any thing hung up for public notice; ,   —Prov.: pendere filo or tenui filo, to hang by a thread, i. e. to be in great danger: hac noctu filo pendebit Etruria tota, Enn. ap. :  .— Transf. .  To hang in the air, be suspended, to float, hover, overhang: per speluncas saxis structas asperis, pendentibus, Poët. ap. ; : : : :  : : .—So of birds, which float or hover in the air:  : .— .— To hang loosely together, be unstable, movable: .— To hang about, loiter, tarry, linger anywhere: .— To hang down, be flabby or flaccid, weak, without strength: : .— To weigh: : : .— Trop.  To hang, rest, or depend upon a person or thing ; constr. with ex, in, ab, the simple abl., or de: : :  : : : : : : : in sententiis   omnium civium famam nostram fortunamque pendere, :  :  : .— To hang upon a person's words, to gaze fixedly, listen attentively to : : : : .—With rel.-clause: :  .—Less freq.: pendere animo: atque animo noctu pendens eventa timebat, Cic. poët. ap. .—In plur.: :  dub. .—With cum: .—Law t. t., to be undetermined, to await decision:   .— To have weight or value: .—Hence, pendens, entis, P. a.  Hanging; in econom. lang., of fruits not yet plucked or gathered: : : : . — Pending; hence, in jurid, Lat., in pendenti esse, to be pending, undecided, uncertain: :  :

, pĕpendi, pensum, 3 , v. a. and n. .—Lit., to cause to hang down, to suspend; esp. of scales in weighing.  Act., to weigh, weigh out.  Lit. : unumquodque verbum staterā aurariā pendere, Varr. ap. : da pensam lanam, Titin. ap.  , read repensum: aere gravi cum uterentur  Romani, penso eo, non numerato debitum solvebant, Fest. s. v. pendere, p. 208 Müll.: .— Transf., to pay, pay out (because, in the earliest times, payments were made by weighing out the metals; v. in the preced. the passage from Fest.;  Müll.:  : : : : : : .—Absol.: .—Impers. pass.: .—As punishments consisted of fines in money or cattle: pendere poenas, supplicia, etc., signified to pay, suffer, undergo a penalty:  Müll.: : : : : : : .—Rarely in this signif. absol., to suffer any thing : .— Trop.  To weigh mentally, to ponder, consider, deliberate upon, decide (class.; : : : .— To value, esteem, regard a thing; with gen. of the value : : : : : : :  so,   : : : :    cf.: : : .— To pay, render : .— Neutr., to weigh : :   , § 93; .—Hence, pensus, a, um, P. a., lit. weighed; hence, trop., esteemed, valued, prized, dear : : ut nihil quicquam esset carius pensiusque nobis quam nosmetipsi, Taurus ap. .—Esp., as subst.: pensum, i, n., something weighed.  Weight, consideration, scruple, importance, only in gen. sing.: nihil pensi habere aliquid, to lay no weight or stress upon a thing, to attach no value to, be indifferent to, care nothing about: : : : :  : : aliquid ratum pensumque habere, Att. Capitol. ap. . —So, non pensi ducere , .—Also, non adest or est alicui pensi:  nec mihi adest tantillum pensi jam, quos capiam calceos, I don't care in the least, am perfectly indifferent, : : . — Prop., the wool weighed out to a slave to spin in a day; hence, a day's work in spinning, and, in gen., spinning, a spinner's task.  Lit. :  : : :  , , 15: , 3, 33: :   .—Poet., a thread spun by the Fates: : : mortale resolvere, to unbind his mortal thread, i. e. to make him immortal, .— Trop., a charge, duty, office (so in Cic.; cf.:  cf.: : :  : : .—Hence, adv.: pensē, carefully, considerately : pensius, Flav. ap. .

To demand or claim at law, to bring an action to recover, to sue for any thing (syn.: : : aliquando cum servis Habiti furti egit; : .— To beg, beseech, ask, request, desire, entreat ; constr with ab and abl. of pers. ; ante- and postclass., with acc. of pers.:  freq. with ut: : : : : : : : : .—Also, with id or illud, and ut, etc.: illud autem te peto, ut, etc., Dolab. ap. .—With obj.-clause :  cf.: cum  peteret donari quasi proprio suo deo, : petit aes sibi dari , .—De aliquo , to beg or request of one : .—Ab aliquo aliquid alicui, to beg a thing of one person for another : : ab aliquo pro aliquo petere, to intercede for: .—With ex and abl. pers. :  .—Hence, pĕtītum, i, n., a prayer, desire, request, entreaty, .— Polit. t. t., to apply or solicit for an office, to be a candidate for office : : :  .— To solicit a person, to seek to possess, to woo: : : :  cf.: quae tuus Vir petet, cave, ne neges; .— To endeavor to obtain or pursue, to seek, strive after any thing, : : : : : .—With inf.: :  : : .—With ex and abl., over, in the case of: : : .— To fetch any thing: : : : : :  cf.:  and: : .— To take, betake one's self to any thing: : : : .— To refer to, relate to : .

fullText: , gŭi, and pĭgĭtum est, 2, v. a. , to feel annoyance or reluctance at; to repent of a thing.  As a verb. pers. : pudet quod turpe est; piget quod dolet, Donat. ap. : .— Piget, piguit, or pigitum est, third pers. sing. impers., it irks, troubles, displeases, chagrins, afflicts, grieves, disgusts one; I , dislike, loathe, etc.; with acc. of the person and gen. of the thing; with inf.; with acc. and inf.; with two acc.; absol., etc. .—With acc. and gen.: mea mater, tui me miseret, mei piget, Enn. ap. : dolet pudetque Graium me et vero piget, id. ap. : : pudet pigetque mei me,  : : .—With subject-clause: non dedisse ipsum pudet; : nisi forte pudet aut piget recte facere, Sall. Or. contr. Lep. med.: : : : :  Auct. ap. : .—With neutr. pron.: : .—Absol.: .— Transf.  For poenitet, it repents one; I repent :  Müll.; Paul. ex  ib.: : : .— It makes one ashamed; I am ashamed:  .

fullText: , cŭi and cĭtus, cĭtum, 2, v. n. , to please, to be pleasing or agreeable, to be welcome, acceptable, to satisfy .  Lit. , dĭdi, dĭtum, 3 , v. a.   To give, put, or bring forth (class.; : : : : : .— In partic. Müll. : .— To extend, permit to go farther.  To put off, defer ,  Müll.— To prolong, = produco, de mendico male meretur qui ei dat quod edit, nam illi prodit vitam ad miseriam, — To hand down, transmit, bequeath : : : .— To propagate : .

, īvi or ĭi, 4, v. n., to sleep before :  Mai; so  5, 22.

, xi, ctum, 3 , v. a., to lead or bring forth, to lead forward or out.  Lit. : : : : : .—Esp.  To bring before the people, senate, or a court: : : cum tribunis   plebis Curionem et Octavium consules produxisset,  : : : : : : .— Of an actor, to represent, perform: . — To expose for sale: :  .— To draw or place one thing before another : : : .— To draw or stretch out, to lengthen out, extend : : : : .— To conduct to a place: .—  To conduct to the grave, sc. a corpse or a funeral procession : : .— To lead or bring along, to bring away: .— To bring to light, disclose, expose: . — In partic.  To bring forth, bring into the world, to bear or beget: :  Lucil. ap. : : .— Of other subjects, to produce, make : : .— = adduco in indicium, to bring forth to trial, ; .— To make to grow, to advance, promote : subolem. .— In pronunciation, to lengthen, prolong : :  .— Trop.  To bring forward , to raise, promote, advance : producere aliquem ad aliquam dignitatem. : : : : .— To lead, induce one to do any thing: : .— To draw or drag out, to lengthen out, prolong, protract : : : : : : : : : .— To put off, to amuse, delude one with fallacious promises: : .— Of time, to pass, spend : .— To bring up, educate: : : .— To make, devise, produce, bring into use: .— To plant, cultivate: .—Hence, prōductus, a, um, P. a., lengthened, long, prolonged, protracted, etc. :  Halm: : commoditates corporis  tam productae temporibus, : : . 53, 213:  so, : : .—  Subst.: prōducta, ōrum, n., preferable things : in vitā non ea, quae primario loco sunt, sed ea, quae secundum locum obtinent, , id est producta nominantur; quae vel ita appellemus , vel promota, et remota, vel, ut dudum diximus, praeposita, vel praecipua;  cf. .—Hence, adv.: prōductē, in a lengthened manner, long : : .—Comp.: .

, fēci, fectum, 3, v. n and a. , to go forward, advance, gain ground, make progress.  Lit. : .— Trop., to go on, advance, make progress; to profit, derive advantage; to perform, effect, accomplish, obtain, etc. .  Of persons: : : : : : : si modo in philosophiā aliquid profecimus, have made any progress, Cic.   Off. 3, 8, 37: —Of the sick, to get better: — Of manim subjects, to grow, increase : : .—In pass.: : .—In a bad sense: .— In partic., to be useful, serviceable, advantageous, etc., to effect, accomplish; to help, tend, contribute, conduce (class.; cf. :  .—Of remedies:  nec alia res celerius proficit, is of service, Plin 27, 11, 72, §  : .—Impers.: .—Hence, prōfĭcĭenter, adv., successfully , Aug Ep. 80: incedere, Hil. Trin. 1, 22; Cassiod in Psa. 133, 2.

, fectus, 3, v. dep. n. , to set out, start, go, march, travel, depart, etc. .  Lit.: : : : : :   : : : : :  : :   : : : : : : : : : : jussit proficisci exilium quovis gentium, Att. ap. : Jovinus eadem loca profectus, Amm 27, 8, 2.—With supine: .—Absol.: : : : : :   : : : : .— Transf., to be going or about to go, to intend to go to a place, to start : :    .— Trop.  In gen., to go, come, proceed: .— In partic.  To set out, begin, commence: :  : .— To come forth, spring, arise, proceed, originate:   : : : quaecumque a me ornamenta ad te proficiscentur, shall pass from me to you, i. e. you shall receive from me, : omnia quae a me profecta  sunt in te, tibi accidisse gratissime, all you have received from me, : :  cf.: .—So, to express descent :  .—Act. collat. form prŏfĭcisco, ĕre, to set out, go, etc. :  hortatur hominem, quam primum proficisceret, Turp. ap. .

, fessus, 2 , v. dep. a. , to declare publicly, to own freely, to acknowledge, avow, confess openly, profess .  In gen.  Absol.: : : .— With acc.: : .— With obj. clause:  .— With de: : .— In partic.  Profiteri se aliquem, to declare one's self or profess to be something:  Poët. ap.  : : : .—With esse: : .— Profiteri aliquid, to profess an art, science, etc.:  medicinam, to profess medicine, to practise as a physician, Cels. praef.;  .—In pass.: . —Absol.: profiteri, to be a teacher or professor : : .— Profiteri indicium, to give evidence, make a deposition against accomplices:  ,  : .— To offer freely, propose voluntarily, to promise: quis profitetur? who volunteers? Plaut Capt. 3, 1, 20: : : : : : magna, Hor A. P. 14; : .— To disclose, show, display, make a show of; dolorem, : : .— To make a public statement or return of any thing :  : : : : :  .—Absol.:   and 5:   also without nomen: : : professae , i. e. common prostitutes, who had to give in their names to the aedile, .—Trop.: .—Hence, prŏ-fessus, a, um, P. a., in passive signif., known, manifest, confessed : : .—Ex or de professo, openly, avowedly, intentionally, professedly: : .

, fātus, 1 , v. dep. a., to say or speak out, to say, speak .  In gen.: veteres Casmenas cascam rem volo profari, tell, relate, Att. ap. , ŭi, ĭtum, 2 , v. a. , to hold in front, i. e.,  To hold back, keep in check, to restrain, hinder, prevent, avert, keep or ward off, debar .  In gen.; usually constr. aliquem or aliquid, with abl.; alone or ab and abl.; with ut, ne, quominus, or an obj.-clause; also with simple acc.; less freq. with de, the dat., or gen. Fest. l. l.: quod di prohibeant, which may the gods forbid or avert,   cf.: di, prohibete minas;  and: .— In partic., to forbid, prohibit a thing (syn.: : : :   cf.: : .— To keep away from a thing for the sake of safety , to keep, preserve, defend, protect ; with ab: : .—With abl.: : : : .—With double acc.: .

, mpsi , mptum , 3, v. a. , to take, give, or bring out or forth, to produce Lit.: : Pa. Prompsisti tu illi vinum? Lu. In gen., to bring, put, or draw forth est aliquid, quod non ex usu forensi...sit promendum et assumendum, : : : : .—  In partic., to bring to light, disclose, utter, tell, express, relate, etc.: percuntanti promere omnia. : : . verba, quae sensum animi nostri optime promunt,  § : promere aliquid  loquendo, : : qui pueris utile carmen prompturus est, wishes to publish, App. Flor. p 358 med.; cf.: .—Hence, promp-tus , a, um, P. a., prop. brought to light, exposed to view; hence,  Visible, apparent, evident, manifest : inimicitiam atque amicitiam in frontem promptam gero, Enn. ap. : :  prompta et aperta, : : .—Sup.: .— Transf.  At hand, i. e. prepared, ready, quick, prompt, inclined or disposed to or for any thing = paratus, expeditus.  Absol.: : : : : : : : .—Sup., .— With ad or in aliquid : : : : : : : : : in latrocinia, Flor 4, 12, 10; cf. in comp.:  and in sup.: : .— With pro or adversus : : — With abl.: :  cf.: :  : .—Comp.: : .—（) With gen.: .—Sup.: .—（) With dat. : : : : : . —（) With inf. : : .— In gen., brave, courageous: maxime vellem, rem publicam in periculis a promptissumo quoque defendi, Sall. Readily, quickly, without delay, willingly, promptly: : distribuere pecuniam  legatis, .—Comp.: : .— Sup.: .— Easily: : .

Magis me benigne nunc salutas, quam antidhac,  cf.   : : : : : : :  cf. passively: Pompeius eo proelio Imperator est appellatus. Hoc nomen obtinuit, atque ita se postea salutari passuś est, *  so,  : aliquem dominum regemque. :   : bene vale Tironemque meum saluta nostris verbis, greet in my name, for me, Curius ap. : : .—Absol.:  .—Of paying reverence to a divinity:     : —Of wishing one well when sneezing: .—Of greeting a place: :  cf.  .—  To bid farewell, to take leave : : .— In partic.  To visit out of compliment, to pay one's respects to, to wait upon a person: : : :   cf.  .—  To greet one's visitors : .— Under the emperors, of the morning attendance at court,       et saep.

, ēre, v. n. .  To be well, or in good health; so in the verb. finit. only once in a lusus verbb. with the foll.; v. II. 1. fin.— In partic., as a term of salutation.  Salve, salveto, salvete, God save you; how are you? I hope you are well; and, salvere jubeo, I bid you good-day, goodday, welcome, etc. : Ly. Charmidem Lysiteles salutat. Ca. Non ego sum salutis dignus? Ly. Immo salve, Callicles, : Ph. Curculio exoptate, salve. Cu. Salve. Ph. Salvum gaudeo te advenire, : Cr. O Mysis, salve. My. Salvus sis, Crito, : He. Ergasile, salve. Er. Di te bene ament, Hegio, : Am. Salve, adulescens. Sc. Et tu multum salveto, adulescentula, : Pl. Pater, salveto, amboque adeo. Dac. Salvos sies, : Le. Gymnasium flagri, salveto. Li. Quid agis, custos carceris?  cf. : : : : : : : Dionysium jube salvere, greet ,  cf.: : : .—Hence, also, once, salvebis, i. e. you are saluted: .—Of a salutation, i. e. adoration of a divinity: .—Poet., in a solemn address to any revered object:  : : .—Also on one's sneezing, God bless you! Giton ter continuo sternutavit ... Eumolpus salvere Gitona jubet, . —In a lusus verbb. alluding to the prim. signif.: Ph. Salve. Le. Egon' salva sim, quae siti sicca sum?  cf. infra, 2.—With a similar allusion, in the verb. finit.: As. Salve. St. Sat mihi'st tuae salutis, nihil moror, sat salveo; — Sometimes with vale, in taking leave, farewell, goodby, adieu:  cf.: :  .— Hence, also, in bidding farewell to the dead: ideo mortuis Salve et Vale dici, non quod aut valere aut salvi esse possunt, sed quod ab his recedimus, eos numquam visuri, Varr. ap. :  cf. .—In allusion to the literal signif. : Ar. Salve. Ph. Salvere me jubes, quoi tu abiens affers morbum, .

, xi, ctum, 4 , v. a. , to render sacred or inviolable by a religious act; to appoint as sacred or inviolable.  Lit., mostly of legal ordinances or other public proceedings, to fix unalterably; to establish, appoint, decree, ordain; also, to make irrevocable or unalterable; to enact, confirm, ratify, sanction .  Sancire legem : :  cf.:  and: : : :  et saep.—Pass.: , and 13, 44; cf.: : : : jus utile civitati, Pompon. ap. : : : :  so :     cf. poet.: .— Sancire lege aliquid, de aliquā re, ut, ne, etc.:  cf.: : :  cf. : : : : : :  cf.: : : : : : .— Without abl.:  cf.: :  4, 13: : : .— With acc. and inf.: : .—  Lex sancit, decrees, ordains : :  cf.: .— Poet., with relative-clause: . — To render sacred to any one, to devote, consecrate, dedicate:  cf. : templum, Coripp. 4, 264.— Transf., to forbid under pain of punishment, to enact a penalty against :  cf.:  : : : .—With abl. of fine: .—Hence, sanc-tus, a, um, P. a.  Orig., rendered sacred, established as inviolable, i. e. sacred, inviolable (whereas sacer signifies consecrated to a deity. Thus, e. g., a temple, grove, or the like, is sacer locus; :  cf.: : : :  : :  so, : —Hence, aerarium sanctius, a special treasure of the State, which was only to be used in cases of extreme necessity .—Of persons: : : .—Because to the idea of inviolability is readily attached that of exalted worth, of sacredness, or divinity , sanctus denotes,  Venerable, august, divine, sacred, pure, holy ; of a divinity, and of things in any way belonging to one: Saturno sancte create, Enn. ap. : Juno Saturnia sancta dearum, id. ap. : teque pater Tiberine tuo cum flumine sancto, id. ap. :  :  : :  : : :  et saep.—  : : : : : .— Of character, morally pure, good, innocent, pious, holy, just, etc. : cum esset ille vir exemplum innocentiae, cumque illo nemo neque integrior esset in civitate  neque sanctior,  cf.: : :  cf.: : : veteres et sancti viri, Sall. Fragm. ap. :  cf.: : : :  cf.: : : :  et saep.: :  cf.:  so comp.: : : : :  cf. . — In eccl. Lat., substt.  sanctus, i, m., a saint, holy man: : . — sanctum, i, n., a holy place; esp.:  et saep.: .—Also in plur.:  et saep.: violare sancta, id. Judith, 9, 11. —Adv.: sanctē , solemnly, conscientiously, scrupulously, religiously, with holy awe, etc.:  :  :  cf.: : : : : : :  cf.: : : : .
, ĕre, v. inch. n. , to become sacred: per nos sanctescat genus , Att. ap. .

, īvi or ĭi , 3, v. n. and a. , to taste, savor; to taste, smack, or savor of, to have a taste or flavor of a thing .  Lit. .  Of things eaten or drunk: : : : .—With an acc. of that of or like which a thing tastes: : : .—Poet.: anas plebeium sapit, has a vulgar taste, Petr. poët. 93, 2: .—*  Of that which tastes, to have a taste or a sense of taste : .—  Transf., of smell, to smell of or like a thing : Cicero, Meliora, inquit, unguenta sunt, quae terram quam crocum sapiunt. Hoc enim maluit dixisse quam redolent. Ita est profecto; : .—In a lusus verbb. with signif. II.: istic servus quid sapit? Ch. Hircum ab alis, .—  Trop.  To taste or smell of, savor of, i. e.,  To resemble : .— To suggest, be inspired by:  .— Altum or alta sapere, to be high-minded or proud: : .— To have good taste, i.e. to have sense or discernment; to be sensible, discreet, prudent, wise, etc. .  Neutr., : :  cf.:      cf.:  : : :  Poët. ap. :  so,  ,  13;    et saep.;  :      :    :  : : : hi sapient, * : Ph. Ibo. Pl. Sapis, you show your good sense,  : :  cf. : : : :    cf.: : .— Act., to know, understand a thing : : : qui sibi semitam non sapiunt, alteri monstrant viam, Poët. ap.    cf.: : : : : : nihil parvum, i. e. to occupy one's mind with nothing trivial ,  cf.: cum sapimus patruos, i.e. resemble them, imitate them in severity, . — Prov.: sero sapiunt Phryges, are wise behind the time; or, as the Engl. saying is, are troubled with afterwit:  Müll.: .—Hence, să-pĭens, entis , P. a. , wise, knowing, sensible, well-advised, discreet, judicious .  In gen.:  cf.: : :  cf.: : : : :  Ruhnk.; so, :   et saep.—With gen. : .—Subst.: săpĭens, entis, m., a sensible, shrewd, knowing, discreet, or judicious person:  cf.:  :   : : :  1, 3, 132.—In a lusus verbb. with the signif. of sapio, I., a person of nice taste: : fecundae   leporis sapiens sectabitur armos, .—As a surname of the jurists Atilius, C. Fabricius, M'. Curius, Ti. Coruncanius, Cato al., v. under B. fin.— Of abstract things: : : : : : : : .— After the predominance of Grecian civilization and literature, particularly of the Grecian philosophy, like  well acquainted with the true value of things, wise; and subst., a wise man, a sage : ergo hic, quisquis est, qui moderatione et constantiā quietus animo est sibique ipse placatus ut nec tabescat molestiis nec frangatur timore nec sitienter quid expetens ardeat desiderio nec alacritate futili gestiens deliquescat; : : :  cf. .—So esp. of the seven wise men of Greece: : : .—Ironically: .—With the Romans, an appellation of Lœlius: te, Laeli, sapientem et appellant et existimant. Tribuebatur hoc modo M. Catoni: scimus L. Atilium apud patres nostros appellatum esse sapientem, sed uterque alio quodam modo: Atilius, qui prudens esse in jure civili putabatur;  cf.: :  , ext. 7; .—Hence, adv.: săpĭen-ter, sensibly, discreetly, prudently, judiciously, wisely:  : : : : : : : :  : : :  .—Comp.:  : : .—Sup.: .
, ĕre, v. n., =  to eat putrid meat, .

Originally, rem solvere, to free one's property and person from debts , according to the ancient formula:  Huschke; cf.: : .  —Hence, rem solvere, to pay; often with dat. of person: : : : : : : .—Trop.: saepe edunt ; .—And to pay by other things than money: : : .—Hence,  Absol. , to pay; with or without dat. of person: : : : : .—Pass. impers.: : : : .—Cf. in the two senses, to free from debt, and to pay, in the same sentence: .— With acc. of the debt, to discharge, to pay: : : : : : :  so, : :  : : .—And of moral debts: : : :  fin.— By a confusion of construction, solvere pecuniam, etc., to pay money, etc. ; constr. with dat. or absol.: : , § : : : : : : :  so : sorte creditum solvere, by paying the principal , : : : : : : :  so, .—Transf., of the dedication of a book, in return for favors: —Of the delivery  of slaves:  .—Transf., poet.: dolorem solvisti, you have paid your grief, i. e. have duly mourned, .—Pass. with personal subject: . —（) Esp., in certain phrases, to pay:  so, : : : cum homo avarus, ut ea solveret sibi imperare non posset, etc., Cael. ap.  cf.: non dicimus reposuit beneficium aut solvit;  but v. : in debitum solvere, to make a partial payment: : aliquid solvere ab aliquo , to pay out of funds supplied by any one : : : : : solvo operam Dianae, I work for Diana, i. e. offer a sacrifice to her, Afran. ap. : judicatum solvere, to pay the amount adjudged by the court, for which security was required: :  so    .—Gerund.: solvendo esse, to be solvent; jurid. t. t., to be able to pay, i. e. one's debts; cf. : : : :  so   , §§ 1 and 4; 46, 1, 52, § 1; 46, 1, 28; 50, 17, 198 et saep.: non solvendo esse, to be insolvent: : : :   cf.: — To fulfil the duty of burial.  Justa solvere; with dat. of the person: : : : : .— Exsequias, inferias or suprema solvere: : : .— Votum solvere, to fulfil a vow to the gods.  Alone: : : : : : : : :    ext.; 1, 1, 8 ext.—Poet.:  cf.   sq.:  et saep.: .— With dat.: :  : : : .— Fidem solvere, to fulfil a promise :   but cf.: itane imprudens? tandem inventa'st causa: solvisti fidem, you have found a pretext to evade your promise , : esset, quam dederas, morte soluta fides, by my death your promise to marry me would have been cancelled ,  similarly: suam fidem solutam esse, that his faith in Lepidus was broken, Planc. ap. .—With a different construction: se depositi fide solvere, to acquit one's self of the duty to return property intrusted to him ,  ext.: factique fide data munera solvit, he freed the gift already given from the obligation of an accomplished fact, i. e. he revoked the gifts, although already made, .—  Promissum solvere, to fulfil a promise : :  .—Hence, sŏlūtus, a, um, P. a., free, loose, at large, unfettered, unbandaged.  Lit. Pigeat nostrum erum si eximat aut solutos sinat, : : : : : : : .— Of texture, etc.; esp. of soil, loose, friable (opp spissus;  :   : : .—Of plants: .—Hence, subst.: sŏlūtum, i, n., a state of looseness: .— Rarefied, thin, diffused: : : .— Trop. Of speech, unfettered, fluent, ready: : : .— Exempt, free from duties, obligations, etc.: : :    : .— Free from punishment, not punishable, not liable, etc.: qui mancipia vendunt, certiores faciunt emptores quis fugitivus sit, noxave solutus, Edict. Aedil. ap.   cf.: : : : antea vacuum id solutumque poenā  fuerat, .—With subj. inf.: : solutum existimatur esse, alteri male dicere, Caecil. ap. .— Free from cares, undistracted: : , § 82.— At leisure, free from labor, business, etc.: : .—With gen.: .— Unbound, relaxed, merry, jovial: : : : .—  Free from the rule of others, uncontrolled, independent: : : : : .—Of animals: .—  Free from influence or restraint; hence, independent, unbiassed, unprejudiced:  : : : : : .— Free from moral restraint; hence, unbridled, insolent, loose: : : : : : : : : .— Regardless of rules, careless, loose: : .— Esp., of style, etc., free from rules of composition.  Oratio soluta, verba soluta, a free style, conversational or epistolary style:    9, 4, 77.— More freq.: verba soluta, oratio soluta, prose ; :  71, 234;  de heisce rebus treis libros ad te mittere institui; : : : : :  55, 184; : historia est quodammodo  carmen solutum, .— Also in reference to a prose rhythm, loose, unrhythmical, inharmonious:  : :  but: verba soluta suis figuris, words freed from their proper meaning, i.e. metaphors, .— Rarely with reference to the thought: soluta oratio, a fragmentary, disconnected style:  cf. :  .— Effeminate, luxurious : .— Undisciplined, disorderly: : : .— Lax, remiss, weak: : : .—Hence: : .— Paid, discharged, only as subst.: sŏlūtum, i, n., that which is paid, a discharged debt, in certain phrases:   : in solutum accipere, to accept in payment: :    aliquid pro soluto est, is considered as paid or cancelled: : pro soluto usucapere, to acquire by prescription something given in payment by the debtor, but not belonging to him: .—Adv.: sŏlūtē.  Thinly: .— Of speech, fluently: : : .— Irregularly, loosely: .— Freely, without restraint: .— Of style, without connection, loosely: .— Of manners and discipline, disorderly, negligently: : .— Weakly, tamely, without vigor: .— Of morals, loosely, without restraint: .

Lit. : impactus ita est saxo, ut sopiretur, became unconscious or senseless, was stunned,   :   fin.;   .—In part. perf.: castoreo gravi mulier sopita recumbit, Lucr b, 794; so, : : :  : ; 31, 23;     :  : sopitae quietis tempus, of deep or sound sleep, .— In the poets, pregn., to lay to rest, i. e. to kill: .—Pass., to be laid to rest, to die:  cf. .— Transf., of things concr. and abstr., to lull to sleep, set, or lay at rest; to calm, settle, still, quiet: : :   cf.: : draconis saevi sopivi impetum, Enn. ap. , spŏpondi, sponsum, 2 , v. a. .  Jurid. and publicists' t. t.  In bargains, covenants, treaties, etc., to promise solemnly, to bind, engage, or pledge one's self ; according to the civil law in its original form, it was essential to a binding contract verbally made that a proposition and its acceptance should be expressed by the question spondes? and the answer spondeo; and only at a later period was the use of promitto, etc., valid : verbis obligatio fit ex interrogatione et responsione, velut, Dari spondes? Spondeo. Dabis? Dabo. Promittis? Promitto;    cf. : De verborum obligationibus: He. Aeternum tibi dapinabo victum, si vera autumas ... Er. Sponden' tu istut? He. Spondeo, : qui stulte spondet, Cato ap. : : : : : .— To promise for another, to become security for a person, to enter bail, etc.: : : : : : . — Transf., of promises or pledges made in behalf of a government, etc.: : : : : .— Esp., to promise or engage in marriage, betroth: qui uxorem ducturus erat ab eo unde ducenda erat, stipulabatur eam in matrimonium ductam iri;   qui daturus erat itidem spondebat. Tum quae promissa erat sponsa appellabatur, qui spoponderat ducturum, sponsus, Sulp. Dot. ap. : Ly. Istac lege filiam tuam sponden' mihi uxorem dari? Ch. Spondeo. Ca. Et ego spondeo idem hoc,  : Me. Etiam mihi despondes filiam? Eu. Illis legibus, Cum illā dote quam tibi dixi. Me. Sponden' ergo? Eu. Spondeo, : Ph. Spondesne, miles, mi hanc uxorem? Th. Spondeo. Ph. Et ego huic victum spondeo, : sponden tu ergo tuam gnatam uxorem mihi? Ch. Spondeo et mille auri Philippum dotis, .—Hence, of women, alicui sponsam esse, to be betrothed, engaged to a man: : , 6;    .— = sponsionem facere , to lay a judicial wager, to enter into an agreement to pay contingent on the truth or falsity of an assertion: si hoc ita est, qui spondet mille nummūm? P. Afric. ap. , 11, 9.— So, absol.: ; .— In gen., to promise sacredly, to warrant, vow .  With fut. inf.: : : : : :  cf. : .— With inf. pres., to warrant, give assurance of an existing fact: .— With acc. of thing : : mihi sex menses sati' sunt vitae, septimum Orco spondeo, Poët. ap. : ea spondent, confirmant, quae, quidem mihi exploratiora essent, si remansissem, Cic : : :  : : : : .— Transf., of inanim. or abstract subjects : : : : .— Hence, sponsus, a, um, P. a., promised, engaged, betrothed, affianced; substt,  sponsus, i, m., a betrothed man, a bridegroom: virgo Sponso superba, Titin. ap. :  : .—Poet., of Penelope's suitors, .— spon-sa, ae, f., a betrothed woman, a bride:  :  et saep.—Prov.: suam cuique sponsam, mihi meam, i. e. every one to his taste, Atil. ap. .— sponsum, i, n., a covenant, agreement, engagement: sponsum negare, to break or disown one's pledge,  :  Müll.— Esp., a judicial wager : .
