, ŭi, ūtum, 3, v. a. , to cause to stand .  Corporeally.  To cause to stand, set up, set, station, fix in an upright position.  To set up, set in the ground, erect: : : : : : : :  .— To plant : : .— In gen., to place, set or fix, set up, set forth things or persons.  Without specifying the place: :  so, : haec carina satis probe fundata et bene statuta est, well placed, i. e. so that the hull stands perpendicularly (cf.: : :  so, aciem statuere, to draw up an army: .— With designation of the place by in and abl.; by adv. of place; by ante, apud, ad, circa, super, and acc.; by pro and abl.; by abl. alone , or by in and acc. : signa domi pro supellectile statuere, Cato ap. : : : : : :  : : : : : : : .—Of living beings: : : : : : : : : : : : , ext. 6: : : : : : : .— Pregn., to construct and place, to set up after constructing,  to erect, make.  Of statues, temples, columns, altars, trophies, etc.; constr. with acc. alone, or acc. of the structure and dat. of the person for whom or in whose honor it is erected: : : :  so  9, 7, 16;   so, : : : : :  so : : : : : : : :  § 70; so,  : ut illum di perdant qui primus statuit hic solarium, Plaut. Fragm. ap. : : : : : : : : : : .— Poet. and in post-class. prose : :  so with two acc.: custodem medio statuit quam vilicus horto, whose statue he placed as protectress, etc.,  cf. .— Of cities, etc., to establish, found, build : : : : , 21:  so, .—Hence, transf.: carmen statuere = carmen condere, to compose, devise a song: .— To cause to stand still, to stop (rare; cf. : , 9, 4: : sanguinem, Oct. .— To cause to stand firm, strengthen, support , only transf.: qui rem publicam certo animo adjuverit, statuerit, Att. ap. . Trop.  To establish, constitute .  Esp.: exemplum or documentum , to set forth an example or precedent for warning or imitation: :  : : , § : : statueretur immo   documentum, quo uxorem imperator acciperet, a precedent, .— Jus statuere, to establish a principle or relation of law: : qui magistratum potestatemve habebit, si quid in aliquem novi juris statuerit, ipse quoque, adversario postulante, eodem jure uti debebit, if he has established any new principle of law, Edict. Praet. in : : . — In gen., to establish by authority : : : : : : :  so : .— With double acc., to constitute, appoint, create: , a, 2: : : .— To determine, fix, etc. ; constr. usually with acc. and dat. or acc. and gen.  Modum statuere alicui or alicujus rei, to determine the manner, mode, or measure of, assign limits, restrictions or restraints to a thing or person, to impose restraints upon.  With dat.: : : affirmabant, libertati publicae statuturum modum, : :  pr.: : :  . — With gen.: : : , 36: .— Condicionem or legem alicui, to impose a condition or law upon one, to dictate, assign a condition to: : : : pretio statutā lege ne modum excederet, etc., the law being assigned to the price that not, etc., i. e. the price being limited by the law, etc., : .—So with ellipsis of dat., to agree upon, stipulate: : . — Finem, to assign or put an end to, make an end of: : : , ext. 1: majores vestri omnium magnarum rerum et principia exorsi  ab diis sunt, et finem statuerunt, finished,  so, : .— Pretium alicui rei, to assign a price to something; fix, determine the price of something: : :  so with dat. understood: :  so with in and acc.: ut in singulas amphoras centeni nummi statuantur, that the price may be set down at 100 sesterces for an amphora, .— Statuere diem, horam, tempus, locum alicui rei, or alicui, or with dat. gerund., to assign or appoint a day, time, place, etc. : : : : : : .—With ellipsis of dat.: : .—Esp. in the part. statutus, fixed, appointed : : : : : : : :  and 20.— To recount, count up, state : statue sex et quinquaginta annos, quibus mox divus Augustus rempublicam rexit: adice Tiberii tres et viginti ... centum et viginti anni colliguntur, count, fix the number at, : .— To decide, determine, with reference to a result, to settle, fix, bring about, choose, make a decision.  Of disputes, differences, questions, etc., between others.  With interrog.-clause: : : : : : : : : : : : semel nobis esse statuendum quod consilium in illo sequamur, August. ap. . — With de: , B, 8: : : : qui ab exercitu ab imperatore eove cui de eā re statuendi potestas fuerit, dimissus erit, Edict. Praet. in  .—Often with reference to punishment: : : :  so  cf.  2, 85; —In partic.: de se statuere, to decide on, or dispose of one's self, i. e. of one's life, = to commit suicide: .— With de and abl. and interrog.-clause: .— With contra: . —（) With indef. obj., usu. a neutr. pron.: : : : : : : : :  :  cf.: , C, 11.—（) With de or super and abl.: : : .—（) Absol., mostly pass. impers.: : : .—（) With cognoscere, to examine and decide: : :  : .— With reference to the mind of the subject, to decide, to make up one's mind, conclude, determine, be convinced, usu. with interrog.clause: : : : : : : : : : : : .—So with apud animum, to make up one's mind: : .—Rarely with neutr, pron. as object: : .— To decree, order, prescribe.  With ut or ne: statuunt ut decem milia hominum in oppidum submittantur,   : : , § , § , § : : .—So of a decree, determination, or agreement by several persons or parties to be carried out by each of them: : : .—  With acc. :  : .—So with sic : .— With dat. and acc. : : : : : : : .— With dat. and interrog.-clause: : .— In partic., of punishment, etc., to decree, measure out, inflict.  With poenam, etc., with or without in and acc. pers. : : : : :   cf. .—Absol.: .— With indef. obj., generally with in and acc.: aliquid gravius in aliquem, to proceed severely against: : : : : .— With a word expressing the kind of punishment : .— De capite, to pass sentence of death: .— Referring to one's own acts, to resolve, determine, purpose, to propose, with inf. (first in Cic.; : : : : : , § : : : : si cedere hinc statuisset,  : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : : , 13; so, .—With sic: .— To judge, declare as a judgment, be of opinion, hold , think, consider .  With acc. and inf.  In gen.: : : , § , ut quisquam juris numeretur peritus, qui id statuit esse jus quod non oporteat judicari, who holds that to be the law, : : : : : : : : : : .— So with sic: : : : . —Hence, statui, I have judged, i. e. I know, and statueram, I had judged, i. e. I knew: : .—With neutr. pron.:  cf.:  .— Particularly of a conclusion drawn from circumstances, to judge, infer, conclude; declare : : quod si aliter statuetis,  videte ne hoc vos statuatis, qui vivus decesserit, ei vim non esse factam, : : : .—With neutr. pron.: :  cf. , supra; so, .— Esp. with gerund.-clause.  To hold, judge, think, consider, acknowledge, that something must be done, or should have been done: : statuit, si hoc crimen extenuari vellet, nauarchos omnes vitā esse privandos, he thought it necessary to deprive, etc., , § : : . —So with opus fuisse: : causam sibi dicendam esse statuerat jam ante quam hoc usu venit, knew , , § 101. — To think that one must do something, to resolve, propose, usu. with dat. pers.: : quae vobis fit injuria si statuimus, vestro nobis judicio standum esse, if we conclude, purpose, to abide, etc., : : : : : : : : : .— With ut: : : quae majora auribus accepta sunt quam oculis noscuntur, ut statuit, as he thought, i. e. that those things were greater, etc., : .— With two acc. : : : : : : : : : .—P. a.: stătūtus, a, um, i. e. baculo, propped, leaning on a stick : .—Hence, subst.: stă-tūtum, i, n., a law, decision, determination, statute : : : .

, fŭi, esse , v. n. , to be, as a verb substantive or a copula.  As a verb substantive, to be.  In gen.  Asserting existence, to be, exist, live: : : : : : : est locus, Hesperiam quam mortales perhibebant, Enn. ap. : :  cf. : : : : : : : : : per quinquennia decem fuimus, Prud. Cath. praef. 2.— Of events, to be, happen, occur, befall, take place: : : : . —  Of location, to be present, to be at a place.  With adv., or other expressions of place: :  : : : : : te hic tutissime puto fore, Pompon. ap. , A.— Of passages in a book or writing, with in and abl., to be, stand, be written, etc.: : .— Of personal relations, with ad or apud and acc., or cum and abl. of person: : : :  cf. with simul: .—Hence, esp.: esse cum aliquo , to be with, i. e. live with, associate with, as husband or wife: :  :  : tum ad me fuerunt, qui, etc., Varr. ap. : :  cf.: .— Of relations analogous to place, of dress, condition, position, office, etc., to be, live, be found, etc., with in and abl.: : : sive erit in Tyriis, Tyrios laudabis amictus; : hominem non modo in aere alieno nullo, sed in suis nummis multis esse et semper fuisse, Cic. Verr   2, 4, 6, § : : : : : : : : :  : : : : : : .—So with abl. without in, when qualified by an adj.: : :  (B. and K. ex conj.: : :  esp. in phrase periculo alicujus esse, to be at the risk of any one: :  Weissenb. ad loc.: : .—  To depend upon, rest with, with in and abl.: : : : . —  In partic.  Esse often stands without a subject expressed, or with an indef. subj., as antecedent of a rel.-clause, whose verb may be in the indic. or subj.; the former only when the subject is conceived as particular or limited, and actually existing; the latter always when it is conceived as indefinite; cf. Zumpt, Gram. § 562 sq.; Roby, Gram. § 1686 sq.; Madv. Gram. § 365; but the distinctions usually drawn by grammarians are not always observed by the best writers; and the subjunctive is always admissible, being the prevailing construction after sunt qui in class. prose, and nearly universal in postAug. writers: sunt, qui , there are those who , or simply some.  With indic.  Without subject expressed: : : : :  cf.: : :  : : : : : : : : : :  fin.: : : : :  Kühn. N. cr.: :  Müll.: : :  cf. : sunt quibus  unum opus est, etc., : : .— With a subject expressed by an indefinite word or clause: : :  Fleck. : : : : : : : : : :  cf.    : : haec sunt, quae clamores et admirationes in bonis oratoribus efficiunt. : .— With. subj.: sunt, qui discessum animi a corpore putent esse mortem; : : : : : : : :  et saep.— With a more or less indefinite expression of the subject: : :  : : : , cf.: : : : : : : : : : : : .— *  Poet.: est, quibus : , 17.— With dat., to belong or pertain to; or, rendering the dative as the subject of the verb, to have : aliquid reperiret, fingeret fallacias, Unde esset adulescenti, amicae quod daret, Ter. , ŭi, ĭtum, 2, v. n. , to be strong.  Lit., of physical strength, vigor, or health.  In gen., to be strong, stout, or vigorous, to have strength .  Absol.: verum illi valent, qui vi luctantur cum leonibus, Pomp. ap. : : plus potest, qui plus valet: Vir erat; : : : : .—Of plants: —  To be strong in or for something, to have the power or strength, be in condition to do something, etc.  Of personal subjects, etc.  With ad and acc.: .—  With inf.: : :  cf. II. B. 2. h. infra; cf.: : :   — Of remedies or medicines, to be efficacious, be good for any thing; with ad and acc.: .—With contra: .—With eodem: .—With pro: .—With abl.: .— With inf.: .— Of sounds: cum C ac similiter G non valuerunt, in T ac D molliuntur, i. e. were not pronounced strongly, .— Esp., in respect of the natural condition of the body, to be well in health, to be in a sound or healthy condition, to be healthy, hale, hearty.  In gen.  Absol.: :  : : facile omnes, quom valemus,  recta consilia aegrotis damus, :  : :  : : : : deterius quam soleo, Luccei. : : Ni. Benene usque valuit? Chr. Pancratice atque athletice, : : .— With abl.: :  cf. : : .— With ab and abl.: :  and facetiously: Me. Ain tu te valere? Eu. Pol ego haud a pecuniā perbene, as to money, not very well, .— Esp., at the commencement of letters , si vales, bene est, and abbreviated S. V. B. E.;    14, 17; 14, 21; 14, 22; 14, 23; 14, 24; 15, 1; 15, 2; Metell.  Vatin.  Luccei.  cf.:  so too: S. V. G. V. et Tullia nostra recte V. Terentia minus belle habuit: sed certum scio jam convaluisse eam, Dolab. ap. .—  Rarely impers. pass.: .— Vale or valeas, in leave-taking, farewell, adieu .  In gen.: Di. Valeas. Ph. Vale, : Ar. Vale. Ph. Quo properas? Ar. Bene vale,  : :  : vale atque salve. Th. Male vale, male sit tibi,  v. salvus: Ly. Ad portum propero. De. Bene ambulato. Ly. Bene valeto. De. Bene sit tibi, : : : : : : .—Before a vowel, scanned vălĕ:  .— At the conclusion of letters:    Luccei. :   rarely bene vale, Mat.  Cur.  cf.:  : fac valeas meque mutuo diligas, Planc.  Mat. .— Also in bidding farewell to the dead:   cf. Varr. ap. Serv. Verg. l. l.; : : .— As an expression of dismission, refusal, or scorn, be off, begone: : : : : : valeant, Qui inter nos discidium volunt, away with those, etc., : : castra peto, valeatque Venus, valeantque puellae, farewell to Venus, etc., :  cf.    sqq.—（) With valere jubere or dicere , to bid one good-by, farewell, adieu: : : :  : obstinatissime   retinuit, ut liberti servique bis die frequentes adessent ac mane salvere, vesperi valere sibi singuli dicerent,   .—So :  . Transf., to have power, force, or influence; to be powerful, effective, valid; to avail, prevail, be strong, effective, etc.  In gen.: : : : : : : : : : : : :   .— Esp.  With respect to the source, character, or mode of exercise of the strength ascribed to the subject.  With abl.: : : : : : : : :  : : : : .— With in and abl.: : : : : .— With some definite end expressed, upon or towards which influence or power is exercised or directed, to be strong enough for, adequate to, or capable of any thing, to be able to do, to have force or efficacy, to be effectual, to avail, to be applicable.  With in and acc.: :  cf. : : : :  cf.: .— With eo: oratio me cohortabatur, ut, etc. ... quod eo, credo, valebat, ut caerimonias religionesque defenderem, the force or point of which was, etc., :  cf. Of money value, to be of the value of, be worth: denarii, quod denos aeris valebant;  Müll.: : : : :  .— Of the signification of words, sentences, etc.; like the Gr. , to mean, signify, import: : non usquam id quidem dicit omnino; : : : cui nomen Becco fuerat; :  et saep.: : .—Hence, vălens, entis, P. a., strong, stout, vigorous, powerful . Well in health, healthy, hale, hearty: : :  cf. : : : , 20.—Subst.:  .—  Of medicines, strong, powerful, active: : :  cf. .— Trop., strong, powerful, mighty: : : : : : : : : : :  so, : : : .—Hence, adv.: vă-lenter, strongly, stoutly, powerfully, violently .
